text:
Jay thank you so much for an EXCELLENT thick, pan type pizza crust, that was crisp on the outside and chewy/tender on the inside! 
The only personal perference additions I did were: I added Italian Seasoning, garlic powder and onion powder along with the salt/oil. And I baked them for 10 minutes prior to adding the toppings in a 12 inch cake pan and 12 inch cast iron skillet, that were both olive oiled WELL, and dusted with yellow cornmeal. They came out of the pan very easy onto the cutting board. 
It was easy to make this. Just have to adjust weather and flour consistency to the stickiness of the dough. Some days need less, some days need MUCH more. Adding about a 1/2 cup grated parmasean cheese to the dough is great with the seasonings. I never roll the dough out, I just use my hands and flatten it in the bottom of the pans, working up the sides Also sometimes string cheese rolled in the crust makes the kids happy too.

text:
I had been looking for a pizza crust similar to Pizza Hut pan style and this is the closest and best so far!  It definitly makes 2 crusts unless you have a huge pizza pan.  And the trick to getting a crisp bottom on your crust is to bake it on a lower rack in your oven so your crust bakes before your toppings burn.

text:
I tried this crust last night and was very pleasantly surprised. I kneaded it with the dough hook on my stand mixture and left the dough slightly sticky to acheive a more tender crust. I rose beautifully and was very easy to stretch into two medium pizzas. I baked the pizzas on a pizza stone preheated for an hour at 500 degrees. They baked in about 8 minutes. The bottom of the crust was very crunchy (but not burnt) and the edges were nice and soft. I've had problems with tough crusts in the past, but this one was nice and tender. I will make it again!

The crust needs a little something so i brushed it the second day with an mixture of olive oil and garlic powder. It rises amazing! and it tastes like real pizza crust. My husband loved it and I think from now on I will make my own dough because it is sooo easy and much cheaper than buying the frozen ones. I can't wait to make it again! Thanks JAY!

text:
Great Recipe, comes out perfect. I find it’s great for making large batches and freezing.  Before letting the dough rise portion it out into the sizes you would like to use and cover the portions with oil.  Place the dough balls on a cookie sheet and freeze them till there solid then place in a freezer safe container.  This way they don’t stick together while freezing.  When you want to make a pizza take out a ball rub it with a bit more oil and let it stand about 6 hours.  Then roll, top it and pop it in the oven the same as the recipe.   I’ve tried defrosting it in the microwave but you need to watch it carefully to make sure the dough does not start to cook.  Also because of the nature of dough it can easily pick up odors from the freezer so you might want to pop some baking soda in there while your at it.

country:
None
text:
*update* I've made this several times and this makes a top-notch pizza crust with a crispy crust and chewy center.  I double the sugar and increase the salt to 1 1/2 tsp because it’s a tad bland as written.  I recently substituted 1 C flour for whole wheat flour and found it did not alter the texture.  100% whole wheat made the dough gummy and hard to roll out.  Kneading was difficult and messy the first time.  I recently tried doing most of the kneading in my stand mixer with a dough hook and then kneaded the rest by hand.  This made the dough much more manageable.  In the end, I added an extra 3/4 cup of flour (1/2 C flour in the stand mixer & 1/4 C while kneading by hand) but it still came out tender.  I baked it on the bottom rack on a preheated baking stone to get the bottom crispy and used corn meal to transfer from the peel instead of flour (a la Pizza Hut vs. Dominos).  Made 2 crusts.

text:
The recipe is good but the directions can be better.  
    On step three, before you put it into the oiled bowl place the ball on the counter and your hands on either side and just force the ball to travel in a circle on the counter until the ball is tight and completely smooth
  Put it in the bowl, cover it with plastic wrap (dont worry about making a seal) and put it in the FRIDGE
  Yes, I said it, in the fridge, yeast will continue to do its thing in the cold.
  Now leave it in there 12-18 hours, the dough will still double in size (for me it doubles in the fridge within 3 hours but I leave it in there longer to let the yeast develop more flavor)
  Take it out and cut the dough in half (two smaller pizzas are easier to toss in the air than one large one, but you don’t have to do that) flatten it with your hands, then fold it back onto itself and form a ball.  Roll the ball between your hands as before until it's tight, cover it with a damp kitchen towel and let it rest for 30 minutes (the recipe said one, but that’s not enough)
  Stretch (dont use a rolling pin) or throw the pizza until it's the size you want (the outside will be higher and you'll get the rising lip that pizzas have) and bake it the same way the recipe calls for.  
  I use an insulated cookie sheet that is nonstick so I dont have to grease it up and I just build my pizza on that but if you have a pizza stone, use that or buy an unglazed ceramic tile for a few dollars and use that as a pizza stone.

text:
After you try this, you may want to throw away the numbers to Pizza Hut and Dominoes!  This is easy, tasty, and CHEAP.  You will get a thick crust (if you make one big pizza) without all the oil and grease.  Very healthy!  I was a little taken aback when I took the mixture out to knead it because it was very sticky.  I thought this was going to be another dough-attempt disaster!  But after a while, it gets better when adding more flour.  I would suggest you have another person there to help you sprinkle on the flour or a plate of it ready because your hands will be a mess.

None
text:
This is a great pizza crust!  It's easy to make, is easy to work with and tastes awesome every time!  I make this recipe in my bread machine, which makes it even easier.
If you like thin crust, this recipe will yield 2 large pizzas.  I you only need 1, this recipe freezes like a dream!  After the dough rises and is ready to be rolled out, just divide in half, spray the spare half with a tiny bit of oil and then wrap in plastic wrap, place in a ziplock back and throw it in the freezer.  When you're ready to use it, take it out of the freezer 3-4 hours prior to use, unwrap it, and let it sit at room temp. or in a slightly warm spot to thaw and rise one more time.  Perfect!

This recipe was good. Mylady, your yeast didn't activate. Check your water temperature and make sure no drafts are hitting the dough while it is rising. Also your oven temp may be too low.
Cooking and baking are 2 different arts, as candy making would be another.
Use this if you like a soft and spongey crust. I cut my dough in half and used one half for pizza and the other for bread sticks. The 'Way Too Easy' sauce recipe was perfect for the breadsticks!

text:
Delicious and easy, especially since I let my bread machine do the hard part for me! One recipe made two crusts for me - used one, froze the dough for the other.  Rather than using a pizza pan I formed the dough right on the pizza peel sprinkled with corn meal and slid it in the oven onto the pizza stone.  Experienced breadmakers will know the measurement of flour is only a guide since so many factors, like humidity, are responsible for how much you'll ultimately use.  I don't usually use sugar in my pizza dough but this tiny bit of brown sugar couldn't have made a huge difference in either feeding the yeast or browning the crust. It must work its magic somehow, however, because this crust was excellent.

text:
I have made this pizza crust several times, and it is definitely a favorite!  I've never made bread before, so it took a while to get used to the whole kneeding process (but it always tasted good!).  My husband asks for this as often as he thinks he can get away with... :).  Like others, we found the flavor lacking, so I've made the following modifications:
1.  Double the brown sugar
2.  Add 1/4 tsp of garlic powder in with the salt
3.  1 cup of whole wheat (to make it more healthy, it improves the texture also!)
4.  Added some parm. cheese while adding the flour.
5.  Make sure to use cornmeal on your pizza stone (pizza stone is a must, yummy!  $12 at Bed Bath and Beyond) so it doesn't stick.
6.  Cook crust for 6-7 minutes without toppings, then brush the edges with olive oil before adding topings.

We make this with pizza sauce III.  yummy!  Thanks Jay!!! :-)

text:
This has been my pizza recipe for over 2 years now, and it is consistently wonderful. I usually add more brown sugar than called for, probably about a tablespoon or so. Also, the amount of flour needed can vary by the weather, so just start with three cups and add more as you're kneading, until the dough is no longer sticky. Initially, we used this to make 2 12" pizzas, but then I bought a 16" pan and now only make one 16" pizza. It makes the best medium-thick, chewy crust. If you haven't yet, try this recipe--You will love it!!

text:
Fabulous recipe. I warmed tha bowl of my stand mixer and followed step 1. After adding ingredients from step 2 I mixed the dough on speed 2 using the dough hook for 1 minute. Next I added the remaining flour and continued to mix on speed 2 for an additional 2 minutes. I then placed the dough in an oiled bowl to rise for about an hour as suggested. Besides using a stand mixer the only thing that I changed is the cooking temperature. I preheated the oven to 475 degrees and cooked the pizza for 10 minutes then turned the oven temp down to 425 to finish the cooking time. My husband commented that this was the best pizza that I have made. Thank you for sharing a great recipe and I hope this may help someof you who would like to use the mixer instead of good old fashioned elbow grease (like me)!

text:
This made the most wonderful crust ever! Very crispy crust with a soft chewy center. Takes 1 packet of yeast...I stood there measuring and after I did I wondered why didn't the submitter just say 1 pkg? I'm not knowledgeable enough in breadmaking to have known that but I won't forget it now. I made 1 change and that was to add 3 cups of flour at once and then work in the last 1/3 cup during the kneading. Hubby and I both agreed this is THE BEST piza crust we have ever eaten. This made 4 12" thin and wonderfully crispy crusts. LOL, this was my second try at "real" pizza dough, so I felt brave and actually tried to spin it, hand toss it...it is an art, mine were so uneven and oddly shaped, but it was sure fun to try. Hubby got a kick out of watching. I need never try another recipe again, this one is the cat's meow as my DH said.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Finally a pizza crust that's thick and chewy! Delicious! I did sprinkle the crust with a little garlic powder, oregano, and Parmesan cheese before spreading on sauce and toppings. NOTE: Add more than 2 cups of flour before trying to mix until it's not 'sticky' as the instructions indicate. My hand's were covered in sticky dough until I added at least 3 1/2 cups total. I suggest at least 3 cups of flour before adding extra and kneeding. I also don't suggest pouring it on a 'well floured' surface. Just keep working with the dough in the bowl and it will save you a lot of hassle and clean-up.  NOTE: This should make about 4 medium sized pizzas. You can freeze the rest of the dough for up to 6 months. Just roll out 10" rounds onto well oiled parchment paper (make sure all sides of paper that touch the dough are well oiled. Wrap tightly in plastic wrap to store. When you're ready to use the dough, let it thaw 30 minutes on counter before topping and baking.

text:
This is FANTASTIC!!  I've made it a ton of times now and love it every time!  I have an el-cheapo standard pizza pan and this makes 2 crusts *that* size.  I generally use one and toss the other ball of dough in the freezer to enjoy at a later date.  I've never rolled the dough, I merely stretch and push it out to fit the pan, which I spray w/PAM and layer w/white corn meal.  I've also used 1/2 whole wheat flour and it's just as fantastic.  I do have to say, I've always had to use quite a bit more flour than the recipe calls for to get it elastic-like and non-sticky.  I use my KA mixer, using my scraper paddle first, then finishing w/the dough hook.THANK YOU, Jay, for sharing your signature pizza crust; LOVE IT!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This crust is so good that I have been making pizza at least twice a week for the last month - seriously. I have used regular flour, bread flour, wholewheat flour - even tried some rye flour for one pizza. My favourite is the regular flour, but if you like the crust "doughy-chewy", go with bread flour and you will not be disappointed.

I halve this recipe to make one pizza. To make it even better, I like to add 1 tsp each of garlic powder and basil to the dough when I am adding the salt and oil. Sprinkle the oiled pizza pan with cornmeal. Once the toppings are on the pizza, stir a bit of garlic and basil into some oil and brush along the crust. Sprinkle that with cornmeal. Makes a super crispy crust that melts in your mouth.

userID:
1469904
Display Name:
Katie-Kate
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6968.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's worth it to make this as opposed to a packaged mix. I finally mastered using yeast. My biggest trouble was getting it to rise enough. Now I put the bowl of dough on a heating pad and cover the bowl/pad with a towel. Does the trick every time!

Another note about this recipe... it is a LOT of dough for one pizza. It will easily make two smaller pies or one larger one. I often double the recipe and then cut my dough into fourths. I freeze three of the quarters before letting it rise. Then when I want one I just pull it out and let it thaw and rise over my heating pad. It is excellent.

A couple of the different pizzas I make are buffalo chicken, and ham with mushrooms. For the buffalo chicken I top the crust with a thin layer of light blue cheese dressing, then a light layer of hot sauce, then cooked chicken coated with hot sauce and a pizza blend cheese. For ham and mushroom, I use a very sweet pasta sauce and smoked provolone cheese... that smoked provolone is the secret to a fantastic pizza!

TheGizzy

text:
After using Allrecipes for years, I was finally motivated to register just so I could comment on this recipe.  I grew up in Chicago, and I am VERY picky about pizza crusts.

Thus far, we've only made this once (tonight!) but I can already see what amazing potential this recipe has.  I cut the recipe in half, and ended up only using 2/3rds of it to make my crust.  It still was not quite as thin as I prefer, but that was by choice since this was a first attempt.

I baked it on a pizza stone which I'd rubbed down with olive oil & pre-heated in a warm oven.  I also used garlic salt instead of salt, and added a bit of garlic powder (1/4t), onion powder (1/4t) & oregano (1/2t) and about 1/2t more olive oil.  I also brushed the crust with some melted butter & minced garlic.

I ended up using more flour than the halved recipe called for.  It's one of those things I think you have to sort of "eyeball."  You just know when it's right.

I believe this crust will make excellent deep dish pizza as well, and plan to try that next week.  I also plan to try using 1/4 of the full recipe to make a very thin crust pizza (think Giordano's or Aurelio's).

My family was very pleased with the results of tonight's adventure.  This was nowhere near as difficult as one might expect.  One more note:  I think it's necessary to use more sauce on the pie than one would normally expect, simply because of the nature of the dough.

text:
I've been making this for a long time and don't know why I never rated it.  This is by far the best pizza crust I've ever tried!  The only tip I want to add is to get the perfect round pizza without tossing it.  I learned this a few years ago on the Food Network.  Shape your dough into a ball.  With your index and middle fingers, push down in the middle of the dough.  Then work your fingers in a circular rotation as the dough pushes out.  Keep doing this until dough is completely laid out.  If you're like me, you can't toss your crust and trying to get a nice round pizza with your hands, rolling pin, or whatever makes for an odd looking round pizza, then you will appreciate this tip.  At least I did!  :)  Hope that helps!

text:
Yes! It is an outstanding crust, but it's not exactly rocket science.

This is essentially the recipe that came with my Oster bread making machine; I use it all the time and I do prepare it in the machine, it's a snap.

Whether you roll-it-out for the thin, crispy crust variety of pizza, or let it rise in a Chicago style pan for a thicker more olive oil infused crust, it works very well.

Oven heat is the key to good crust and savory pizza, that's why coal-fired and wood burning pizza ovens are so popular; you can get UP there in the 500 to 600 degree range.

It doesn't take too long, but the crust comes out with an out-of-this-world finish on it, especially when you do a focaccia, which is not hidden under any sauce and/or cheeses!

Stay hungry, my friends...

Display Name:
sarah

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of the best pizza crust recipes out there. I have made it several times, both with all-purpose, whole wheat, and a mixture of the two -- all are delicious. Use the listed flour amounts as a guideline; it changes every time depending on the climate, but generally I will need to add a few tablespoons or more extra flour per recipe and knead for 5-10 minutes to get it to a workable, elastic consistency. I make this the night before I need it, and allow it to slow-rise in the fridge. Remove from the fridge and let sit on a floured surface for ~20 minutes before rolling it out. It's great! Brush with olive oil and par-bake it for ~7-10 minutes at 450F before topping it and putting it back in the oven at 400F, and the bottom crisps up beautifully! Highly recommend.

This has been my go to crust for years.  I sometimes add various herbs and spices to the crust but it's good as is as well.  Last night I got three different textured crusts out of this recipe.  I got a nice crisp crust rolling out dough thin  with lots of flour and cooking on stone positioned on lowest rack.  I got a "pan" style pizza by rolling out medium and placing in a cake pan lined with foil and coated with a  heavy tablespoon of evoo.   I got a thin but sturdy(not floppy) and soft crust by cooking on one of those pans with holes in it positioned on top rack. We were in pizza heaven.

Wow Jay, you've really done it!  This crust was really easy to make.  I didn't even have to toss it.  I just shaped it into the pan.

A word of warning: the dough is very sticky, and there's enough to make two pizzas.  I only made one pizza because I was too lazy to shape another one.  My crust was really thick, but next time I will make two.

The texture of the dough reminds me of Pillsbury dinner rolls: really dense with a hint of sweetness.  It wasn't crusty and crunchy like a traditional crust, but that might have been because my crust was thick.

I'm going to use this recipe to show off to my friends!  Fresh baked pizza tastes so much better than store bought.

text:
Wow!  This is one of the most consistent recipes for pizza crust I have used.  Every time, the crust has the same consistency, texture, snap, and taste.  It has never let me down.
To this, I do add one caveat: I feel his oven temp. is too low. I bake at 500, preferably using a pizza stone, and for 8-10 minutes.  This gives a crispier crust than the original temperature, and has the mouthfeel of a crust from a fine quality pizza oven.

It was easy and good. I did 2 cups white/1 1/3 whole wheat (and it did take all the flour). I also added 1 tsp each of onion and garlic powder to the crust for a little flavor. I too divided it into 2 crusts. I prebaked 1 while the oven was preheating, then i did the second as our pizza. The first I froze for another time. I just came back to edit. I just used the frozen crust for a quick pizza and it was just as good as the first. I pre heated the crust on a stone for 12 minutes then added the sausge toppings and cheese and baked another 6-7 minutes... Just made it again and I still love it!!

Well, Now I think I've used this recipe about 100 Times and it is by far the best.  Thick crust, Thin crust, with seasonings and without, white or red sauce it's all phenominal.  We were on vacation this summer with a total of 16 people, so I made 7 pizzas and 2 strombolis.  Pizzas with 4-5 toppings, double stuffed pizzas, you name it. text:
I've never been brave enough to try to make homemade pizza dough but thought I'd give this one a try.  Really good and nice and light, but there is a lot of work involved.  I first attempted to make it in my bread machine on the "dough" setting.  Came out really gooey.  Perhaps that is because I didn't let the yeast set first.  I remade it by hand and it came out fine, although I agree with other reviewers that it is quite sticky to work with.  I had to add quite a bit more flour.  Also, I only added 1/2 tsp. of salt and should have put the entire amount in.  It was a little flavorless.  I made 2 med. pizzas on pizza stones and stacked them in the oven.  The top crust didn't bake up quite right and was a little soft.  The next time, I will use the convection oven.

text:
Easy to make!  Try it with your Kitchen Aid mixer using the dough hook attachment.  It's so easy and only takes two minutes to knead.  If you use a pizza stone you'll get superior results that remind me of a brick-oven pizzeria.  This is a soft, thick, bread-like crust with a crunchy exterior and chewy interior.  Tastes similar to DiGiorno's frozen pizza, but better (and cheaper!).  I recommend spicing up the crust with garlic powder, oregano, rosemary, or anything else you want to add.  This is definitely a keeper!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1042052.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time trying this recipe out.I like that it is a very simple crust to make with items you probably already have on hand. There was enough dough to make two pizza crusts, one for a 16 inch pan and one for a 12 inch pan. The dough had a very nice consistency and was easy to roll out. I did not use a pizza stone, and based on other reviewers, I pre-baked my crust for five minutes before adding the sauce and toppings. I also brushed the crust with melted butter and garlic before I popped it in. I baked each pizza for 17 minutes once I put everything on it, and the crust came out beautifully. It was light and crispy underneath the pizza and slightly crispy, but soft inside around the edges. My only drawback with this crust is that it isn't very flavorful on its own, which is why I am so glad I decided to put that butter/garlic concoction on before I baked it! It's an easy problem to solve with just a pinch of various spices. Next time I think I will add minced garlic to the dough itself while mixing it. This is a keeper for me.

text:
I have had this saved in my recipe box forever, but have been reluctant to try it, as I like my crust pretty thin.  Finally, I decided to try it out.  When adding the salt, I also added 1/2 teaspoon each of dried basil, parsley and tarragon.  After I punched down the dough and formed it into a ball, I put it in a Ziplock bag I had lightly coated in olive oil.  I put it in the fridge overnight, and pulled it out for dinner tonight.  I separated it into 2 portions, and rolled one out. ..I brushed Uncle John's  sauce liberally on the dough, put it on a pizza stone and baked it for about 8 minutes.  Then I pulled it out, topped it with homemade pesto sauce, slices of fresh mozzarella cheese (hint: to make perfect slices of fresh mozzarella, place it in the freezer for about 15-20 minutes- much easier to slice!), and fresh from the garden tomatoes.  The crust was a tad thicker than my normal preference, but I am not complaining.  To say this pizza was scrumptiously delectable would be a major understatement!  Thank you for sharing this recipe Mr. Sharp...truly a go-to, palate-pleasing winner :)

this recipe is perfect.  i made a double batch, let it rise the first time overnight, punched down the dough, then divided into 10 balls.  flattened each one to a 6-8 inch circle, then par baked at 400 for 5 minutes on a cookie sheet sprinkled with corn meal.  now i have a freezer full of individual pizza crusts, ready for toppings at a moments notice!  thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Ok, to begin with, I followed every step of the recipe (used yeast that was just purchased from the store two days ago). I triple-checked measurements. My yeast proofed just fine. Everything was perfect until I came to the point in the recipe that said, "Turn dough out onto a clean, well floured surface..." HAHA. At that point, my "dough" was the consistency of pancake batter...literally. I had to add approximately four more cups of flour just to get to the sticky point. That was on top of the 2.5 cups of flour the recipe calls for adding to the mixture. I lost count on the cups of flour to get my dough to the NON-sticky point. The dough rose perfectly after about an hour it had doubled. I punched it down and allowed it to relax. I rolled it out. I had a 20 minute preheated 425F oven...allowed the dough to rise on my pizza pan before adding the toppings. I cooked it for 15-20 minutes as directed and ended up with white, dry bread with sauce, cheese & canadian bacon.

This recipe is promising...it was my first homemade pizza crust.  I was worried about the dough because I had to add an awful lot of flour to get it to not be sticky, and then after I let it rise it was really sticky again so I added a little more.  The recipe said if you're baking it on a pizza stone, you can go ahead and add ingredients and bake the pizza, but I really think I should have prebaked it a little.  My pizza was doughy on the bottom.  The crust had a good taste, so I will definitely try this one again, and prebake it next time.

text:
Wow, excellent recipe, added 1 tsp of brown sugar instead of half. Easy, crispy and light inside. I rolled it out pretty thin on a big square cookie sheet, ended up with 16 pieces of pizza. I also brushed the dough with a mixture of olive oil, black pepper, oregano, crushed garlic and pizza spice then let it rise the last 20 min before adding the toppings and baking it for 15 min. Hands down the best homemade pizza I've made.

Great pizza crust! It really takes a total of 4 cups of flour to make it not sticky.  Use your Kitchen-Aide with the dough hook attachment and you won't even have to mix or kneed the dough at all!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/92993.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my 1st time making pizza crust from scratch and it was super easy and tasted wonderful!  I followed the instructions in the recipe along with a  couple tips provided by other reveiwers:  1) instead of using regular salt, I used 1 tsp. of garlic salt; 2) I mixed in the following spices to the flour for additional flavor - 1/2 cup Parmesan cheese, 1 tsp. garlic powder, 1 tsp. dried basil leaves, 1/2 tsp. onion powder; 3) After you roll out the dough, use a fork to puncture holes into it to allow even rising in the oven; 4) Pre-bake pizza crust alone for ~ 7 minutes on the lower oven rack so that it's crunchier on the bottom; 5) Remove crust and add a thin layer of pizza sauce & toppings and bake for an additional 10-12 minutes.  You can't go wrong with this recipe!

text:
So tasty! I made the dough in my breadmaker: First put in the 'wet' ingredients (water,oil) then the salt & sugar and eny spices you'd like to add (I added some basil, oregano, and Parmesan cheese). Next, add the flour then make a little well in the flour, and add the yest into that well. Set the bread machine to the white dough cycle and press Start! I believe this recipe makes enough dough for 2 pizzas...this time I used my pizza stone & brushed the crust with the 'garlic juice' that is in the jar of minced garlic (before baking)...yum! Next time (with my leftover dough), I think I'll try making a deep-dish by baking the pizza in a cast-iron round dish. We all loved this crust, perfect! :D
PS- (sorry forgot to add)...if you want to make your dough in the bread machine, you're going to have to add much more flour (I ended up adding in about 1 cup more).

text:
Not that this needs another great review-but it was such a success, that I have to chime in.  I used 1 Tbsp of brown sugar to proof the yeast (1pkt) and added some parm cheese, garlic and onion powder to the mix as I mixed in the flour.  I probably used a scant 3 cups and only kneaded for a couple of minutes to get the dough into a non-sticky ball.  I didn't want to overwork the dough and toughen it.  I used the whole dough in a 14 1/2 inch pan, let it rise again for about 10 minutes while I got the toppings ready.  I stuck the dough into the over for 7 miuntes, pulled it out, added all my toppings and cooked it for another 7 minutes -a total of 14 minutes.  THIS WAS THE BEST PIZZA WE'VE EVER MADE!!!!!!!!  I had never done a homemade crust before because I was a little scared of the whole yeast thing, but MAN, THIS WAS SOOO EASY AND SOOOOO DELICIOUS!!!! We'll never used prepared pizza crust again!  Thanks for an easy and delicious recipe!!!!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic recipe!  I just added a 1/2 tsp of garlic powder.  I used my Kitchen Aid with the bread hook to mix at a 2 speed for two minutes and then at a 6 speed for eight minutes.  I found that the higher speed of kneading makes a huge difference in the stickiness of the dough.  The gluten needs to activate so that you don't have such a sticky dough (still some what sticky though).  I sprayed a glass bowl and my hands before I handled it.  It is much easier to work with that way.  Formed into a ball, covered with Saran wrap and I let it rise for an hour before I rolled it out and placed it on my pre-heated pizza stone.  Baked for 5 min.  Poked holes  and added toppings (prego traditional sauce, mozzerela cheese, olives, and pepperoni).  Baked for an additional 10 min and I had a very yummy pizza that my family loves!  I think that this would make great breadsticks as well.  I will have to experiment.  Thanks so much!!

text:
Great flavor but the proportions are a bit "off". I don't know if it's a typo but maybe it should read "1 cup water". Pizza dough is often 1 part water and 3 parts flour. The yeast solution needs to foam to see whether or not the yeast activated. Also, try adding 3 tablespoons vital wheat gluten for a fluffier crust or bread flour instead of all purpose. I also used a pizza stone at the bottom rack of the oven. Overall, good recipe!!

Display Name:
PTcook

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the only pizza crust recipe I use.  3 1/3 c. flour is not enough flour, unless you do 3 1/3 cup packed flour.  I usually up mine to about 4c. flour (measured by weight or by spooning flour into a measuring cup).  I throw everything into the bread machine on the dough setting and omit the oil.

I have used this with whole wheat flour or white whole wheat flour, and prefer the texture to AP flour or bread flour.  (However, the dough does not rise as much with whole wheat flour.)  I pre-bake the crust (after you roll out the dough, poke the crust with a fork a few times otherwise you'll have bubbles baked into the crust) for about 10 minutes and then add sauce and toppings.  I use a pizza stone unless I'm making chicago style deep dish...then I use a cast iron pan.

text:
This is an awesome recipe!!!  The key to good pizza making is the pizza stone.  I have always put together the pizza on an aluminum pan then put it in the oven.  The correct way is to heat up a pizza stone in the oven for 20 mins. at 450 degrees.  Assemble the pizza on a wooden pizza shovel.  Then gently shovel the pizza onto the heated stone in the oven.  The pizza comes out like a gourmet restaurant pizza.  This recipe is good becuase the crust is crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside.  Try it, you won't be disappointed.

text:
This is almost the exact recipe as the one that can with my stand mixer.  Only difference is the brown sugar.  I have not put brown sugar in my crust but it is a great recipe without it.  For crispy thin crust pizza, roll it out really thin and prebake for 5 or 6 minutes.  Put plenty of corn meal on baking sheet so it does not stick.

Then put the sauce on soon as it comes out of the oven.  When you bake the pizza, slide it on the oven rack without the cookie sheet.  Bake pizza at 425 for 8-9 minutes.  Result is great!  I've shared my pizza with 7 people and now they keep asking when they can come over for more.  Share at your own risk.

This was a first for me although I have been cooking for 40 years I never have made my own pizza dough.  My Dad used to make his own pizza's for parties often, so I figured I would give this a try.  I did roll it out very thin making two pizzas.  Added a teaspoon of garlic powder to the flour.  Living in Colorado was a little cool out so put the dough in the laundry room on the washing machine and turned the dryer on, closed the door and it rised to perfection.  The bottom of the crust didn't get as crisp as I would like but that is due to figuring out the right temp and time for my oven and high altitude not the recipe.  Had a great taste, was very easy to work with, and offered a very pleasant experience for my first pizza dough!  Thank you for this submission!

text:
I've made this recipe many times since I first found it.  It's the only recipe I use for pizza crust anymore! I've made it with white flour, half white and half whole wheat, and white whole wheat flours, on a pizza stone or a baking pan, with garlic and herbs and plain - and it's been great every time.  I use a KitchenAid mixer and it makes it a snap.  I do find that I need to use a little more than 4 cups of flour, though, to make a dough that isn't sticky.  It freezes well - I usually divide the dough in half, wrap one half in freezer paper and put in a zipper bag and then freeze.

I can't give it a five-star rating since I don't really know what /great/ pizza crust tastes like. Otherwise, it was easy to make. Made two thin 14" crusts or one thicker 16" crust. If you're pressed for time/space/motivation, don't bother kneading it and just add the full amount of flour all at once. It hasn't seemed to make any difference to me how I add the flour.

None
text:
We have not ordered pizza delivery a single time since I started using this recipe. The crust is so versatile, and I've added different herbs to it (rosemary, basil, oregano) with great results each time. Sometimes I cut the recipe in half for one regular size pizza, but mostly I make the entire recipe and save half, wrapped tightly in plastic wrap while still in dough form, for up to 2 days.  You can make two pizzas with the recipe, and I've found that if you pat out the dough out into your circle of crust and let it sit for about an hour at room temp before adding your toppings and baking, the dough rises perfectly and develops the nicest crisp crust while staying chewy and soft inside.  This recipe is THE BEST!

text:
I make this at least once a month. My husband's friends are so envious that they don't get "home made" pizza like he does. I don't agree with those who say it's "bland". In my opinion pizza crust is supposed to taste like bread (which this does!)not all kinds of seasonings, that's what your topping is for! I usually let my batch rise twice for a more developed flavor to the dough. Just punch it down after the first rising and put it back in the oiled bowl, cover and let rise until double again. I have found that baking for 15 minutes at 500°F makes a perfectly baked crust on my perforated aluminum pizza pan.

We eat a lot of pizza and I wanted to try another recipe and this was a winner with everyone at my house.  I did add 1 tsp. italian seasoning, 1/2 tsp. each of onion salt and garlic pwdr., and 3 Tbsp. parmesean cheese to dry ingredients before mixing. I took others advice and divided this into 2 balls of dough after it rose and they filled 2 14" air bake pizza pans. The crusts rose 15 min. after I brushed a garlic/butter mixture over it. Then I added toppings and everything turned out great.  It was easy, taste and texture were great-there were no leftovers.

text:
I love this recipe.  My first batch was a little sticky but tasted fine.  I add 1/2 tsp more brown sugar, dust my stone with a little corn meal, and mix about 3 Cups of the flour in before kneading in the rest. I bake the crust 5 minutes or so before adding sauce and toppings so I don't get a soggy crust. I also made it into breadsticks and brushed garlic,parmesan butter over the top! Excellent!

Display Name:
ABROSEN

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just as the other reviewers noted, this recipe yields 2 medium-sized pizzas.  I served both pies tonight to 4 people and no one left hungry.  This crust got rave reviews and was very easy to make (1st time dough-maker here!).  It cooked up in 15 minutes on a 14" stone that was preheated at 425 deg C for 1 hr.  Like many have noted, I also used close to 4 c of flour.  Being a novice at this, after I cut the dough into two portions, I wrapped them each in wax paper and stored in the fridge.  BIG MISTAKE-- the dough stuck like glue to the paper and was nearly impossible to remove (I lost a lot of dough in the process).  Just passing on this info to possibly help other cooks out there avoid this painful experience.  Also, don't be stingy with the corn meal (on the stone and peel or any surface where you prepare the topped pie)...it makes a big difference.  Thanks Jason!

country:
None
text:
As a Chicago pizza snob, I never buy frozen pizzas and rarely eat at any national pizza chains so my homemade pizza has some big shoes to fill.  This crust, while better than others, doesn't stop my search for a go-to pizza crust recipe.  It just doesn't have the chewiness that it promised and is a bit bland.  After making it a few times, I prefer it with added spice per other reviewers' suggestions (I add 1t Italian seasoning, 1/4t garlic powder, and increase sugar to 1T).  Maybe it depends on pan size/thickness, but it doesn't need pre-baking to cook through (and my try at pre-baking just made it drier) as been suggested.  I have a feeling the crust I crave needs a lot more oil (which negates the healthier homemade version I'm going for so haven't experimented with that yet), bread flour instead of all-purpose, and a pizza stone.  Overall, this is a good crust that I'll make occasionally until I find my perfect recipe.

text:
Oh My Goodness! This was soooo good. I didn't change not one ingredient. I used my bread machine to do all the kneading and rising. I then did the final punch, turned it out gave it a little dusting with flour kneaded it twice and shaped it to fit my pizza stone that i pre-heated. I let it sit on the hot stone a few minutes to let the heat penetrate through the dough a little. I spread some pizza sauce on it then topped it with bacon, grilled chicken, salami, roasted red onion, red, green and yellow bell peppers and a lot of cheese. It was done in 20 minutes. Thanks Jason for a truly top notch recipe!

country:
None
text:
This dough was pretty quick to make and easy to work with.  I replaced one cup of flour with whole wheat flour.  I rolled the dough as thin as I could into a rectangle, topped with veggies (sauteed briefly to remove excess water) then rolled the long edge jelly-roll style and sealed the edges.  I placed on a baking sheet sprinkled with cornmeal and brushed the top with a wash of egg yolk and water for a shiny surface.  I baked at 350 F for 20 minutes, brushed with more egg wash then baked for another 15 minutes.  My family enjoyed it although we all agreed the dough could probably use a little more salt.  The amount of dough made a very large pizza roll, so I will probably divide into two next time.

text:
This easily makes 2 medium pizzas, I halved it and made a generously sized single medium pizza.  It has a chewy texture, and slightly crispy.  It tastes like a pan tossed crust, which i really like.  I cooked my crust for 10 minutes (would add another 5 min), after it rose for 20 min, on the 2nd to lowest rack; i am glad i did, because otherwise it would have been doughy in the middle after the normal baking time.  Next time I am going to lower the oven temp a little bit, as the cheese got a lil too brown around the edges.  I brushed the crust with a garlic butter to give it a little flavor.  Will make again and again for my pizza loving hubby!

Delicious!!  I couldn't have made a better pizza!  I didn't use very fancy ingredients, simply shredded cheese, tomato sauce, mushrooms, and chopped sausages. userID:
3494413
Display Name:
OhioKEE
isPro:

67

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/377839.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Look no further.... this is the BEST pizza crust you can make.  I followed the recipe exactly and included a reviewer tip of pre-warming my mixing bowl.  I put my large bowl in a pan of warm water (110 degrees) to equilibrate.  Then I put the brown sugar and yeast inside the bowl and added the 1 and 1/2 cups warm water (110 degrees) by slowly pouring it down the side of the bowl.  The yeast dissolved very quickly but I did let it rest for 10 minutes before adding the salt and oil.  I added the flour slowly.   Keep in mind that the amount of flour it takes varies with the temperature and humidity but mine was close to that in the recipe.  I hand kneeded it until it was no longer sticky.  It took mine about 2 hours to double (that can vary due to the age of the yeast).  When it was ready, it was sooo easy to roll out and stretch.  I got two 14 inch pizzas.  I made Easy Pizza Sauce I and added cheese, pepperoni, and family favorite toppings.  Tasted fantastic.  Thanks, Jay!!

userID:
2305813
Display Name:
Pete Ormsbee

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been playing around with different crusts for quite a while and have never found one that I've been thrilled with...until now.

I don't use a pizza stone but instead use a 16" perforated pizza pan (I found mine at Kohl's) that works great as it allows hot air to circulate through the bottom.  If you weren't using one of these or a stone, you'll probably need to precook the crust for about 10 minutes before adding toppings or it will most likely be doughy in the middle.  If you have a stone or a perforated pan then no worries...add toppings to uncooked dough.  If you're using a smaller pan, this is enough for two pizzas, if using a large pan, this is the perfect amount for a 16" pan-style pizza.

The only change I made to this recipe was substituting the all-purpose flour with the same amount of bread flour (high gluten).  I haven't made it with all-purpose flour but with bread flour, it's definitely soft and chewy with a crispy crust. Be sure to have some honey on hand to eat with the outer crust; if you live in Colorado and have ever been to Beau Jo's, you know what I'm talking about and this crust is extremely close to what they make.

My wife and I had fun making a pizza today and definitely enjoyed the fruits of our labors with a great spicy Italian sausage and onion pizza.  Enjoy!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe but even better with a few changes.  I used my mixer with the hook attachment and it was so easy.  I did double the surgar and subed 1 cup of whole wheat flour.  Sugar for taste and wheat flour for texture.  After kneeding I oiled the same mixing bowl and let it rise twice for an hour each and pounded back down.  Preheat to 425 with pizza stone in oven, this is a must!!  Roll out with corn meal on a pizza peel so dough will slide easily.  Top how you like and slide in oven on stone for about 15 min.  With 5 min left I brushed some melted butter around outside edge.  Turned out awesome and this is the only recipe I use now.

text:
I have tried quite a few recipes for pizza crust in my bread machine....always dissapointed I gave up... When I took this one out of the machine and started working with it, I knew it was "different". It glided through my hands like silk. I used half a recipe and got a medium-thin crust 12 inch pizza. Great texture and taste!  I like to prebake the crust for 3 minutes, then add the sauce and cheese and bake it for about 10 more minutes at 500 degrees.  I've played with tempertures from 425-450-475.  500 gets the pizza more evenly cooked and keeps it from getting soggy.

text:
Well, this wasn't good. I tried this recipe three times and none of the times did this recipe turn out good. 425 is a mistake. I've never heard of a pizza recipe baked at such low temps before. It's always baked at 500 degrees. According to a friend of mine who is a chef and a baker, the 500 degree temp gives pizza that perfect crust. He outta know, he makes the best pizza in town. Even after 20 minutes the crust on this recipe never got golden brown. Not to mention, the pizza had no flavor either. It was pretty bland. My husband liked everything about the pizza except for the crust. He only took one bite and didn't want anymore. I can't blame him it was like white bread with sauce and cheese on top. I hate to say it, but I would've been better off buying a store-bought pizza than wasting all my money on this... even Totino's would've been better than this. I should've stuck with Ricardo's version. I just thought I'd try this one based on all the rave reviews. Next time I will head the bad reviews before I waste my money.

userID:
450736
Display Name:
CHAMMI
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'VE FALLEN BACK IN LOVE WITH THICK CRUST!

I just finished a VERY satisfying veggie pizza. The crust was a bit doughey and underdone in the middle, but I suspect it was my fault for layering so much sauce and fresh spinach on top. 

I'm sure it would only turn out better on a pizza stone, but it's really worth trying with whatever materials you have. I used a cheap Kroger cookie sheet and white sugar instead of brown. Despite eyeballing the smaller measurements (having misplaced my measuring spoons-0y!) and using a glass milk bottle to roll the dough, it still turned out fantastically the first time! (I'll admit, though, that I have some prior experience working with yeast, which is a key factor in making this dough).

The crust turned out nice and crispy and smooth-- like a non-greasy foccacia bread. I rolled it thick and the edges were a delight to munch on. I also ended up adding a bit more flour, but this largely depends on the absorbancy of your work surface (mine was pretty non-porous). If you have bread making experience, you'll have an easier time knowing when the dough is the right consistency. Another note is that it took me about 2.5 - 3 hours to finish this recipe--though I'm a slow cook and I wasn't able to take any shortcuts, like baking it immediately after rolling on a pizza stone.

Once again, thanks to the author! For the rest of you, this is a good "first" pizza dough recipe.

39
favoritesCount:
31
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a delicious recipe.  I've been making my own pizza for years, but was never super-happy with the recipes that made it easy to get a yeasty taste.  This dough is chewy inside, crusty outside.  The two changes I made were using white sugar instead of brown, using a little more flour and plenty of olive oil for the rising bowl so it wasn't too sticky after it was finished rising.  I also do not punch it down after it rises...I get it right from the bowl and spread it into a pizza pan, and let it sit (covered with a dampened paper towel) and rise for another 20 minutes, then put my sauce and mozzerella on.  I bake it in a pre-heated 450 oven, bottom rack, for about 15 minutes.  I've made this at least 20 times, and it only gets better each time.  I've had many friends and family call it "heavenly" and "better than a pizza place". Thank you Jay!

Very dependable recipe and yeilds a soft, workable dough. I have even substituted whole wheat (1:1 ratio) and still tastes great.  Also, I double the recipe sometimes to make about 16-18 mini pizzas, which are great to put in the freezer for easy lunches or late dinners.  I place them individually in ziplocks and label.

text:
I make this whenever I make pizza and it is my family's favorite pizza crust recipe. I do a few things differently though which makes it a lot better. 

1. I brush olive oil on the crust which makes it crispier and a lot better

2. I add about 1 cup of extra flour when making otherwise it is way too sticky to the point I can't use it. 

Other then that I follow this recipe exactly and it is great. I just wish it was crispier and had more taste. I will take other reviewer's advice and prebake the dough before adding topping for 10 minutes and then put the toppings on and bake it some more the next time I make this.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2426420.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow - loved it!  Why did I wait so long to try this recipe?  I know, it uses yeast and I have a fear of it.  I put all the ingredients in the bread machine and let it do the work for me.  When it was time to remove the bread, I put it in a Pam™ sprayed self-sealing gallon bag and put it in the refrigerator to use later.  When I got home, 8 hours later, the bag was about ready to explode!  I spread the dough onto a well greased pizza pan, let it rise for 20 minutes, pre-baked for 5 minutes, and then added the toppings.  I used:  sausage, pepperoni, onion, green pepper, mozzarella cheese, cottage cheese and fresh diced tomatoes.  For the sauce I made 'Exquisite Pizza Sauce' from AR.  The results were the BEST homemade pizza I've ever had. I like that I can make this again and freeze for another time.  This makes enough dough that you could halve the dough and make smaller pizzas. Thanks Jason Sharp for sharing your recipe.

This is the first successful pizza crust I have made.  All the others (some from this site) have been too bland, dense or chewy.  The only problem we had was there the extreme crust to topping ratio - a 14 inch cast iron pan was too small. 
Next time, I plan to sub half the flour with whole wheat and also use a cookie sheet pan.
Also, added tip - spray the crust with oil (Pam works fine) and sprinkle with garlic salt before baking.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I prefer to use whole grains whenever possible, so I used only one cup of all-purpose flour and the rest white whole wheat flour. Added 1 tsp Italian seasoning as other reviewers had suggested. I put all the ingredients in my bread machine on the dough cycle, and it was way too wet when it finished, so I had to knead out the dough some more with extra flour. Pre-baked the crust for 7 minutes on a well oiled baking sheet, then topped with sauce and veggies and baked for another 10 minutes. Turned out WONDERFUL. I'd been looking for a thick, chewy crust that wasn't too heavy, and this was PERFECT, even with the the whole wheat. Will DEFINITELY be making this again soon!

country:
None
text:
This is indeed a very good recipe.  I've used it to make both pizza and calzones for a superbowl party and several people asked "Who made this?  It's awesome!"  Using bread flour instead of all-purpose flour gives it an even better taste (to me, anyway.)

One note for anyone using this recipe - you will need more flour than the recipe states so don't start this if you're running low on flour.  I usually make double the recipe and need about 2-3 more cups of flour to get past the "sticky phase."  Then you'll usually need more when you roll out the dough.

This recipe was amazing for breadsticks!  I made the dough as directed and used part of it for the pizza and the other I spread in a pan for the breadsticks.  I brushed melted butter over it, added garlic salt, parmesan cheese and then a little mozzarella, baked it until lightly browned. text:
Thanks for sharing this recipe Jason!  I finally broke down and decided to make homemade pizza using my bread machine. Ingredients were added according to the manufacturer's directions, but I did find a lot more flour was needed. None the less, this dough was very easy to work with and made two 12 inch pizzas.  Also I did not let the dough rise for the 15 or 20 minutes before adding the toppings. Second time around I replaced 1 1/3 cups of the flour with whole wheat.  Delicious and yes it is soft and doughy on the inside and slightly crusty on the outside.  Just be sure not to over cook.

userID:
3383741
Display Name:
TruthKid
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've never made pizza from scratch before, but this crust made me pretty proud of a noble first attempt. I had the pizza stone in the oven on the highest temp for a good hour and a half. I added some onion powder, garlic powder, marjoram, oregano, basil, and parmigiano. I split the dough in half, and on a corn meal covered cookie sheet I stretched out the dough. When I had the proper size, I took the stone out, slid the pizza on and got it back in the oven. After 5 minutes of pre-baking, I took the stone out, went to town on some homemade sauce, added some fresh mozzarella (be sure to cut into 1/8 - 1/4 slices and put on a paper towel plate, place paper towel on top, followed by another plate, and something that weighs 5 pounds or so and let it drain the moisture for a good 30 minutes or so), prosciutto, and fire roasted peppers/tomatoes. I cooked it for 12 more minutes, and it gave a very crispy crust, which wasn't bad, but I think I'm gonna scale back and go with maybe 7 minutes of cook time next.

This is my favorite pizza crust recipe! Some people like their pizza crust crispy, this is by no means crispy! It is fluffy and soft and to me incredibly delicious! It is really easy and makes two medium sized pizzas. I crank the oven to 425 then after I put the pizzas in I turn it down to 400, to prevent the toppings (onion,pepperoni etc.) from burning.

text:
I've been looking for a good pizza crust recipe, and this is definitely not it. I followed this recipe to the letter and the crust was awful. I bake all my pizzas on a stone, and it was still really raw and doughy. The recipe said to place the toppings on the dough and bake immediately. If I would've baked it longer the cheese would've been burnt. Maybe if the crust was par baked it would've been better. We threw the whole pizza out it was so bad. I will keep looking for a good recipe for pizza dough.

text:
I used all-purpose, bread, and whole-wheat flour.  I made this in my bread machine.  The dough was very easy to work with.  I took the advice of others and baked it for a few minutes before topping it.  Toppings:  I sauteed kale in butter, lemon, and pepper.  I added a little bit of whipping cream and cayenne pepper to a jar of mushroom alfredo sauce.  I also had stuffed chicken sausage on hand.  I layered the pizza with sauce, kale, sausage, and cheese.

text:
Excellent crust that is soft inside and chewy-crisp on the outside!  This will be my new pizza crust recipe, but next time I will add some herbs and garlic powder as I did with my old recipe.  I made this in my bread maker on the dough setting which simplified the preparation.  I was able to make two 14" x 15" pizzas.  The only change I made was to bake at 350 degrees for about 19-20 minutes on air cushion cookie sheets since I don't have a pizza stone.  This is a really great recipe.

None
text:
I've tried a couple of other pizza crust recipes, but I think this will be my go to recipe for now on. Today was my 3rd time making this crust, and every time I make it, I need to add a lot more flour than what's called for. At least 1/2 cup more. I don't know why, but that's how much is needed until the dough is no longer sticky and becomes smooth and elastic. I do add 2 tsp. of brown sugar into the salt and oil mixture for a little extra flavor. I also sprinkle in onion powder and garlic powder (maybe 1/4-1/2 tsp. of each). Also, for the oil I do half olive oil and half vegetable oil.

text:
I've tried several variations of this recipe by adding garlic and herbs or sometimes an extra pinch of sugar and it always turns out wonderful! I put all the ingredients in my bread machine, separate it out into three dough balls ( we like ours thin) pre bake until slightly golden and then top and finish. I highly recommend this crust as a great base to whatever kind of pizza you can cook up.

text:
I've never made pizza dough (or any kind of bread before) and this still came out fantastic.  A couple of lessons learned by a first timer:  1) Roll it thinner than you think you might need to, unless you like REALLY thick crusts.  2) Spaghetti sauce does not a pizza sauce make.  It's too thin.   3) This will also make EXCELLENT bread-sticks. :-)  Some reviewers said don't over sauce your pizza for fear it would turn out soggy. I personally did not have this problem.

country:
None
text:
I have seen this numerous times on the recipe buzz. And, after making it, I don't know what all of the excitement was about. I had thought it was maybe going to be more of a pan type of pizza crust, for some reason. But, it is like regular pizza crust, just much softer and thicker. The dough is equally soft and tears easily when working with. The flavor is actually pretty good, for just a plain pizza crust, but it is a lot of dough for one slice. Although, the crust was very easy to make, as I mixed and kneaded it all in one bowl. But, If you are looking to make an authentic pizza or impress guests visually this is not the crust. Though, it you looking to satisfy a big hungry family this will work great!

text:
Wow! This is wonderful!!  I made this in my Kitchen Aid mixer and let it do the kneeding...not adding too much flour.  I made the mistake of doubling the batch.  We always like to eat left over pizza for a few days, so I wanted to make sure we had enough.  I only made 2 pizzas, and did not divide it in half equally, so one pizza had a VERY thick crust.  But it was still so yummy!!  Nice crispy bottom with tender center!  I've never had a homemade crust that tasted like a restaurant pizza!  I substituted 1 cup of whole wheat flour, and will experiment with more whole wheat.  This would be great to impress guests with!  Thanks so much for sharing!

text:
I have never successfully made pizza dough before this recipe. Lord knows I have tried. I always end up with too doughy a crust and burnt toppings. Even refrigerator dough in the tube that goes *thwuck* has that result for me.  I followed the recipe exactly, except I let my KitchenAid mixer handle the kneading. The result was a thick, chewy, delicious crust that got thumbs up from both the roommate and the boyfriend. I highly recommend this recipe.

text:
This is an excellent crust recipe as is!  It comes out chewy with a fairly crisp crust, but I always pre-bake the crust before topping it (otherwise it may turn out soggy). That said, I am constantly changing it up to make things new. My favorite combination is using 1/2 wheat flour and 1 Tbsp fresh ground black pepper. I also cook it on the grill during the summer, and it works there too!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a good recipe to work with, but I think I can make improvements. I used approx. 4 cups of flour. Half of the flour was whole wheat. The dough was incredibly sticky and soft, so much so that I had to use a spatula to smear it on the pizza pan. It also did not form a tight ball. Next time I will add at least 5 cups of flour. Because it was so difficult to work with, I made 1 crust. It rose up well. The baked crust came out very soft, more like a roll or fococcia than pizza crust. I prefer a crust that is soft but has some chew.   I'll use this recipe again for its straightforwardness, but I will change a few things:  Use at least 5 c flour  Knead it longer  Make 2 crusts   I baked it for 9 minutes before adding toppings and then 12-15 minutes once I put the toppings on. It came out nicely done.   I'd say this is better than my other crust recipe but  it needs tweaking. Enjoy!

text:
5 star recipe.  I even made significant changes to it and it turned out awesome!  I used 1/2 whole wheat flour and added onion powder, garlic powder, and Italian seasoning to the salt/oil mixture.  I didn't use even close to 3+ cups of flour.  I started with the 2.5 cups and then only added a little afterward so that it wasn't sticky anymore.  I also put the crust in the over @425 for 7 minutes before adding the topping.  Delicious and I'll definitely make it again!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4640322.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my standard crust recipe!  I have made this at least a dozen times now.  I always use my bread machine and it makes the process a breeze.  I start by putting the water and oil in first, followed by the sugar and salt.  Then I add the flour and the yeast last.  I replace 1 cup of the regular flour with whole wheat and I also add a teaspoon or more of an Italian garlic herb mix I have.  Takes about 1 hour & 20 minutes in my machine.  This makes enough dough for me to cover 2 large cookie sheets.  If I only need one I wrap the leftover dough in plastic wrap, place in a freezer bag and put it in the freezer for later use.  Pull it out the morning you need it, place in the fridge and it'll be ready to go in the evening.   Thanks for a great, easy recipe!

text:
Fantastic crust!  I can see why some of the reviews compared it to Pizza Hut's pan pizza.  While the flavor isn't the same, the texture is very similar to the pan pizza - very crispy on the outside and fluffy and chewy on the inside.  There weren't many reviews of making this crust in the bread machine, but I decided to try it anyway.  I was impressed with the results and can't wait to try it by hand to see if it turns out even better!  I used the dough cycle on my machine.  The dough came out very wet, and I think that's what lends it's texture.  I let it rise in a greased 16" pizza pan for 15 minutes, then pre-baked it for 5 minutes before putting on the toppings.  We topped ours with Contadina pizza sauce, 1 lb. shredded mozzarella, mushrooms and pepperoni.  Delicious!

country:

text:
I’ve made this recipe before, each time taking reviewers’ advice and baking the crust for 10 minutes prior to adding toppings.  This last time I made it though, I did not pre-bake.  I will never pre-bake this crust again!  Pre-baking made my crust somewhat hard, and I was confused as to why this recipe had so many rave reviews when it seemed just okay to me.  Pre-baking, although it may work for some, didn’t work for me.  My non-pre-baked crust was the perfect consistency.  I made this for my sisters and I, and we all loved it.  I added Italian seasoning, rosemary, and garlic as I was kneading (I kneaded for eight minutes).  I sprinkled the same on the pan prior to placing the pizza.  Since my homemade pizzas were always okay but not fabulous, I had almost given up on them as a dinner item—since this last pizza turned out so well though, there will now be a homemade pizza in my house every once in a while. :)

text:
This is a great crust & I did it the lazy way. I used 1 small packet of quick-rise yeast. Once the yeast & sugar mixture dissolved, I added everything to the kitchenaid with a dough hook & let it knead itself.  I accidentally let the dough rise for close to 1.5 hrs. I also precooked the crust for 7 min. It turned out thicker than I expected but got super reviews from the boyfriend that prefers a thicker crust that's crispy on the outside (aka: not floppy at all).

text:
We've finally found a great dough for our pizzas.  I followed this recipe exactly (though I prebaked the crust for 6 minutes before adding the toppings since I was using a pizza pan which I think helped a lot) and rolled it out for a thin crust and was spurprised that the crust remained chewy.  We brushed the crust with melted buter and shaker romano cheese.  A key I believe to add flavor to this is to add in Italian seasonings and some onion and garlic powder into the dough as any other reviewers did.  It gave it a little extra kick and gave the final product a very pretty look.  The crust was just gorgeous and I am going to try deep dish next time and perhaps at some point substitute some wheat flour to give even more texture to it.  I split the dough into thrids and froze 2 and baked one tonight.  The one I made fed one adult and two children, perhaps a "medium" size pizza.

text:
We were looking for an easy dough recipe and this was it!  I used the Kitchen Aid mixer to knead (felt like cheating, but saved me time!  Thanks for the suggestion- 2 min at speed 2, 8 min at speed 6) and it turned out perfect--I am sure I added more flour than the recipe called for, but I didn't measure it out.  I also added garlic powder, and next time will add some Italian seasoning, etc.  We made two flatbreads out of the recipe-One with just herbs, parm. cheese, and garlic.  The other with gorganzola, parm, mozz, prosciutto, tomatos sliced very thin, and garlic and herbs--excellent.  Baste the edges with more olive oil before baking.  We didn't parbake the crust first, but just topped and baked...with more and thicker toppings, I can see why you may need to though.  We have been buying refrigerated dough from Trader Joes in the past, but this far exceeds that, and sometime I am going to try to hold the dough in the fridge for a couple days and then bake it (like I read in other reviews).  I am making two batches tonight for real pizza!!

This didn't turn out for me, though I really believe it was due to operator error and not the recipe.  I added some Italian spices and extra garlic, made in the bread machine on dough cycle, then let it rise for an hour. Put in the fridge over night and used the next day. I used the entire amount of dough on a pizza stone and it was way too thick and got tough after first precooking it for 10 minutes then adding the goodies and putting back in the oven till the cheese was melted.  The dough behaved fairly well, I did have to add flour to it, but not a terribly huge amount. I am going to buy 2 deep dish pans and make 2 smaller pizzas instead of one huge one the next time. I think I just had too much dough for one pizza stone.

I rate this a 3 because it took many reviews to make this work.  It took at least another cup of flour, and "one giant pizza" for the size was very vague- is that a 16" or what?  I ended up using a cake pan, (forgot I loaned out my pizza stone), but others said so many different types of pans, it was confusing. I then only used 2/3 of the dough. I took the advice to cook the crust 10 min. first instead of the extra rising time - then added toppigs and cooked 20 more min. After reading the reviews - many of the 5 star reviews had numerous changes  by adding spices, flour, cheese, etc. to the crust.  That makes it a different recipe folks! We did like it quite a bit, believe it or not, but pretty sure I got lucky by taking the right advice from other reviewers. Maybe the pizza stone makes the difference -if so the recipe should say so.

country:

text:
This is by far the best pizza crust I have ever made. It worked out perfect for elasticity and was easy to work with. I did not find it hard to throw together but I am used to making bread doughs, etc. I followed the recipe to a tee and did not need to add extra flour. I worked it all in and tried to toss it, but to no avail, but will keep trying to toss. I think it takes a little practice. It rolled out very nicely. This recipe did two large pizzas. I made one thin and the other thick. Worked well both ways. I do believe adding some herbs to the crust would do very nicely, but needed to try the crust by itself first. It was great tasting! I did make one change, I baked at 450 degrees rather than 425 degrees and I used cornmeal under the crust. The crust came out chewy on the inside and crisp on the outside. This is a keeper and I will continue to use it and will not look for another pizza crust recipe at all. Thanks, Jay
Reviewed by Kathleen Folsom-Johnson

text:
I thought about giving this 3 stars, but considering how easy it is to make, I bumped it up to 4.  There are multiple drawbacks to this recipe.  Most, if not all of these are mentioned in other reviews, but since my wife found this recipe for me I never saw the reviews.

I have tried this crust 3 or 4 times and will probably use it again in the future, though slightly modified.

Yes, it is bland.  Not much flavor to it.  Adding salt, garlic powder, or your choice of seasoning should help.

Yes, it is thick.  The first time I made it I assumed it would make up one pizza.  Whoa was I wrong!  After I took it out of the oven it looked like a loaf of bread with pizza toppings.  Every time since then I have rolled it out absolutely as thin as possible, so it ends up making at least 2 large pizzas.  Sometimes I'll make several mini pizzas for my kids and a couple medium sized ones for me and my wife.  We still have leftovers.

I wish the bottom of the crust wasn't so soft.  Next time I'll put some cornmeal on the pan before laying the dough over it.  I imagine a pizza stone may help as well.

And yes, I needed to add a lot of flour to the recipe during the kneeding.  I can't imagine anyone making this recipe work with the specified amount of flour.

All in all, though, the it does work out and is quite usable.

text:
This recipe was ok.  I warmed my oven to 200 degrees then turned it off and put a damp towel over my stainless steel bowl and put it in the semi-warm oven to rise.  It rose QUICKLY and was very easy to work with and roll out and put on the pan.  I folded the edges like papa johns does so the end of the crust was thick.  I topped it and baked it.  The crust ends turned out ALOT like papa johns chewy crust, BUT, had no flavor.  It DID taste a lot like white bread and was doughy in the middle.  I give it one star for taste, and one star for ease of making. Probably won't make it again.

text:
I gave up attempting pizza crust a few years ago because I was less than successful.  After reading the reviews, I decided to give this a try.  My 4 year old son loved rolling out the dough and he topped the pizza.  He typically doesn't like pizza, but he ate 1/2 of this!  I topped the other dough with olive oil, herbs and parmesan --- I was going to serve it with steak for dinner but my husband ate it all before dinner.  He really liked it!  Thank you for sharing this recipe -  We eat pizza approx. twice a week so this will really help to cut down our money spent on pizza.   If I can do it, anyone can!  FOLLOW UP: I have made it often enough that I now "know" what I am doing - I add more brown sugar and salt and I do Not let the crust rise once it is on the pizza pan because we like a thin, crispy crust...I add 
San Marzono tomatoes ( hard to find so I buy direct from Italy  - it is required that i buy in bulk, so feel free to contact me if you are interested), "real" mozzarella and fresh basil...tastes just like the famous margherita pizza you find in the southern part of Italy!!!! CIAO/CHOW, BELLA!

country:
None
text:
Great pizza crust recipe...really easy to make, and the flavor is wonderful.  This is a great basic recipe that can be easily tweaked to individual tastes.  I sprinkled the crust with some Italian seasonings and prebaked a few minutes before putting the toppings on.  Only one caution: be careful not to prebake too long!  I did the first time I made this crust and the crust turned out VERY crunchy after the toppings finished baking.  It was still delicious (we love crunchy pizza crust in my house), but for people who prefer more of a soft, thick crust that could be a problem.  So if you prebake, keep a close eye on it!  

This made two large pizzas for me, and each had a nice crust thickness.  This recipe has become a staple in my kitchen!  My husband, who doesn't care much for pizza, loves it and asks me to make it all the time.  I highly recommend it.

text:
This was an extremely sticky dough, but it should be that way! I ended up adding an extra 2/3 c flour and let the dough rise in the mixer bowl. After it has risen it isn't as sticky, but if you need to, oil your hands when working with it. If you add too much flour you'll end up with a thick, tough, doughy crust. If you don't add the extra flour everyone else is, you'll be able to make it an extrememly thin crust. I rolled it out on a thick layer of cornmeal (on the paddle) topped it and baked on a preheated stone. AWESOME! Best pizza we've had in a LONG time! THANK YOU JASON!

text:
This made a beautiful, tasty crust with a couple of modifications. First, I did have to add almost a cup of flour to make this dough kneadable. I bake a lot of bread, and am used to working with sticky dough, but this was ridiculous! (Maybe in a mixer with a dough  hook this amount of flour would work) And it occured to me while adding all this flour that this may account for the lack of taste some reviewers mentioned, so I doubled the amount of salt, and used sea salt instead of table salt. I also baked untopped for 15 minutes, then topped the pizzas (the recipe made 2 12 pizzas) and baked for 10 minutes more. Perfect!

I was very impressed with this pizza dough.  As promised, it bakes up crisp on the outside and soft & chewy inside.  I would give it 10 stars for texture if I could. This coming from a woman who has gotten so frustrated with previous pizza dough recipes that I have actually thrown them into the garbage & ordered out.  This is truly THE Pizza Crust for Dummies!

text:
I am usually not very good with bread recipes, but I really wanted to make homemade pizza.  This is a great pizza crust recipe.  I added italian spices and actually did it the day before.  I made it as the recipe said, then just put it in the frig.  The next morning, it had rised and I just deflated it and put it back in the frig until I came home from work.  Then finished the crust as the recipe said.  And it gave me one GIANT pizza.  Much too big for my pizza stone.  Next time I will just make two pizza out of this recipe.  This recipe is a keeper.  Now I only get take out pizza when I don't have time to make this.

I also thought this recipe was 'just okay' the first time we made it.  Apparently, our yeast was not very active, and that's why it was rather thin and bland.  Tonight we made with some new yeast and it was wonderful!  Nice and chewy, and enough of it that we could make one kid friendly and one adult friendly pizza.  For those who didn't like it, make sure your yeast is active, because it really is a delicious crust.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OK..this makes a GREAT crust, but if you plan on using a bread machine you will need to make an adjustment.  I made two batches last night..I started with the 3 1/3 cups flour in my machine with the other ingredients and then added the 1 1/2 cups water.  TOO STICKY!!  I'm not sure exactly how much flour I ended up adding, but I would say it was easily more than a cup.  The second batch I made with only 1 cup of the water to start..I ended up adding maybe an additional tablespoon of water to form into a lovely smooth dough.  Be prepared to make a few minor adjustments..but be prepared to ENJOY your delicious pizza.  This makes a very tasty start to any pizza.

This is a very workable pizza dough...which for me is half the battle.  I did have to use quite a bit of flour to make the dough "not sticky", but once I got there it was a very nice texture.  My husband says it's his favorite pizza crust yet (and believe me, I've tried a lot of them).  I also liked this crust...although I'm still a little partial to my mother's recipe.  Maybe it's because she used to take the extra dough, braid it, bake it then slather it with butter.  Anyway, thumbs up to this recipe.  Thanks Jay!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe. I've been making this recipe for many years. I suggest checking the temp of your water before adding yeast. Too cold or hot can affect your results. I like 105-115 F  Whisk the yeast, water and brown sugar (I like Dark Brown sugar but light works also) together and let sit for 10 minutes. The sugar feeds the yeast so don't omit the sugar. I use ungreased parchment paper on a pizza stone or pizza pan. Great results. OPT- Brush baked crust with melted butter, garlic butter or garlic Parmesan butter.

This has become my go-to pizza crust.  I've been making it for quite some time (we make our pizza at home, since we're on a tight budget). I've occasionally strayed and tried other pizza crust recipes, but I always come back to Jay's! Most recently, I used 1 tbsp. of brown sugar instead of the 1/2 tsp. the recipe calls for. Wow!! This made an even chewier-on-the-inside, crisp-on-the-outside crust, so I'll use this tweak from now on. :)

None
text:
makes good pizza. I recommend cooking the pizza at 550 F or hotter (as hot as your oven will go). The pizza will cook much more quickly, the crust will actually be closer to NYC quality pizza and the cheese will get all bubbly and perfect within 8 to 10 minutes. Try it and you will never settle for a cold oven again when cooking pizza.
P.S. ask at a pizza joint how hot the oven is set to...it's going to be a far sight hotter than 425 F.

text:
I made this two nights in  a row. The first night I used my kitchen aid dough kneader and it turned out "ok". The second night I followed the video and directions exactly and I loved the result! One change- I used about 1/3 c whole wheat flour. Next time I will increase the ww flour ratio. 
I also learned how to use a pizza stone - it is important to heat the stone for 10 min at a preheated temp of about 400, and also to generously flour the stone before putting the dough on. This made it exceptional!
