country:
None
text:
I have never made a pizza from scratch, but will definitely be making it this way from now on.   I made a few of the recommended changes ( 1/2 teaspoon extra brown sugar and salt) and it was fabulous, and so easy using my stand mixer.  The only issue I had was that I underestimated how much it would rise in the oven and didn't roll it out enough, and it came out a little too thick for my liking (still tasted fabulous though). Those that rated this low stating it didn't rise probably had issues with the yeast, if made correctly (with good yeast and water the correct temp) it rises just fine. Also, you will get better results if you pre bake at least five minutes before adding the toppings and bake at 450 instead of 425. I am a novice when it comes to using a pizza stone and pizza peel, next time instead of two larger pizza I may try three smaller ones with a thinner crust that will be easier to manage. Made it with the Easy pizza sauce III recipe from this site and shredded my own mozzarella cheese, topped the kid's with pepperoni and the adult's with lots of fresh veggies as well....amazing!!!!!  My nine yr. old said it was better than take out.  Try this recipe, even if you are a novice pizza maker like me, you won't regret it!

userID:
5278182
Display Name:
Yada yada yada
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
37
favoritesCount:
247
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Have tried a lot of crust recipes and this one is by far the best!  I found that there are a couple of keys to the best result. I mix the dough in a stand mixer and then transfer to an oil coated bowl, forming a ball and making sure the dough is coated with oil. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap coated with cooking spray to let rise. The olive oil coating on the dough seems to be one key. I've skipped this step before and let it rise in the mixing bowl & it wasn't as good. This recipe makes 2 approximately 12" crusts for me. I use a rolling pin and a lightly floured surface to shape the crusts, pre bake on  a pre heated pizza stone at 500 degrees for 5 minutes and use a fork to poke some holes in the crust prior to baking, it still puffs a bit. The pre baking on a pre heated stone is another key. A pizza peel generously sprinkled with cornmeal helps with getting the crust on the hot stone. Also sprinkle the stone with a little corn meal right before placing the crust. I don't always top and bake right away. Bake as long as the toppings need at 500 degrees. I sometimes turn on the convection for a minute to brown up the top. Pre baking on a stone makes the crust crispy on the bottom, but still bread like in the middle.  "Exquisite Pizza Sauce" from this site is a great sauce!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a wonderful, basic recipe for dough. I prepared it exactly as instructed and used a dough hook and mixer. After adding the first 2 1/2 cups of flour to the dough, it seemed way too wet, or not dough like. Mine didn't ball up like other breads do. But, as the instructions stated, I turned that "dough" onto a well-floured surface. I ended up adding close to one additional cup of flour when working the dough. It still seemed not dough-like enough, but I left it as is. 

After allowing the dough to rise for an hour, it turned out fabulously! It was easy to roll; not too many air pockets like other crusts have often had. 


I baked my crust on a pizza pan for about 8 minutes at 425, before adding my toppings. I then cooked it an additional 8 minutes with 2 minutes of broiling. I like doing this so the center of the pizza isn't so soggy and the toppings are really cooked. I'm glad I did because the pizza dough still wasn't cooked quite as much as I'd like. 

I will definitely use this recipe in the future.

country:
None
text:
I've been using this recipe frequently for the last few years.  It makes a great pan pizza, and a pretty good thin-crust pizza, too.  I had tried out other recipes that turned out fine when fresh but that got tough or gummy when I re-heated the leftover pizza for lunch the next morning.  This recipe makes the best leftover crust I've yet had. 

I have successfully used 1/2 whole wheat flour and 1/2 all-purpose flour for a more substantial crust, and it works very well.  

I usually let the bread machine mix up the dough for me (though I usually have to add 1/4-1/2 cup more flour) and then pat or roll it out.  I especially like baking it on a stone, but it works fine in a regular pan, too.

text:
This recipe is simple and excellent.  I scaled the serving size down to 10 and it made enough dough to completely cover a 14" round pizza pan with about 2" of dough overhanging the outside edge of the pan.  I rolled the dough inward to make a good sized crust.  I paired this with the exquisite pizza sauce and tweaked it to my liking a bit and it came out great.  Also I didn't have to precook the dough, I just cooked it at 425 and took it out when the cheese was nice and golden brown.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So simple to make when using a bread machine . I set on "Dough" cycle rather than "Piazza Dough" . When done i pressed dough down in pan with two fingers then allowed machine to knead dough 20 times. After removing dough from machine I placed on floured surface and allowed to rest for 10 minutes.
The sky's the limit with this recipe.  My first attempt was stromboli. The dough makes 4 6"x8" rectangles. I will add a bit more flour next time since the dough was just a bit too sticky for easy rolling once toppings in place.
FYI: I used white whole wheat flour to add more nutrition and the texture was quite good.

text:
This is by far one of the best pizza crust recipes I've found! I modified this recipe by making it a "stuffed crust" pizza. I cut mozzarella cheese sticks in half lengthwise. I rolled the dough out about 1 1/2 inches wider than the pie plate, placed the cheese stick halves around the plate edge, then folded the extra dough over and crimped the fold with a fork. I topped it with pizza sauce, added my ingredients, and it made a perfect stuffed crust pizza.

It took me 3 tries to get this right.  I had no idea how long to knead, so after it only rising slightly the first two times i kneaded by hand, I finally just set my kitchenaide dough hook on it for several minutes and must have added another cup of flour.  Then it almost doubled in size, and tasted MUCH better.  I also added some onion powder and garlic powder.  I baked it in a 14" cake pan for 15 minutes before adding toppings.  Good bye papa john's!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This recipe delivered. I was having friends over for dinner and realized half an hour they were supposed to arrive that neither of my pizzas had gone in the oven and no food was on the table. I could not afford for anything to go wrong as I was flying around the kitchen, defrosting pita, putting out dips, grilling veggies and assembling my two pizzas, and this pizza crust recipe did not disappoint. After prebaking for five minutes the crusts (I made two crusts from a single recipe) puffed up well and were beginning to brown lightly. The toppings went on and in about fifteen minutes (slightly less) I had two show stopping pizzas on my hands. My guests raved and kept eating the pizza despite their complaints of being so full that they would explode. The result in itself would be reason enough to make this recipe, but it is also one of the easiest crust recipes out there. Try it and you'll be glad you did. This is the only crust recipe I'm using from now on.

Thanks Jay, great recipe!  I asked a couple questions about this on The Buzz and with Buzzers advice, I was able to make 2 pizzas from this amount of dough.  Also, I put it directly on a cold pizza stone and that went in the oven pretty close to 20 minutes.  Forget about rolling out the dough.  It was WAY too sticky. text:
This is a great recipe, but it makes twice as many pizzas as the recipe says. I usually make the full recipes and freeze the other half for another day. It freezes really well. If you want an amazing recipe, add 2 tablespoons of honey after the yeast activates. You'll need a little more flour to make up for the extra moisture, but the honey gives the dough a slightly sweet flavor that is to die for. I've also added garlic and/or italian seasoning with the flour and it turns out great as well!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I haven't tried - too many negative reviews when you sort by rating but I have a very good pizza dough recipe from American Test Kitchen that is so similar that maybe with the few changes those that got poor results will find improvement.    ATK's recipe calls for 1 3/4 cups water to 4 cups BREAD flour.  They recommend that you use a food processor to mix dough if you have a 11 cup capacity or larger food processor.  It works great. Also for more flavor they recommend sauteing garlic with your favorite pizza herb(s) in the oil and letting it cool before adding to the recipe. ATK also feels a pizza stone or tiles are a must and that the oven should be preheated to and the pizza cooked at 500 degrees.  (The surface temperature of the stone or tiles should be 500 degrees before placing the pizza on it.  This requires at least 30 minutes of preheating your oven.) They use 6" square, 1/2 " thick unglazed terra cotta quary tiles which are cheaper to purchase and easier to store than a good pizza stone.  I'm a novice at pizza baking but get excellent results with this method.  Good luck.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/658932.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This crust is absolutely delicious! Even with my pizza stone the crust was still doughy in the middle. I figure it's my oven causing the issues, so I will pre-bake the crusts from now on. This recipe yields two large pizza's. I make my own pizza sauce from scratch. It's the pizza sauce for Rachel Ray's french bread pizza. -2 pts cherry tomatoes -1 head of garlic -EVOO (extra virgin olive oil) -salt & pepper. Toss the tomatoes  w/ EVOO on a cookie sheet lined with foil. Salt & pepper to taste. Peel the skin off the head of garlic (leaving it intact) drizzle with EVOO and wrap in foil. Place it on the cookie sheet(if there's room) or directly on the oven rack. Roast the Garlic and tomatoes at 350° for about 25-30 mins. Allow tomatoes to rest a couple minutes, open garlic to allow to rest also. Remove cloves from garlic and add to a large bowl, add tomatoes and mash with potato masher, until desired consistency. Season w/ salt & Pepper if needed and then spread on pizza crust. --Yum-O!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an awesome crust, and my new "go to" pizza crust.  I didn't give it 5 stars because there's not really any need to let it rise for an hour.  I greased a large jelly roll pan, plopped my dough on there for about 10 mins and then easily worked it into place.  I naked-baked at 475º for 10 mins removed it from the oven, sauced and put it back in for 10 mins on the lowest rack at the same heat setting.  What I did next is a secret, you're not getting all my tricks ;) But needless to say the 2 baking times of 10 min each at 475º produced the perfect crispy crust that I was looking for!  Well done, friend.

The outcome of this recipe surprised me. When I read "brown sugar" my mind immediately went to "in white crust? Yuk!" It turned out quite lovely, though, and really huge. My husband, who enjoys a thicker type Sicilian crust, was truly wild about it. It's too thick for me as one crust, so I'll either have to use a larger pan, or make two pizzas in the future. The texture is exactly what we always hope for, tender inside and slightly crunchy on the exterior. Thank you very much, Jason. This will definitely be in my best recipes folder.

text:
The dishes aren't even washed yet and I had to post my rave review. This was the best homemade crust I've ever made/had! I followed the recipe and some of the reviewers who recommended pre-baking the crust before topping the pizza. After the initial rising, I put it my jelly roll pan (which it fit in perfectly) and let it rise another hour. Baked it for 8 minutes at 425 and took it out, topped it and baked it another 10 minutes. Absolutely perfect! This recipe will also replace my foccacia recipe which never seems to be airy and crisp like this dough was.   Highly recommend this one!

Have made a couple different ways as written and with modifications.  With modifications made a very good crust.  Instead of water I used milk.  I used 2 cups of bread flour and 1 and 1/3 cup of semolina four.  I baked on a pizza stone for 13 minutes at 500 degrees.  I let the pizza stone bake so it was nice and hot for about 30 min before putting the pizza on.

This was my first time making  homemade pizza and it turned out great. My only real complaint is that the crust didn't brown, but the taste and texture were spot-on. I used my bread machine (only my 2nd time using it) to mix the dough and let it rise for an hour. I used the dough to make one 13" hand tossed style cheese pizza. Baked @ 500 degrees on my pizza stone for about 12 minutes. This was so easy and tasted so good that I will definitely be making it again and again! No more take-out pizza for us :)

text:
Great recipe, and you can definitely tweak it by throwing some spices or parmesean cheese in with the flour!  I've made this twice, and both times substituted increasing amounts of the all-purpose flour for whole wheat flour and it came out great (started with 1 1/2 cups and then 2 cups)!  The first time I made one pizza with this recipe and it was a very thick crust.  Second time, I split the dough in half, froze part and made a thinner crusted pizza with the other.  It was still thick enough for our tastes!

text:
Best pizza crust ever!!! Made this tonight and it was crispy on the outside! I cooked mine a little too long so the inner dough was a little dry but that was my fault. I learned that if you wait until its light brown and then remove from the pan and put directly onto the oven rack you can get the bottom crispy as well. Will be putting this in my recipe box, its my new go to pizza crust recipe!

My first review...I followed recipe as close as I could. I did take the advice of baking it for 10 mins before adding toppings because I was using a large pizza pan...let me tell you this crust is AWESOME!!!! Kids gobbled it up and I had to threaten my brother when he came by just so I can have a couple slices for tomorrow. He was totally amazed at how good it was. I used a pizza sauce recipe from this site and that was amazing as well. I've committed to mainly using recipes from this site for the remainder of the year as a fun project for myself and this is one I can see using over and over and over again. We're going to save a lot of money on take out pizzas from now on!!! Thanks Jay!!! ***I brushed crust with garlic infused olive oil prior to baking with toppings...**totally awesome. Next time I'm going to try a cheese stuffed crust...this recipe makes a LOT of crust...which is great!

text:
Easy I used this dough make Hot pockets after trying several other types of dough.  This is my fav by far.  JUst simply roll to desire size stuff with what ever you want (I use everything from pep and moz cheese to ham and cheddar cheese.  Left overs work well too such as chicken or roast just add some veggies and brush dough with left over gravy or jar gravy) Bake on a greased cookie sheet dusted with corn meal @ 350 for 25 minutes.  You can also freeze them to reheat at a later date.

text:
Fantastic! I hadn't made any dough from scratch for a couple years and was suddenly taken by the urge to. I'm so glad I chose this recipe & will definitely make it again! The dough was easy to make and super elastic to stretch out.  I found that I ended up only including 3 cups of flour before it rose, and when preparing to bake (kneading and rolling stage) I added the other 1/2 cup at that point as it had become sticky while rising. I used the tips others left and threw it in the oven for a couple minutes before adding the toppings, and it cooked all the way through.  Fabulous!

This is a great recipe. I swapped out the white flour for whole wheat (King Arthur) and subbed honey for the brown sugar. It was a great pizza dough. We added fresh mozzarella with a simple tomato sauce. Next time, I will up the honey a bit because the whole wheat flour can handle some additional sweetness. I also used my kitchen aid mixer and beat it in the bowl with the dough hook for about 6-7 minutes. YUMMY!

0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easier way: There is no reason to proof the yeast.  I refrigerate my yeast and it's still fine after 8 months. Put all ingredients EXCEPT the warm water into a food processor fitted with steel blade and pulse a few times. Turn on the processor and pour the warm water slowly into the feed tube. Process until the dough forms a ball. Let rise, punch down, place dough in oiled bowl, cover tightly with plastic wrap and then refrigerate overnight. Use about 9 oz. for an 8 to 9 inch pie. For a tasty margarita pizza, sprinkle unbaked crust with a generous coating of shredded mozzarella, add about 8 cherry tomatoes cut in half with cut side up, sprinkle with salt, pepper, dry basil, garlic powder, and then drizzle on some extra-virgin olive oil. Bake about 15 minutes on a pre-heated stone at 425ºF. Check during baking to make sure pizza is not burning.

city:

country:
None
text:
This makes a wonderfully crispy and tasty pizza crust! It is worth the extra time it takes before it is oven ready.  Dough can be prepared ahead of time and then refrigerated for up to 2 or 3 days until ready to use.  I  prefer making personal size pizzas that can be baked more evenly and quicker. Stretch dough to desired size onto oiled cookie sheets or pizza pans.  Add desired toppings. Bake on lower rack at 425 degrees. Transfer pizza from pan to oven rack the last 3-5 minutes of baking time for a crispier crust. Total baking time is about 10 minutes for the personal size pizza.

i used my bread machine to make the dough for this, and the only change i made to the recipe was i used a full tsp of brown sugar rather than half. next time i'll use more (maybe a tablespoon or two) as i like my crust to be a little bit sweet. it did come out of the machine pretty sticky but it wasnt anything a floured cutting board couldnt fix :) i liked how i could shape it and make it as thick or thin as i wanted it and it held the shape (this would work well for thin crust pizza as well!) and i liked how it was actually chewy inside and crispy on the outside! thanks for the recipe, i think this will be my go to pizza dough recipe from now on.

text:
We thought this was pretty darn amazing.  I took a tip from another review and baked it on a pizza stone in my gas grill.  I set the grill to high and left it there where it hovered around 450 to 500 degrees- it tasted just like something from a gourmet pizzeria. Browned and crispy on the outside, chewy, soft and moist on the inside.  Word of advice: only double this recipe if you want pizza dough coming out of your ears.  I didn't think it would be enough for a family of four as is, but doubling it I ended up with enough dough for 6 nice size pizzas- I ran out of cheese and made a garlic, olive oil and parmesan bread with one hunk of it. I ended up eating mine standing up because I was so busy cranking out the pies! Bonus: cool kitchen on a hot day.

text:
I'm notorious for making super tough/hard pizza crust...crust that could crack teeth. But, this is a no brainer. I've made it a handful of times already, and each time it has baked perfectly. The 15 serving size is too big for my pizza stone, so I just divide the crust in 2, make a couple of balls and freeze one ball for later. I love to add Mrs. Dash seasoning to the dough, a little mozzarella cheese, garlic, etc. Also, I don't have one of those nifty wooden pizza spatulas to put the pizza on the stone, so I usually prepare the pizza on parchment paper and place it on top of the stone - voila! no sticky mess.

text:
I tried this recipe on my family two weeks ago and they LOVED it! They loved that it was soft & chewy but could also be a little more crispy on a thin sheet. I made 4 pizzas for my sons birthday party this past weekend and they were all gone within two hours! I would say this is very close to Pizza Hut dough/crust in that you can make it a thick deep dish, or spread it out thin and it will taste just as good. So far I've printed out 4 copies to give to friends. This is a keeper! BTW-the original recipe says to roll out your dough but doesn't mention that you can actually get two crusts out of this recipe.

text:
I love this recipe and my husband does too. I make the dough in my food processor. Proof the yeast as directed, meanwhile mix 3 cups flour, the oil and salt together in food processor just to blend. When the yeast mixture is ready, add slowly while processor is on. Once the yeast mixture is absorbed, check the texture of the dough. I then add the extra 1/3 cup flour. Pulse until the dough is thoroughly kneaded and stretchy on outside. Continue rest of recipe as written.

text:
I was very hopeful because of the great reviews this recipe had. I wanted to make homeade dough for calzones and thought I'd give this recipe a shot. I used my breadmachine and didn't change a thing about the recipe. I kept checking on it and it looked fine, but very "poufy." Then, when the timer went off, I went to get it out and it was awful. It was runny...more like batter than dough. I tried incorporating more flour but it couldn't be salvaged. I don't know if my water was too hot or the yeast wasn't good...I have no idea what went wrong.  I'm definitely going to try this again when I have time and inclination to make it by hand, and not in the breadmachine.

text:
Great recipe! You have to be generous with the flour so as to get the dough right but this is an excellent recipe for a good pizza crust.

I divided mine in half (I like a thinner crust and this was too much, so I made 2 pies).  I also added some red crushed pepper.  Used San Marzano crushed tomato sauce, sliced mozzarella and fresh basil for an out-of-this-world home-made pizza Napolitana. Everyone loved it!

Suggestions: Bake the crust for 5-7 minutes before adding toppings; then brush crust with olive oil, add toppings and bake!

Fantastic says it all! I rarely hand-make pizza, so I was a little nervous, but both pies came out perfect! 

I made Chicken Alfredo Pizza (minus the dough) from All-Recipes (recipe by lighthousekeeper)and worked in 1/2 cup of Parmesan cheese, 1/2 tablespoon rosemary, 1/2 tablespoon Italian seasoning, and a 1/2 tablespoon garlic powder into the dough.

I don't have a pizza stone, so I pre-cooked the dough for about 6-7 minutes before topping it. 
Yummy! Can't wait to make more!

text:
This is a decent pizza crust recipe but nothing particularly special.  I had to use a lot more flour than it called for, probably a whole extra cup.  The crust was very chewy, and I'd suggest adding a few seasonings to the dough if you like it flavorful.  Also, if you don't like your dough extremely thick (like, focaccia bread-style thick), make sure to roll out the dough very thin before topping it.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3055.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My first successful pizza crust! Prebaking is crucial, (the first time I made this I didn't prebake and the cheese burned while the crust was still floury) but stick to prebaking it about 6 or so min, no more, or the crust will get a little too crispy. My family has made pizza crusts before but we always made it the wrong way, letting it rise too much, and using too much flour. I wanted a slightly thinner crust so I reduced the water to 1 and 1/4th cups and the flour to 3 cups(I didn't have to add any more flour while kneading either) and it was great. Not too thick. My family of four ate the whole pizza! It produced about 10 good size slices. Because of the prebaking, after adding the toppings, the pizza is done in about 5 min. Also make sure to let it rise a second time after stretching it out onto the pan( before the prebaking) a good 20-30 min.

text:
I love this recipe.  I've made it quite a few times now.  I like to make half of it pizza crust and half breadsticks.  For the breadsticks I roll it out into a rectangle, lay a split in half mozzarella stick on the edge, roll the dough over to cover it, slice it off with a pizza roller, and roll it between my fingers so the cheese doesn't melt out.  Just keep doing that till there's no more dough.  Then I brush them with butter, sprinkle them with parmesan and bake till golden.  Holy moly.  Tonight we're just doing breadsticks and salad. YUM!  You for sure have to add seasonings to the recipe though.  I add italian seasonings, garlic powder and a little onion powder.

Delicious. I split the dough in two before I roll it out and make two medium-sized crusts. I think using all of it for one crust would make a pizza that was way too doughy. The second time I made this I made the mistake of rolling the crusts too thin. userID:
713444
Display Name:
Ginny Judd
isPro:

followersCount:
13

276
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2833540.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make pizza often but usually buy prepared crusts. Decided to give this a try and it was worth the effort. However 3 1/2 cups of flour wasn't enough. I added the whole 3 1/2 cups before kneading and it was still very sticky. I think I ended up using more like 4 to 4.5 cups. This makes enough dough for 2 large pizzas, unless you like your crust really, really thick. The dough rose very nicely but I don't think I let it relax long enough before attempting to spread it in the pan. I split the dough in half and struggled with the first piece. Had to wet it, add a tad more flour, and re-knead it a bit. It lost some elasticity so I just shaped it into a round crust and used a pizza stone. By the time I got to the second piece of dough about 10 minutes later it was very easy to spread into a rectangular crust. I let both crusts rise about 15 minutes, brushed them with a little olive oil and sprinkled with italian seasoning, then baked at 425 for about 8 minutes before adding the toppings. Once I added the toppings the pizzas took about 20 minutes more to bake. The crusts came out nice and light and slightly crunchy. Just the way I like them. Other reviewers mentioned using the same recipe for bread, calzones, breadsticks, etc. I think this recipe would be perfect for any of those. Can't wait to try them. Thanks so much for sharing this great recipe!

text:
The crust puffed up a bit on its first shot through the oven.  It made a nice crunchy pizza though, and I will not complain!  My personal modification is to brush pesto on the edge of the pizza, then when the dough is rolled up to make the crust, brush more pesto on the edges.  It's a scrumptious crust, far tastier than the stuffed or garlic varieties.

text:
Best pizza crust ever and easy to make too. I make this about every other week and it turns out perfect everytime. The last time I made it I let the dough rise to double, punched it down and then put it in an oiled bowl covered with Saran wrap in the fridge until I needed to use it. It will last a couple of days that way. It will rise again though so punch it down again and let it come to room temperature before rolling it out.

text:
My family loves this recipe, I make it many times each month. I use this recipe just the way it is, though I do sprinkle corn meal on the bottom of the pan. 
I noticed many reviewers add extra flour to make it non-sticky. I don't because I don't roll it out, I just press it into the bottom of a pan and the stickiness makes that easier actually. Faster and easier, and it comes out perfect everytime, why work hard!?
I don't use a pizza stone, and I don't prebake the crust, I have never had issues with the crust being soggy or uncooked. I've noticed that soggy crust is often caused by putting meat or other toppings under the cheese instead of on top of it. Pizza hut can do that, but when I do it is a mess.
Overall, this is one of my favorite recipes! It makes awesome garlic bread too.

text:
I see people talking about thick pan pizzas but I like thin base pizzas.  This recipe appears to do both as I get the most brilliant thin base pizzas from this recipe.  

My biggest problem is using the oven and adding fresh (in brine) mozzarella which makes the pizza a bit soggy.

I have never had a failure with this recipe and often make multiple batches at once and divide into single pizza balls and freeze.

Defrost in the micro at a very low defrost rate, roll out, add your toppings and bake......  brilliant every time

WINGNUT68

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for my husband and me last nite and it was a hit!! I used bread flour instead of AP flour and added 1 Tbl. pizza seasoning and 1/2 tsp. garlic powder to the dough. I divided dough in half and rolled out each fairly thin (came out as thin and crispy, if you like a thicker crust, dont roll as thin) and placed on pans and pricked with for (like pie crust) before baking at 450 for 8 min. Put one crust in freezer(with no toppings) to use later. Brushed the other crust with garlic butter, put on toppings and finished baking at 425 till crust was browned and cheese was bubbly. My husband and I had to keep from eating the whole thing ;) No more bisquick crust or take out for us!! Not sure why some came out with more of a bread than crust, but I would guess that they didnt roll it out thin enough to begin with. Thanks for the great recipe!!

text:
This recipe was great!  I followed the recipe exactly.  I was worried because I used expired yeast.  Also, the dough was very sticky.  I didn't use much additional flour because I used the hook on my Kitchen Aid Mixer to form the dough.  I was glad that I did not have to handle the dough with my hands.  After the dough rose, it was still sticky and I couldn't form it into a ball.  I ended up spreading the dough on a large jelly roll pan greased with olive oil and covered with cornmeal.  I let it sit before I topped with bbq sauce, cheese, chicken, cilantro, and onions.  The bbq chicken pizza was perfect.  The dough was crispy and the crust was chewy, better than the premade dough from the supermarket.

I suppose it's not really fair to rate this since I changed it a bit...but I will anyway...I used all organic wholemeal flour for the first 2 1/2 cups, and regular flour for the kneading. I found the crust nice and soft but a bit heavy, maybe my warm water wasn't warm enough to activate the yeast enough, or maybe the wholemeal flour was the culprit.  Next time I will cook it for a bit longer than 15 minutes to try and get it crispy on the outside, but at that oven temp the cheese started to get hard and brown after 15 minutes.

text:
I made this crust for BBQ chicken pizza and it was wonderful.  For those of you who are ending up with soggy crust.. here's a tip.  Cook your pizza stone for about 40 minutes before placing the dough on stone and cook for the regular time.  (with the stone already hot you crust is cooked very evenly and it's done throughout.)  Also, I spread a mixture of oregano, basil and crushed garlic on the crust before topping, it gave it a bit more flavor.  This recipe is wonderful!  Try it with the "exquisite pizza sauce" on this site!

text:
I replaced 1 c. of the all-purpose flour with whole wheat flour, and put all the ingredients in the bread machine (I dissolved the yeast first).  The dough turned out REALLY sticky, so as I was working with it (I had to use spoons to knead b/c it just stuck to my hands!) I added probably another 1/2 to 3/4 c. of flour.  In the end it turned out yummy, and made two pizzas: one pizza-stone sized round pizza and one rectangular pizza the size of a standard cookie sheet.  I didn't have cornmeal, but it didn't stick to the stone or my silpat baking mat with flour underneath the dough.

userID:
678943
Display Name:
CMiceli
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
139
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has become *the* pizza crust recipe at our home and I am making it approximately every other week.  A couple of points for you: This crust will be a 'thick crust' style crust.  If you like a thin, crunchy style crust, you will find that this is too 'bread-y' for you.  The recipe does make either one absolutely huge pizza or two med/large ones.  I have found that I really do need to prebake in order for the crust to be fully cooked.
I make this recipe in my bread machine dumping in all the ingredients and all the flour and allowing the machine to mix, knead and allow it to rise.  I then remove it from the bread machine pan, and roll out, adding about a cup more flour in the rolling.  You will probably need more flour than called for as other rieveiwers have suggested - this is a very 'wet' dough.
One more tip, I often roll this out directly on Reynolds Release aluminum foil so that I have no problems with it sticking.
Review:

5

This is the only recipe I use now. I use it for regular pizza, mini pizza (My four kids love to make own pizzas, makes 6 individual pizza crusts) and I use the recipe for bread sticks. Today I am going to make stuffed breadsticks, wrapping the dough around a string cheese stick. I think my kids will like this surprize! I think I could even wrap some of the cheese with peperoni first. And then heat some pizza sauce to dip them in.

This crust is amazing!  I just didn't believe that it would be as good as everyone is saying, but is exactly like a pizzeria pizza!

I doubled the mixture, then made 16 individual portion pizzas I topped them with cheese, ham, pepper, pineapple, onion and a tangy base sauce of ketchup, tomato paste and spicy tomato relish.  Boy!  These were excellent, and so economical - ended up costing me about 30 cents a pizza.   I laid them on cookie sheets and froze, then place in layers in an airtight storage container.

text:
Being Italian, I have been eating Pizza my whole life. This is one of the BEST recipes for crust I have found, including my grandfathers! My picky husband raved about it also. Just tweaking for taste, I used bread flour with a little higher gluten content and added herbs/cheese to the flour mix, I am not sure if the HG flour made a difference and next time I will use AP with a small amount of whole wheat or rye flour since I like a bit chewier crust. I only needed a small amount of extra flour since I felt this dough is supposed to be on the soft side. It rolled out great and made one huge Pizza. All in all an excellent recipe. Thanks for sharing Jay!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This makes a great pizza crust! As everyone else said, though, it yields a *lot* of dough.

The first time I made it, I rolled it out into only 1 crust. To make sure it would be done in the middle before the toppings burned, I prebaked the crust for 15 mins. on 350 degrees. It worked fine that way, but the crust was WAY thick! 

On the second try, I rolled it out into 2 crusts and prebaked them for 5 minutes, then added sauce and cheese. One pizza turned out great, BUT - as a previous reviewer said - the one on the Air-Bake pan was awful. It did not get done on the bottom and turned into a soggy mess that we ended up tossing. If you make this pizza, go with a traditional pan!

text:
We have been using this crust recipe for the last few years. It is very versatile. Sometimes I add herbs or cheese and sometimes I brush the crust with olive oil. I always use 1 cup of whole wheat flour(the rest is white flour), decrease the water by 1/4 cup and let the bread machine do all of the work. We like crispy crust so I usually prebake the crust. I've also used the dough to make breadsticks with olive oil and spices. Even with all of the variations we have tried, it always turns out great.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I've made this three or four times now, and it has the best texture of any pizza crust I've made. The first time, it came out a little bland for me, so I started adding canned minced garlic, basil, and a little grated parmesan cheese when it's time to mix in the olive oil and salt.

I found what really helps the flavor, though, is letting the dough ball set in the fridge for a day or two before using it. 

Overall, this recipe is great and I will definitely continue making it in the future.

userID:
25355930
Display Name:
Aaron Staheli
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
74
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6512029.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I only had Red Star Quick Rise yeast on hand so that's what I used.  I mixed it all up and kneaded for 10 minutes.  I then proceeded to put it in a bowl, covered with an unsealed sheet of plastic wrap, and into fridge for a few hours due to a crazy schedule change.  I got back and it had risen nicely.  I preheated my oven with a pizza stone on the bottom rack at the temperature the recipe said.  I don't have a pizza peel so what I did was I took a sheet of parchment paper, rubbed some olive oil on it, and proceeded to make a pretty thin pizza on it.  I slid the pizza and parchment paper right on to the pizza stone and kept it in until crust had a nice color to it (between 10 and 15 minutes) .  The cheese didn't get burnt and it tasted fantastic.  One of the best pizza crust recipes I've tried from this website.

This is our go to pizza dough recipe.  I add a tsp of Italian seasoning to the yeast mixture before adding the flour and it gives a great flavor.  We use a 14" pizza stone.  The dough is thick and soft and my 3 kids love it!  I have divided the dough into parts and made individual pizzas for the kids.  It also freezes well, so I usually make a few at a time and keep some on hand.

country:
None
text:
This was my first attempt at making homemade pizza crust. Great, easy recipe! Some things I altered: I used 1 tablespoon each of regular olive oil and basil infused olive oil, a dash or so of onion powder, and around a tablespoon of a pizza seasoning blend that contains oregano, basil, marjoram, and garlic. The crust it makes is very thick! This recipe could easily make 2 smaller thin crust pizzas.  It also wouldn’t hurt to pre-bake the crust for a couple minutes prior to adding toppings. The middle was still fully cooked without doing a pre-bake, but it didn’t get as crispy as I would have liked. I made one on a stone, and one on a metal pizza pan... I didn’t notice a significant difference between the two methods. Overall, FANTASTIC recipe that will definitely get used again and again!

1522917

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been playing with this recipe for two or three years and I think I finally have it the way I like it.  For me, the key is to use bread flour instead of All Purpose.  I also find that pizza dough is better when it is made several hours or days before you bake it.  Today, I made the dough in the later morning.  I let it rise on the counter until doubled.  Then I punched it down and put it in the fridge.  I punched it down once more in the fridge before taking it out for baking.  I let it sit out for at least 20 minutes before shaping it in the pan.  Then, I let it rise in the pan another 20 minutes or so.  And - I bake it at 475 - in an oven that has been preheating at least 45 minutes. I've tried baking with a stone and without a stone.  I find that my cheap, thin, tin round pan works the best.

text:
After trying tons of crust recipes, I finally found the perfect pizza crust. I follow the recipe but I do add in 3x the amount of brown sugar. I will sometimes add in crushed garlic or italian seasoning. It will make 2 14" thick crusts. I bake at 375 degrees for 20-25 minutes, but that is just my oven. Make sure you brush the crust with butter before adding the toppings

Update: I have now been making this weekly for Survivor pizza night. It is still a great dough week after week!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2206629.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is now my go-to pizza crust!  I had a "friendly" competition with my cousin (a chef at an Italian restaurant) over who makes the best home made pizzas.  Let's just say it was close to a very embarrassing moment for him!  The first few times I made this I was worried about the timing, but if you top the pizzas you can leave them out for an hour or so with no damage before popping them in the oven (the weight of the toppings seems to "hold" the crust down so they don't over proof and the crust rises up a bit around it to make a good food handle!).  Also, I find sliding them off the pans for the last 5 minutes of cooking time helps crisp the bottom, then I put them on wire racks to avoid soggy bottoms!  Awesome!

text:
I was nervous trying this recipe after I read through its bad reviews - and while I still don't know what went wrong for them, I am delighted by how this turned out for me! I was surprised I didn't need to add more than a half cup extra flour. Since a lot of the complaints were about hard dough, I left it slightly sticky and kneaded it only a bit. I added garlic powder, italian seasoning, and a bit of onion salt. I also pre-baked it for about ten minutes on a cookie sheet that was coated with some corn meal. The result? Exactly as advertised - crisp on the outside, soft on the inside, just thick enough, and flavorful (though probably because of the spices). Definitely a keeper!

text:
A SOLID recipe but after making it 4-5 times, I've finally mastered it (with the following tweaks).

1.) use a full tablespoon of salt
2.) add an extra tablespoon of olive oil
3.) brush it with olive oil, once on the stone (or in the pan)
4.) par-cook the dough for up to 10 minutes

A+!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pizza dough is perfect as written.  I divide into three portions and cook in a well oiled 9" round cake pan. I precook it for about 8 minutes, then add toppings, and continue cooking until cheese is bubbly.  I now refuse to buy pizza dough at the store.  I keep this in the freezer at all times.  I'm sure it is best to defrost for several hours, but I never remember to take it out in time.  Place in an oiled zip top bag, squeeze out the air, and seal well.  Then put the bag in a bowl of warm water (110ish-degrees).  Change the water after about 10 minutes.  It should be defrosted and ready to shape in 20-30 minutes.

text:
Never fails. Very easy to make. It is the best homemade crust i have ever made. Sometimes I double up the recipe and freeze one ball of dough right after kneading. I put it in a large oiled freezer bag, pressing out the air before closing. Voila! Frozen pizza dough ready to defrost and rise on the counter (still in the bag) the next time pizza is on the menu.  My kids actually tell me that it's as good or better than some of the pizza chain stores.  Another tip is to make mini pizzas and put them in the freezer wrapped in foil. Reheat in the oven for only a few minutes. I also pack the mini pizzas for the kids' school lunches.

text:
I used a bread machine - it definitely needed a little more flour (at least 3 2/3 cups, maybe a full 4 cups).  It was super sticky & hard to get out of the machine.  I also used my regular pizza stone - which is not an extra large size so the crust was super thick & needed probably a good 10 min in the oven before putting the toppings on (it was still slightly raw when we ate it).  I brushed the crust with some garlic butter & that made it crisp up nicely on the outside.  I would definitely use this recipe again if I want a thick crust (my husband actually liked it a lot & he's more of a thin crust guy).

text:
I am a very experienced bread, roll, crust baker. This was excellent! I used my kitchen aide mixer and did add a little more flour than called for to get the right texture. I used olive oil to grease my bowl, and that does impart more flavor than sprays, and I prefer whole and healthy to convenient and processed. Mt pizza topping began with a pesto base,, also homemade, which added more delicious flavor to the crust. From experience, I sprinkled cornmeal onto my jellyroll baking sheet before pressing the dough into the pan. 18 minutes in the oven resulted in a crispy crust throughout the pizza, with ideal chewiness. Perhaps the differences are a result of smaller pans, or varying ovens. I baked this with my convection bake setting.  This will return to my table frequently!

I added some garlic powder and pizza herbs/seasoning because that's what I usually do when I make pizza dough. I used this recipe earlier today because I couldn't find where I put my recipe book for the pizza dough recipe I usually use. I found it after the pizza was out of the oven! None
text:
The flour instructions confused me, as I changed the serving size to 8 but the 2 1/2 cup amount didn't change. I wasn't sure if this meant two half-cups or two and a half cups, so I added almost all of the flour and assumed the rest was for seasoning the kneading surface. Well, to clear things up, you're going to need a LOT more flour than it calls for. I ended up using around 3-4 cups of flour in total. I would recommend adding most before kneading as it becomes a mess otherwise. I also cooked this in a skillet, so I increased the cooking time by 5 minutes. Aside from the flour confusion, the pizza tasted as good as any I have bought, and much better than cook-from-frozen store pizzas. Thanks Jay!!

userID:
2855561
Display Name:
Christine Amsden
isPro:

7

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2328072.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've spent the past 3 years trying to improve upon this recipe. I've substituted varying quantities of wheat flour, or added certain Italian seasonings, or decreased the recipe for a thinner crust. And after all those experiments, I've figured something out: THIS IS PERFECT JUST THE WAY IT IS! Seriously. I wish the wheat flour had turned out because I do like staying on top of that health trend, and it's okay, but it makes for a tougher, chewier crust. As for the spice blends I've tried, they're okay, but it takes a lot to flavor the dough, and there is an easier way to have a flavorful pizza -- use quality toppings. I'm a supreme pizza girl in a supreme pizza household (well, the kids are a work in progress, but we'll get them there), and this crust supports the blend of meats and vegetables. (Not as good for a one-topping pizza, but then, I don't like one-topping pizzas.) 

Just one thing, and I cannot stress this enough, ***USE A PIZZA STONE*** You cannot make good pizza on anything else. You must use a pizza stone that you preheated in the oven so it's nice and hot. This cooks the crust from the top and the bottom, and keeps it from getting doughy.

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
This has been my "go to" pizza crust ever since I found it on this recipe website and it always gets GLORIOUS reviews by friends and family!  As long as you have fresh yeast, this recipe will NEVER FAIL YOU.  Crunchy on the oustide and chewy on the inside YES!  First time I made it, seemed strange that just after mixing it, the dough actually "poured" out of the mixing bowl and onto my floured surface - but don't worry, after it rises and you press out on a pizza stone it will be GREAT!  Pizza will be very thick, so consider dividing in half for hand tossed thickness like at pizza parlors - otherwise BEST PIZZA DOGH EVER!

text:
My family has enjoyed this dough time and time again. Recipe is good for either thick or thin pizzas. Just roll it or stretch it out to your liking. We have also used this recipe to make calzones and panzos and it works just right... same oven temp, but I usually add around 10 minutes to the time, give or take. The reason I give 4 stars instead of 5 is the lack of flavor. I've added garlic powder, onion powder, fresh garlic, rosemary, or combinations of the above. With none of these things added, it is a little bland. As long as you season the dough, it's great. This is our go to recipe!

text:
I used this recipe for deep fried dough sticks. You know how you get the garlic bread from restaurant? These had a nice crust on the outside and fluffy insides. When you are told that your breadsticks are better than Domino's or Pizza Hut you need to give the credit where it is due. I could not have had the success I did without Jay's Signature Pizza Crust recipe. Years back I loved these deep fried dough balls with cheese and marinara for dipping. I was about to go on the road back to that taste. I thought it would have been a long journey to go back 20 years. Not so. This was the first pizza dough recipe I tried in our deep fryer. I was a bit worried how the deep frying cooking process would alter the final product.I drizzled them with garlic salt and margarine as soon as they came out of the fryer. Now that I know this works I will be using real ingredients like garlic and butter. Wasn't expecting success the first time. Jay has done a wonderful thing. I plan on making little Calzones next time. This a great recipe for beginners. I am by no stretch of the imagination new to baking but the personal investment and technical skills necessary are minimal. The dough proofed in less than an hour(about 40 minutes) AT ROOM TEMPERATURE.  They say that perfection is a journey and not a destination but if you are looking for the perfect dough-ball recipe this is the recipe for you. 

Thank you Jay!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a wonderful pizza crust. I made it in the bread machine, turned it out onto a large cutting board, then line a 10 inch (sort of small) cast iron skillet with it, trimming it around the outside edge to make a deep dish crust. I then baked it for 10 minutes at 400 degrees before assembling the pizza. After assembly, I baked it at 325 degrees (convection mode) for about 20 minutes. The crust was very full and great tasting. About three minutes before taking it out I brushed the outer layer of crust with olive oil and seasonings. It was a hit! I will use this crust in the future.

I did not roll the dough out very thin, as I wanted thick crust deep dish. It rises a lot, more than I expected. But, where I live in China, pizza is unheard of, much less the kind I made using this crust! Many thanks to Jay!!!

text:
I agree with the reviewers who 1) compared this crust to Pizza Hut's pan pizza; and 2) recommended pre-baking the crust a bit before adding toppings. I decided not to pre-bake, and I wish I had. I also noticed that, as I added the flour while kneading, my dough never become "not sticky," so eventually I just decided to work with what I had (which was decidedly sticky). It still came out great - I usually prefer a thin crust, but if I'm ever craving a thicker crust, this'll be my go-to recipe.

text:
Freaking great! Soft and crispy! I added some Italian seasoning, garlic powder and onion powder and this crust was delicious! I topped it with a simple Ragu Alfredo Sauce and finely chopped ten cloves of garlic in to it. (don't fear the garlic. it made the pizza!) I also lightly coated the outer crust with olive oil. Then topped it with canned artichoke hearts, fresh mushrooms, fresh basil, sun dried tomatoes, mozzarella and shaved parmesan. Man was that a great pizza! For as cheap as some of the ingredients were, it tasted exactly like a creamy, garlicky specialty vegetarian pizza you would get at a higher end pizzeria! Thanks Jay!

text:
I followed the recipe exactly to start off but had to make serious changes to salvage it.  The first problem is that there is too much liquid relative to the flour. At step three I had a nearly liquid "dough" that I was supposed to turn out and knead.  I added the needed flour in order to make it solidify.  The pizza turned out flavorless.  I followed other's advice and par-baked it for a few mins before adding the toppings.

text:
This crust is delightfully chewy, and yet crispy at the same time. I don't think I will ever use another one. If I have time I make the dough with only half the flour (a sponge) and let it rest for an hour before adding the rest of the flour, for added chewiness, and a fuller flavor. But the recipe is fantastic as is!

text:
I have four teenage boys and a husband.  I need enough food to fill their tummies and this pan pizza was incredible.  It was HUGE!!!  I used 12 inch pizza pans and had to half the bread since it makes for two pizzas that size.  They could only eat a quarter of a pizza and were too full.  I used the recipe for "Easy Pizza Sauce III" as my sauce and it was Soooo good. I will definitely make this again.  We brushed ours with olive oil, seasoned with italian seasoning, and pre baked the crust for 10 minutes.  You have to cook the crust slightly prior to topping it. I had so much left over that I precooked a pizza, topped it and stored it for the next night's dinner.  Oh, I also made cheesy sticks. Yum!

text:
I followed the directions exactly. I used 3.5C flour. I used my Kitchen Aid and personally, I like the dough a little sticky. That is what makes it light and not dense. TIP: instead of using a floured surface, oil a counter top and your hands to handle the dough and you will be able to work with it a lot better. Use a rolling pin and your (oiled hands) to roll into a circle.

text:
Wonderful crispy yet soft and chewy crust. I followed suggestions from past reviewers which helped a lot and I also added a little more br. sugar, fresh herbs and fresh grated parmesan cheese to the dough mixture. It was absolutely flavorful and delicious. The only thing I forgot was to brush on a little olive oil to the crust to help it stay nice and golden. We were happy with the way the texture of the pizza crust turned out great which was slightly crusty on the outside. This was my first attempt to make home made pizza dough. Thank you Jay for this delicious recipe. I used, "Exquisite Pizza Sauce," also from this website. I plan on making this again as this was a hit with my family!

This was my first time cooking with yeast, and I am happy to say it was easier than I thought! The dough was tasty, but keep in mind it makes a lot of it-- enough to cover an entire 18X13 pan, and I would have rolled it thinner if I had the space. If you have a round pizza tray/stone, I recommend using it to make two personalized pizzas. I will keep this recipe because it was so easy and tastes better than store bought.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great basic recipe. This is my first attempt at homemade pizza. I live in the south and I am from Chicago so ALL the pizza here just doesn't cut it. I did make a few changes but this recipe
is a good beginning. I added italian seasoning and garlic powder to the oil-salt mixture. This makes a BIG pizza, I easily made a pizza 16 inches across on a round cheap pizza pan with holes. I rolled it very thin, it was easy to roll. I have enough left over for a 10 or 12 pie. 
 Pre-heated oven to 450. I also brushed the crust with olive oil-melted butter  and let rise 10 more min. I pre cooked for 6 min. took out and added toppings. Cooked for 12 mins. spun around and cooked for 5 mins more. This is just like a Chicago thin crust pizza. 
Changes I will make next time:Pre-cook for 10 mins. Brush with butter only, and cook on the lowest rack. The crust was alittle undercooked underneth. But just a little. This crust can be thick or thin it's just up to you....thanks

text:
This was very good! I wish I read reviews because, as a newbie making breads, I was just following the recipe. The flour was way off for me. I added an extra cup of flour while using the dough hook on my KA and it was still extremely sticky. I was afraid to add more thinking it would mess up the dough. It rose fine and was still pretty sticky but I stretched it out with some more flour and it actually came out great! Seems to be a fool-proof recipe but I will definitely be using more flour next time.

country:
None
text:
okay, I have made this pizza crust three or four times before and thought it was good, but not anything wonderful. However, this evening I made this crust again and realized I was not letting the crust rise 15 to 20 minutes after putting it on the pizza pan.  this is the key to a nice crust!  I also stretched the dough out about 1 inch past the edge of the pizza pan and rolled some of the shredded mozzerella cheese up in the crust.  Took a little work, but it was really good and looked great.   I also baked the pizza at 350 degrees for about 10 minutes then bumped it up to the 425 degrees to brown the cheese a litte.  I don't like a doughy crust.

text:
Excellent! I tried this pizza crust recipe today; it was the first time I had ever made a home made pizza crust.  VERY easy -- not even worth the hassle of breaking out the ol' bread machine.  I did pre-bake the crust for 10 minutes before adding my toppings to ensure the crust got nice and golden brown and crispy.  Added my toppings, then finished baking until the cheese was all beautifully melted.  The crust was delicious and crispy and chewy!  Wonderful! Will use forever and ever and am excited to try different types of pizzas now!

text:
Excellent crust. I made it in the bread machine on the dough cycle and added some italian seasoning and garlic powder. It made 3 medium pizza's. My house smelled like a pizzaria before I even cooked the crust. I messed up and was waiting for the bottom to get golden. It never did and I burnt the pizza slightly. Still delicious. I will never buy a store bought crust again. You can't even compare the 2. UPDATE: I have made this 4 times now. I always put cornmeal on the bottom of the pizza pans. I tried baking the crust for 5 min and then adding the toppings but thought it came out too hard. I definitely won't do that again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great pizza dough recipe. It was super easy to knead in my KA for about 5 minutes. The only thing I didn't like about it was that it didn't get crispy at all on the bottom, but I think I just need one of those pizza pans with the holes in it or something. Next time I might try some whole wheat flour. UPDATE: I tried again with a real pizza pan, but it was still doughy on the bottom, so I transfered it straight to the oven rack for a few minutes at the end, and that helped a lot! Also, we used almost all whole wheat flour this time and I would not recommend it. It completely changed the consistancy and texture of the crust. I think I will do 2 cups regular flour, 1 cup wheat from now on.

text:
I used this recipe last night to make my first homemade pizza ever. It was very easy to make and I didn't find it inconvenient at all to let it rise for a little while since I had other things to do. I followed the recipe and I topped the rolled crust with sauteed onions, mushrooms, roasted garlic, mozzarella and parmesan cheese. I cooked it for 20 minutes. I could not believe how beautiful and puffy this pizza was! It was absolutely perfect! I told my husband that dinner was done and he took one look at the pizza and ran to get the camera hehe. He was so proud of me that he wanted to take a picture. It is funny because I would consider myself to be a good cook, and I cook all of the time. It tasted as good as it looked! Thank you so much for the recipe! I don't think I will ever try another crust!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Dear Jay, you have pushed the boundaries of home cooking. I had no idea what could be achieved with a tin of flour, a rolling pin and an oven until I made this recipe. I acheived the most soft, fluffy, doughy pizza crust I've ever eaten. My buddies were speechless. One of my mates even went out the next day and bought a new oven so he could make this.  Advice: I only got the hang of this on the fourth try. The key is to really MAKE SURE the dough is "no longer sticky". I ended up having to use a lot more flour than I expected when "kneading in more flour". I really dug my fingers deep into the dough, and got every inch of it smooth. This also took a lot more effort than I expected. I really had to work up a big sweat to get a result here. When punhcing the dough, I also didn't hold back.  What I got was a very rubbery dough. When streching it out onto the pan, it had a lot of resistence, and kept wanting to bounce back. This was the main difference I noticed between this attempt and my other, unsuccessful, attempts.   Great!

text:
Perfect pizza crust!  This is so simple it seems impossible that it could be that good.  This will be my go to pizza crust from now on.  One batch yielded me two large crusts.  It raised perfectly.  I did let it set 10-15 minute before using my hands to press it into a round shape on my pizza pans.  I prebaked my crust for 10 minutes at 375 degrees for 10 minutes, topped it, then baked for an additional 10 minutes at 400 degrees.  It was slightly crispy on the outside and nice and chewy on the inside.  YUM!

THis was wonderful. I made it for my family and our company and several commented on the crust. I let it raise for 1 hour in an oven that I preheated at 170 degress and shut off. It raised very nicely. Don't overcook this. I made two pans, the one I let the edges get nice and brown but when we ate it  the edges got alittle crisp. The other one I took out when it was very lightly browned but this one I actually had on a stone too so that probably helped. This was our favorite homemade crust we have ever had.

This was fantastic!  I ended up needing all the flour in order to make the dough not stick, and then added some more flour while I was shaping the crust. text:
Per someone's suggestion, I added 1/2 tsp of garlic powder, 1/2 tsp of Oregano with dash of freshly-cracked black pepper into the batter before kneading the dough. I also brushed some olive oil on pizza edges and baked crust with pizza sauce for 10 min. at 325 degrees before adding other toppings. My “Chicken Mozzarella Ham Pizza” really came out crusty on the outside and chewy from inside. This recipe can make two 10" thick crusts and three 10” thin crusts. So, next time we will double all ingredients to freeze them for later use.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fantastic.  One thing I do differently is use quick rise yeast.  It may not yield such high-quality dough, but the time it saves me is well worth it.  So I add all dry ingredients together and then pour in the wet, and mix as usual.  I immediately shape it into pizzas and let rise maybe 15-20 mintues, just to say it bulks up a bit (I still put them in a warm moist place covered in a towel).  Then I top and bake.  Simple as that.  Remember that if you don't roll the ends of your dough inwards after shaping it, you won't get a nice crust.  Just roll them to the desired thickness.

Before making this, I never could get a pizza crust quite right, but this recipe was it! I add mixed Italian seasoning in with the flour, along with a bit more onion and garlic powder, always sprinkle the bottom of the crust with corn meal, and pre-bake it for a few min before topping, and I have never had a better crust from any restaurant I've ever eaten at. text:
First time crust-maker. Recipe was simple, and gives an absolutely delicious result. I did add some garlic and onion powder, about 1/2 tsp each, although next time I might add a little bit more. I divided dough into 2...my pizza stone isnt that big, and there are 2 different "tastes" in the family. I had a bit of a hard time transferring the dough round from a cookie sheet to the pizza stone. I used what I thought was quite a good layer of cornmeal. Next time I might try spraying it a bit. Before I added the toppings, I brushed some olive oil over the dough and sprinkled with italian seasoning. Nice crunchy outside (not hard) and fluffy inside. Better than delivery or frozen. I have requests to make again in the next couple days. THANKS!!

text:
Wow, what a terrific crust! The best we've tried to date. The only alteration I made was subbing in 1 cup of whole wheat flour to add a healthy touch. The dough was extremely easy to work with an roll out. I got two medium thin crust pizzas out of this recipe. Made it on my pizza stone and pre-baked crust for 7 minutes on lower rack first. country:
None
text:
What's great about this dough is that it can turn to either the thicker bread like variety or the thinner crustier (and hence less filling) variety depending on how you handle it. I am pretty hopeless at rolling out dough into a perfectly round circle so what I do is I beat down an appropriate amount of dough into a minimally floured pizza pan, then lift up the shaped dough with both hands while someone oils the pan, then place it back in. The dough would've stretched to larger than the pan size by this point (and thinner than before lifting it from the pan), so I cut of the excess and use it for the next pizza pan, patching up any small holes with dough.

This was awesome and the pizza disappeared as fast as it came out of the oven!  It was incredible!  Thank you for posting this easy recipe that is delicious!

text:
Best pizza dough recipe I've tried yet.  I added some seasonings:  1 tsp. garlic powder, 1/2 tsp. onion powder, 1/2 tsp. Italian seasoning.  I also increased the brown sugar to 1 tsp.  I "knead" the dough for 10 minutes using my KitchenAide with the dough hook.  I sprinkle cornmeal over the pizza pan before I press the dough into it.  I also rubbed the outer crust with olive oil prior to putting the toppings on.

text:
This crust was fantastic!  If you have a lot of toppings (our bbq chicken and hawaiian pizzas were pretty loaded), prebaking is a great idea...doesn't need a lot, just 5-10 min at 400 will do the trick.  I loved the idea of adding seasonings but didn't see any amounts in any reviews, so I guestimated and came up with: 1 heaping tsp of garlic powder, 1/2 tsp of onion powder, and 1/2 tsp of oregano.  I kept the salt the same and added a few generous dashes of black pepper--wow!  Jay gave the great texture and here's the great flavor! I started my pizzas at 375 and turned them up to 425 at the end to get a nice brown on them.  I also rubbed the outer crust with olive oil.  Thanks for the great recipe!

Display Name:
Margaret

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe after I figured out what worked best for me.  First, I mixed everything in the bread machine like any other dough.  I split the dough in half but we like a thick crust and so no more splitting the dough.  The first half, I baked on a pizza stone on the bottom shelf but will not do that again as it was tough.  I refrigerated the second half and removed from the refrigerator, generously oiled a small iron skillet, sprinkled with cornmeal and "tossed" the dough by letting the weight of the dough shape the circle.  (Just hold by the edge and work around in a circle until the right size.)  I placed it in the pan with a piecrust edge.  The crust rose on top of the warm stove while the oven was heating.  Then, I put on the toppings, drizzled a little extra olive oil around the outside crust and baked on the middle rack.  This was great!  We want be ordering anymore Pizza Hut pizza!  I don't see a need for preheating the skillet or prebaking the crust.  This is a really good crust and I look forward to trying bread sticks and cinnamon sticks with it.  I might try a little more sugar in the crust next time - possibly natural brown sugar, a little Italian seasoning and garlic as some suggested although, my husband said that it is perfect the way it is.  Thanks for a great recipe, Jay!

None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe! I have used it for pizza as well as italian pizza bread(italian dressing with asiago, parmesan and mozzarella cheese sprinkled on top). Everyone loves it. I noticed a few people were saying they had tough crusts. If this is the case you are over-kneeding your crust. The recipes states to add flour till it is no longer sticky but there should be a slight moistness before it goes through the 1 hour rising period or it will be dried out and tough. I also sprinkle cornmeal on the pan before I place the dough on to it. This definitely adds to it!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/364297.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm soo glad I tried this recipe!  This is the first time I've been pleased with the way homemade pizza crust has turned out.  I made this in my bread machine on the dough cycle and had to add about 1/2 c. more flour; the dough was waaay too sticky otherwise.  As suggested by a previous reviewer, I added 1 tsp. Italian seasoning, 1/2 tsp. garlic powder, and 1/2 tsp. onion powder to add some more flavor.  After taking it out of the machine, I divided it into two, let it rest a few min., then rolled it out, pricked it with a fork, and let it rest in the pans about 15 min.  I liberally oiled my deep dish baking stone and my cast iron skillet, baked the crust 10 min. on the bottom rack before adding the toppings and baking for an additional 15 min.  Turned out similar to Pizza Hut deep dish!  Yum!

I will without a doubt be using this recipe for now on!!

I made this in the bread machine! Tip do not use warm water, just regular temp tap and cook on the dough cycle. Also since I didn't have a pizza stone, I let the pizza rise in the oven for 10 minutes at 170 degrees. I then cooked it at 425 for 10 mins. I then put all the toppings then cooked in oven again for 8 minutes. It was perfect! I did add some herbs to the crust (basil & Oregano) and I'll add more next time along with garlic. This is the best!

text:
If you use a pizza stone to cook the pizza, preheat the stone in the oven for an hour. The heat contained in the stone will give the pizza a great crispy crust.   Coat the bottom of the crust with Yellow Corn Meal. It you put the pizza on the without it, it will not come off easily. Then slide the pizza off the stone after its done so it doesn't continue to bake the bottom.

This dough turned out soooo thick, it could have made two pizzas, but I don't have a large pan so maybe that was it.  It puffed up in the oven so perfectly and was crisp on the outside and doughy on the inside, just as the recipe said.  I used white sugar instead of brown sugar, and pretty much did everything else the same.  Next time I will add more salt and make two pizzas out of it.

As far as pizza crust goes, I usually have nothing but problems.  This recipe, however, turned out pretty good.  I wouldn't exactly compare it to pizza hut's pan pizza as some reviews say. I will definitely make this again, only I will be a bit more generous with the seasonings and probably brush the crust with butter instead.

Best.Crust.Ever!  I needed two pizza crusts and so I doubled the recipe. 

My changes: (1) substituted 2 cups white flour for whole wheat flour. (2) For knead I used bread maker, because I'm lazy like that.  BONUS: Be sure and give a generous edge crust on your pizza! text:
The first time I made this recipe, it was a disaster.  My pizza cooked unevenly, and half of it rose about 2 inches higher than the other (raw) side.  I gave it a second try today with an important change (for me anyways), and wow!  It's perfect!  Instead of dry active yeast, I used instant yeast.  I melted the sugar in hot water, mixed in the salt and oil, and then added a mixture of the yeast and flour.  It came out beautifully!

Display Name:
Baybee Caix

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/145624.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought this pizza dough made a phenomonal crust! I too added seasonings and parmesan cheese to my dough. I smeared this crust with 'Exquisite Pizza Sauce' from this website and I had a winning recipe combo. I made the dough a day in advance, divided it into 2 portions, applied a thin coating of olive oil to keep the dough from drying out and getting sticky, and finally wrapped the 2 discs in plastic wrap. Just let the dough come to room temp before patting it down and stretching it out- it makes it so much easier to handle. I baked my crusts ( I made 2 smaller pizzas) in perforated pizza pans on the bottom rack at 500 degrees for 8 min., then turned down the temp to 425 degrees and baked for 8 more min. I chose to brush some melted garlic butter on the edges of the crusts after they baked- IDK, just an idea I got from a pizzeria. It was crusty on the outside and nice and chewy on the inside. My guinea pig wants another homemade pizza for his upcoming b-day. Thanks, Jay! * If adding greenery such as parsley, basil, spinach, ect. I highly recommend placing these topping directly on the sauce then covering with cheese and other toppings. The first pizza I made had crispy spinach with charred edges. Go 'head and giggle! :P

text:
I have tried many pizza crusts and none of them worked.  I decided to try this one because of all the good reviews.  This pizza dough is fabulous!  It's basically fool proof.  I have allowed this dough to sit in the fridge for 2 days before baking and I have made it last minute and either way, it comes out perfect!  I like to cook my pizzas in a pan on the outdoor grill.  The pizza crust comes out crunchy on the outside,  fully cooked and nice and  "fluffy" on the inside.  You can't mess it up!
I like to put fresh mozzarella and good canned tomatoes on my pizzas like I had them when we visited NYC. 
TIP: Precook crust 2-5 minutes before final cooking with toppings.
Thank you, Jay, for a great crust recipe!

text:
This is an awesome recipe.

One word of advice: If you substitute whole wheat flour, use Gold Medal Stone Ground Whole Wheat. Don't use Hodgson Mill Brand.  The difference is like night and day.  For some reason the Hodgson Mill flour creates a very terrible (lumpy and brittle) dough but Goal Medal makes a great (smooth and elastic) dough.  I've tried them both several times.

Awesome crust!  I hate using yeast because it usually takes me a few tries to get it to proof.  Three tries this time but it was totally worth it.  It looked so good and was nice and thick.  That said, there are a few changes I plan on making next time.  1. Will use heavier toppings.  I used Buffalo Style Chicken Pizza from this site and it's just too light for a crust this thick.  2.  Will prebake for 5 minutes so that it gets a little crisper on the bottom.  3. Brush the edges with butter and sprinkle with garlic salt.  4.  Spray the bottom of the pizza pan with Pam.   Great this time, but I think it'll blow us away next time.  Thanks!

text:
I'm trying to avoid high glycemic foods, so I subbed one cup white flour for stone ground wheat and used raisins in warm water, with a tsp of honey (blenderized) in place of the brown sugar.  I ran out of time and so after the first rise I put the dough in the fridge and came back to it about five hours later (tres convenient).  This was a tasty, tender dough, next time I will do a slow rise, overnight in the fridge, since I think that makes the dough chewier.

text:
Very good!!!  I added 1/2 tsp garlic powder and 1 tsp italian seasoning at the same time that I added the salt.  I then mixed it in my bread machine.  I will definitely make again!!
*Second time making this I turned it into breadsticks.  I added 1 tsp of garlic powder, 1 Tbsp of italian seasoning.  Then baked for a couple minutes, removed them from the oven and pre-cut them, sprinkled with approx 1/2 cup of fresh parmesan and then baked again for another 7-10 minutes.  Once they were done, I brushed them with garlic butter.  They were delicious!

None
text:
Muy delicioso! I used bread flour instead of all-purpose and it came out great! I also found that leaving the dough overnight helped to give it that pizzeria dough taste. Sprinkled some cornmeal on the bottom before baking and call it a day! I agree with the other members about leaving the dough to cook a little first before adding the toppings and maybe poking some holes on the dough beforehand to keep bubbles from forming. Also, I didn't know this the first time I used yeast but be sure to follow the instructions as far as the water/liquid temperature---that way the yeast can activate and give the dough that fantastic rise! Thanks for sharing this awesome recipe!

text:
Nice recipe. If you don't have a pizza stone, sprinkle cornmeal over your pizza pan. This helps make a nice crust -- and no sticking. UPDATE: I had leftover dough in my refrigerator. Then, my nephew & I had a brain storm today (he's 6). We scooped out the dough, using a standard ice-cream scoop. We then rolled the dough into a ball, floured the ball, and then flattened it in a floured tortilla press. This made great little pizzas for lunch. And he loved pressing the dough and applying the toppings to the crust.

text:
This is one of my family's favorite. We  make them into small breadsticks.  Using fast rising yeast, let it sit for ten minutes after kneading (should rise a little) and then shape into breadsticks.  Brush with melted butter, parmesan and garlic pepper.  Let them rise for about 20 minutes then cook for 14 minutes at 250 degrees.  Delicious!!

text:
Easy to make and work with!  The flavor was OK but not really anything special.  I think next time I will sub honey for the sugar and see how that does.  I made two pizzas with this.  One thing we did was to prebake one crust before adding sauce and the other one we just added sauce before baking.  We preferred the one that was not prebaked - The crust was moist under the sauce and crispy on the bottom.  The prebaked one was more like a cracker all they way through.  Of course the dough was very thin to begin with because of making 2 pizzas with one recipe.  We are thin crust people.  Will use again!   Thanks

text:
This made an awesoem crust...highly recomended!!! I did make a few changes, i didn't have any olive oil so I used butter and I added 2 tsp of milk powder( makes it softer). I made the dough in the bread machine then let it rise in the pans till my husband got home to eat. I would definatly recommend cooking the crust for at least 5 minutes or so before adding the topping. The dough was a bit too soft in the center. I will be making this again and adding it to my recipe box...Thanks:)
