text:
I'm giving this recipe 4 stars because it does have a wonderful texture and turns out great everytime! That said, the amount of flour is not very accurate, and to make it flavorful you do need to tweak the recipe a bit. I liked it the way it was, but I probably wouldn't have kept making it, if it wasn't for some of the suggestions in the reviews. If it doesn't turn out right the first time, read the other reviews and make some adjustments to get the best pizza crust ever. This is the only recipe I use now...with my adjustments ;)

text:
This was fabulous!  I added a tsp each of garlic powder, oregano and basil to the dough and baked it about 10 mins before adding the toppings.  Smelled so good could have just kept baking it and eaten it as it was!  The only thing was I added almost another cup of flour as was very sticky and then I guess I kneaded it too much as was very springy and wouldn't stay put on the sheet pan; kept springing back to the centre.  Finally convinced it to stay stretched out in the end tho.  Will definitely be making pizza and bread sticks and whatever else I can think up with this!  Thanks Jay!!

text:
Used a pizza stone. Very good but a little bit time consuming with the hour wait. Healthier than the store bought pizza dough packets and frozen pizzas by far. Rose very nicely. Kept shape very well (didn't spring back). I used white sugar instead of brown and added 1 tsp of garlic powder to dough. Cook dough for at least 5-10 minutes before adding topping and cook in bottom shelf.  Nice easy recipe.

userID:

Display Name:
DCANT

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3056.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've tried pizza doughs without any luck until today.  For those of you who are curious this dough turns out a little less thick than Pizza Hut's and less greasy.  I did a couple of things differently after reading many reviews.  I let it rise 45 minutes after kneading. I greased the pans with butter and molded the dough into the pizza pans.  Let it stand another 30 minutes or so.  Finally, I added the ingredients and baked in the oven as directed.  I doubled the recipe because we are family of six and got 2 x 16" and two 8" pizzas.  I also doubled the sugar and salt and the dough turned out with a really good flavour.  The crust was crispy on the outside and fluffy inside.  It was just perfect.  We did a cheese only one for the kids and one with the works.  The more ingredients you put the wetter the crust so keep that in mind.  Also, one very good suggestion from another reviewer was to bake in the bottom rack this way the dough will cook without burning the cheese and other toppings.  Thanks Jay!

text:
I gave this 4 stars because my husband loved it, however my son and I were not really thrilled with it.  It is nothing like pizza shop crust, which is what I was looking for.  I did add some spice the the dough, per other reviewers {garlic powder, basil, oregano, and parmesan cheese} and mixed the dough in my bread machine.  It came out extremely sticky and I had to add more flour at that point and knead it.  It just didn't have much taste to it and got very crispy, although the crispiness might have been my pan.  Since hubby loved it, I will likely try it again, but I will also continue searching for other recipes.

text:
I rolled the crust out to what I thought was thin enough to turn out the thickness of a hand tossed pizza.  However the crust rose into the thickness of a pan pizza.  For those of you who are going for a thinner crust make sure you roll very thin.  Great recipe though.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had to let the dough rest in the bowl for a few hours and I made two batches. I read all the other reviewers comments and thought that if I just left the dough as is and rolled it out it would be a thick crust. So, I rolled it out with a floured roller until it reached a thickness that I thought would not puff up too much. I did have excess which I froze. I didn't let it rise in the pan but immediately put the topping on and cooked it. It didn't rise, except for the edges which puffed a tiny bit. So because my dh likes a thin crust I did this to the 2nd batch as well. So, I wish I would have let it rise in the pan for the first pizza which was my favourite. I also added onion powder and garlic powder to the mix.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this pizza dough for over 12 years now and it always turns out.  I always get rave reviews from everyone who tries it.  I  make the dough hours before I need it and let it rise longer in the bowl.  Once I roll it out and place it on the pan I stick it in the oven and I turn on the bread proof feature and let it rise for just under an hour.  I find that I get a thicker crust when I do this.  Lately I've been using half all purpose and half whole wheat flour and it works great and gives it a nice taste.  Best dough ever!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had such high hopes for this based on recent reviews and popularity.  While making the dough, I had to add much more than the 3 1/3 cups flour but kept telling myself that all flours vary.  While proofing, I then came back and read reviews and realized I was not alone in the flour issue.  Others also stated it needed more salt and sugar.  I did prebake the crust (made sicilian style on a large cookie sheet since I only had 1 round pan)  I again took advice and prebaked the crust for 10 minutes brushed with EVO and some garlic powder and herbs and added feta, spinach, calamata olives, mozzarella, romano, and parmesan shredded.  Had some roasted red peppers so threw a few of those on.  With the toppings it was okay but it is not a chewy crust...more like italian bread.  It is a rather bland crust.  I didn't have the sticking to the pan problem, threw cornmeal down...can't beat it; acts like little ball bearings.  I am glad I tried but needs too much tweaking so would rather search for another.

text:
Excellent pizza crust recipe.  I also sprinkle the crust with Italian seasoning but I also add a good sprinkle of California garlic powder before putting the toppings on.  Since I use a stone to bake the pizza, I don't pre-bake the crust.  I do cut the recipe in half which makes one thin crust 16" pizza.  YUMMY!!

text:
Amazing! I split the dough (after it rose) into four portions to make 4 thin-crust style grilled pizzas. I punched down each portion separately. Caution: if you do the same, refridgerate the dough ASAP. I forgot to put the individual plastic bags containing the extra dough portions into the fridge, and had to repackage b/c the dough rose again and busted the bags' seams!! Also, the dough could use a bit more salt, but not sure how to adjust without messing up the rising process. Any suggestions?

text:
I recently made a pizza dough from a pizzeria website, and it was awful. I vowed never again - but out of curiosity, I thought I'd give this recipe a go. I am not the best cook, in fact I can't even make roast potatoes I am that bad. I followed the instructions by the book (halved the quantities as I didn't have enough flour), loaded it up with sauce and veggies - no cheese as I'm trying to give it up and I havent got any lying around. Anyway, I have just taken it out of the oven (just used a normal oven tray as I don't have a pizza stone) and hey - its fantastic!!! Really, really nice  - great texture - light and fluffy yet crispy. I will definetly be making this again. Thankyou Jason, you deserve a great big kiss !!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/962968.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow!  Seriously, one of the best pizza crusts I have ever had--my new favorite.  I made roughly a 13-14" pizza with this in combination with a sauce recipe called "Exquisite Pizza Sauce" on this very site.  Cooked for right around 16 minutes (very old oven, and tends to be inconsistent) and the crust turned out absolutely perfect; very thick, soft crust--like deep dish style.  Worth every second of the prep time involved...

Also, we made this on a pizza stone, and we did NOT preheat the stone first.  I rounded-out the dough on the stone itself, topped it off and put it directly in the preheated oven--16 minutes later, it was perfect.

One more thing: careful not to over-eat with this recipe.  This crust will expand in your stomach and make you miserable if you're not careful...  ;)

text:
I really like this pizza crust recipe. I used to purchase pre-baked crusts but was looking for a healthier option and decided to try making my own. One recipe I tried (not on this site) didn't work at all.  I've made this one 3 times since, and it's been great every time.  The flavor is kind of bland tasted alone but I find the taste to be very good with pizza toppings.  I even ran out of flour once and used about half whole wheat, and it tasted even better like that.  I like to use the amount needed for the pizza I'm making that day and freeze the rest in individual sizes so I can make a quick pizza anytime I want it.

Excellent!!  I have never made pizza dough before last night.  I saw this recipe a while back and saved it to my recipe box and last night I made it for dinner.  It was very easy and fun to make.  After the dough rose and was ready to be rolled I just put the ball on my pizza pan and spread it out with my hands.  My husband liked it very much he said it filled him up with only 2 pieces, my 2 year old son ate one whole piece and is currently working on a left over piece for his lunch, my 11 year old sister said it was the best pizza she's ever had, and I couldn't agree more with all of them.  Thanks allrecipes I LOVE this site!

Wow! I've never made pizza crust from scratch before, but it turned out Great! I 1/2ed the recipe. And it was the perfect size, about a medium large. I did think it might need just a little more salt add. Plus, if you use a baking sheet/etc. make sure you cook it on your bottom rack of your oven. Also let it cook about 8-9 minutes before putting on your toppings.

I've finally found a pizza dough recipe I like!  I kept the recipe as it was, except I kneaded in some pizza seasoning into the crust, as well as about 1/4 to 1/3 cup of cornmeal. text:
Pretty good, but needed flavor, so I kneaded in some pressed garlic, garlic and onion powder, and oregano to spice it up.  If you're not using a pizza stone, I wouldn't pre-bake the crust first, as it rises and makes it hard to get the sauce to stay on the crust.

text:
Speaking from a dough novice point of view, five stars is not enough for this recipe!  I consider myself a pizza connoisseur, and this crust rivals the best pizzeria crusts I have enjoyed.  I added four teaspoons of vital wheat gluten hoping to make the dough more elastic and chewy as I was afraid that the little kneading that the dough required would turn out a flat hard pizza.  I do not know if my addition made this crust chewy on the inside and crisp on the outside or if it was just the original recipe.  I will make this again and again.  Already planning on making calzone with it today.  Many thanks to the originator of this recipe.

text:
Wow!  Finally a pizza dough recipe that actually tastes like...pizza crust.  Thank's Jay!  I used a bread machine on the dough cycle [Order in: water, oil, flour (substituted bread flour), sugar (substituted "fake" calorie-free brown sugar), salt, yeast (quick-acting)] and it made this recipe that much easier!  Once the dough cycle was finished I halved the recipe as other's suggested (freezing the rest for later) and it made 8 delicious thin slices (took close to 30 minutes to bake it all the way through).

I like a thicker crust so I may try using 3/4 of the dough next time and using the rest for breadsticks but even as a thin crust it was very filling.  Will *definitly* be making again!

text:
I have made this crust over a dozen times and I have found it to be the best. I have made a few changes the last couple times I've made it. I've added minced garlic to the dough to give it more flavor and now I always pre bake the dough (on a pizza stone) for 5 min. and then top the pizza with sauce, cheese and toppings. That way the crust gets cooked to a golden brown color instead of staying white. I will not buy frozen pizza anymore. It's just to easy to make this crust.

text:
This is the only recipe I've used for years.  I use my bread machine to prepare.  I scale it to 8 servings for a perfect standard-size, 12 inch pizza.  I cut the amount of water slightly as I found I had to add too much flour to make it a workable ball of dough.  Also, after the second rise when the crust is nice and full, it "deflates" after I top it so I'm going to try baking it for 8-10 minutes before topping.  Still, this is the best  and easiest recipe.

text:
My fiance and I made this crust last night, and it was excellent!!  Just like the recipe says - soft on the inside and a little crusty on the outside.

This made only one crust for us (we like our crust somewhat thick).  I used a pizza stone and pre-baked the crust for only 2 minutes (at 425).  I should have pre-baked for just another minute longer - we like to load on the toppings, and the crust came out just a tiny bit underdone in the middle.

Excellent - definitely a keeper!

text:
Definately a winner and definately makes more than one crust.  After rolling out a circle big enough to fill width of the cookie sheet, I still had enough for about 8 good sized bread sticks.  I didn't have any trouble with it browning.  We had a "Greek" pizza with layers of thinly sliced tomatoes topped with minced garlic, sliced black olives, onion and feta.  I prebaked the crust for about 15 minutes to keep the crust from getting soggy once the tomato slices were added.  It has a lot more flavor than regular crusts - maybe it's the brown sugar.  Regardless, this is our crust from here on out!  Thanks.

text:
My first attempt at a homemade pizza crust and I was not disappointed!  The yeast I used was even expired by at least a year, and it was still great.  There was nothing hard about making this crust.  Yes, it was sticky after mixing, but by adding the rest of the flour, it really had a nice texture after the kneading.  I used a large deep-dish style pizza pan and made a perfect "medium thickness" crust. Had enough dough left to make a small personal pizza. I also added a little Italian seasoning to the dough before kneading.  I think this crust would be hard to mess-up!

I prepared this dough in the bread machine, then added a bit more flour and spread it into a 12' by 17' rectangle pan. I then let it rise for an additional 25 minutes, before topping and baking it. This was a pretty tasty pizza crust, but it wasn't quite what I expected. I'm still on the search for a New York style pizza crust, and am beginning to wonder if I will have to wait until my next trip to NYC to taste that yummy crust. Just a note, even though I used a very large pan this crust was really, really, think, you could probably cut it in half and make two giant 12' by 17' pizzas.  My husband gave it four stars. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I typically use a one pound frozen white bread dough cut into thirds for my pizza crust and bake on a stone.  This recipe makes more like 5 of my size and thickness pizza crusts.  Dough was sticky (probably needed more flour.)  Taste was ok -- not better or worse than the frozen dough, just different.  For the additional work this recipe is not worth it.  I am sticking with the frozen bread dough!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/168919.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this pizza recipe a few times now and it turns out great everytime.  One of these times I think I will add some basil or oregano to the flour when I make the dough for something a little different.  The last time I made the dough I split it into three and made panzerotties I think you Americans call them calzones. Roll out the dough and place the pizza toppings that you like on one half (no sauce) fold over and seal the edges well with water.  Deep fry them in a large skillet one at a time (I use my wok) carefully turn then over to brown on both sides till golden. Drain on a paper towel.  Serve with your favorite spagetti sauce.  They turned out excellent.  My family liked them even better then the ones we ordered from the pizza restaurant.  Thanks for sharing the great pizza dough recipe Jason.

text:
This pizza crust came out delicious! I added 1 tsp of Italian Seasonings and 1 tsp of Garlic Powder to the dough. I did not have a pizza stone so I used greased pie pans. I followed the instructions and I was able to make 7 personal pizza's that came out perfectly. I made 3 BBQ Chicken Pizzas, 2 Cheese Pizzas, and 2 Veggie Pizzas. The pie pans worked out great for me due to the variety I was able to make. Ordering pizza for our family of 6 costs around $20.00. Making the crust myself, plus toppings only costed me around $10.00. Everyone loved it better than the local pizza place we order from.
Another great thing is this crust did not come out with tons of grease/fat/oil. Some places when you pick up a slice of pizza, grease just oozes out of the crust. Thanks for the awesome recipe it is definantely a keeper!

text:
The first time I made this recipe I used half the dough for a medium-sized pizza and the other half for breadsticks.  Using the dough for breadsticks isn't the best, but the pizza crust was very good!  And about the stickiness:  I probably used a total of four cups flour.

I've also made this with part-whole-wheat flour, or a bit of garlic powder and dried spices (basil, oregano, thyme, marjoram, etc.) and it's VERY tasty!

However, I'm after a chewier crust, and this recipe is just nice and soft.  So I've switched to using Pizza Crust I, which is similar but more chewy.

I'm still looking for a VERY chewy/tough pizza crust...

text:
Great recipe!!!  We make it in the bread machine (I add a bit more flour so that the dough isn't too sticky) and divide the dough in half, spread the dough into two pizza pans and bake for 9 minutes at 425. We freeze the crusts so that the boys and their friends can make pizza anytime they wish.  They add the sauce and toppings and bake 10 minutes at 450.

country:
None
text:
Excellent pizza crust!  The texture is as described, "soft and doughy on the inside and slightly crusty on the outside."  I made my crust on a standard cookie sheet and found that it yielded a thick crust...kind of like a pan pizza.  I'm sure it would be different if I rolled it thinner and could make more than one crust that way if you prefer a thinner and crispier crust.  I also had to add more flour...about 4 to 4 and 1/2 cups total, which is not a criticism, I just note it so that you are not surprised if your use varies.  This recipe will replace my old tried and true pizza crust recipe.

text:
I enjoy cooking and do a fair amount of it. This crust is awesome. The only things that I did differently were...
I used filtered water for the yeast. I allowed it to rise twice. And I dressed it and cooked it for 10 minutes, then put the cheese on it to finish.  (It was cooked in a non-convection oven) 
It was fantastic... this is an example of why I use this site. In a word, wow.

text:
So, I'm in Houston, Nov 2019 and it's super humid. My girlfriend said that might be why it took me almost FIVE cups of flour to get this dough to work, and even then it was fairly sticky after rising. That said, we baked it at 475 F for about 18 min, without prebaking, and it was wonderful. We added a bit of honey to the very ends of the crust for a an extra something. Overall worked out! I would like to try it again and measure a bit more precisely.

text:
Crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. I mixed it in my stand mixer and used the bread hook to knead. left it slightly sticky as one reviewer mentioned to keep it tender. I made 2 med. pizzas from this recipe. I have a cast iron pizza stone and heated it up in a 500 oven for thirty minutes. the bottom of the crust was crisping up before I ever got all the ingredients on, so I saw no reason to precook the crust. baked for 8 minutes at 500 and it was perfect. My wife and I swear we wont order take out pizza ever again. This is so easy and far superior to take out. love it. This will be my go to from now on.

I searched for a really good pizza crust recipe forever (it seemed) but once I started using All Recipes as my go to site, I found this recipe.  I am terrible about commenting but since I am making pizza tonight, I thought this the perfect time to comment while I am waiting on the dough to rise. The ONLY thing I can comment on this that doesn't coincide with the recipe is that I split the dough and can get to large pizzas from this one recipe. text:
I've made many different pizza crusts and since this got so many good reviews, figured I'd try something different. I'm now confused about how so many people are having success with this. First of all, there was too much water for the amount of flour it says--it was basically a flour soup till I mixed in at least another cup to get it to a point where I could actually work with it. After the rise when I started to work with it, it was still too soft and started to fall apart. I salvaged enough of it to get a pizza out of it, and it was super bland. Followed everything exactly, and I'm no stranger to pizza crust. Going back to the ones that work for me.

amy w

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a lovely pizza dough recipe. I've made it several times exactly per the recipe. More recently, I've been adding a bit of corn meal to the dough (maybe 1/4 cup? I don't measure, just pour a bit in), as well as sprinkling corn meal on the pizza stone before cooking. I also pre-cook the crust for 15 minutes or so before topping. I love this. Also, when I'm feeling extra lazy, I don't even knead, but just mix it thoroughly with a wooden spoon in the bowl, then let it rise. This works great too. I'll also note, after reading the comments of some other folks here: really, it does not have to be that complicated (squeezing into balls and refrigerating for hours and more balling and  . . . ) to be delicious. Pizza crust is a flat dough. 

Really, you almost can't mess up this recipe. Try it!

userID:
24355096
Display Name:
Aaron
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great Pizza Crust and will make again.  I modified the procedures when I made it the second time and it cam out even better.  steps below

1.	In a large bowl, dissolve the yeast and brown sugar in the water, and let sit for 10 minutes.
2.	Stir the salt and oil into the yeast solution. Mix in 2 1/2 cups of the flour.
3.	Note if using a mixer and dough hook add the remaining flour as it mixes. And skip step 4
4.	Turn dough out onto a clean, well floured surface, and knead in more flour until the dough is no longer sticky. 
5.	Place the dough into a well oiled bowl, and cover with a cloth. Let the dough rise until double; this should take about 1 hour. Punch down the dough, and form a tight ball. Allow the dough to relax for a minute before rolling out. 
6.	Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
7.	 If you are baking the dough on a pizza stone, place dough on to a well oiled stone (I Use Olive Oil on a 15” stone using all the dough) you may place your toppings on the dough, and bake immediately. Or prebake the crust for 5-7 minutes, Then place topping on dough.(makes a less soggy crust) and bake till done
8.	If you are baking your pizza in a pan, lightly oil the pan, and let the dough rise for 15 or 20 minutes before topping and baking it.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-10-07T02:26:31.913

text:
Great pizza dough! I halved the recipe and it made a personal pan stuffed crust pizza that I was very satisfied with. I didn't have a pizza stone, so I broiled the dough for 5 minutes on the bottom rack in a normal cooking pot to give it shape and to melt the mozzarella pearls I stuffed the sides of the crust with. I added my bbq base, cheese, toppings, more cheese, and broiled again for 6-7 minutes. The bottom of the crust was slightly browned and absolutely perfect amount of crunch to chewy ratio. I must say, this was my first time making dough at home and overall it turned out great even for a beginner. Next time I'll make some garlic butter to brush on the sides of the crust before I put it back in the oven! Delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This calls for regular all purpose flour, when pizza dough most definitely needs "Bread Flour".  Pizza dough need the elasticity of the extra gluten in the bread flour that the all purpose flour does not have.  The flavour is weaker with the APF too.  Brown sugar just gives it a weird after taste. Use white sugar for a more authentic Italian taste. Also this crust was a little ...bland. You could try adding spices to the dough. Like Oregano, Sweet Basil and/or garlic powder.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-09-01T02:16:03.087
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
14324333
Display Name:
Nicole Faughnan
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
44
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4841313.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it as-is many a times now. Adjusted to my family’s liking. While we do not like thin crust but they do not want super thick crust(which I love! But it is supper time and it is not about what MOM wants) , we found a simple medium. 
Make the recipe exactly, let rise 1hr. Punch down, divide in 2 equal halves(you can use a scale to get them exact). 
let the two rest for a minute before rolling out. once rolled out and on a butter greased pan rest about 5 min. 
I have never pre-baked, and this has worked perfect.  425 for 25 min. (ovens can vary) 
at the 20 min my timer goes so I can brush my salty garlic butter along the crust and a tiny bit on toppings, but mostly crust. Take out in 5 min. and your family will NEVER want take out pizza again.

text:
I've made this twice now, the first time exactly as written, and the second time I used 1/2 tablespoon of brown sugar instead of the instructed 1/2 teaspoon (because it seemed like a typo), more flour and then grilled it. IMHO, this dough is too sticky to easily work with. I probably added a little over 4 cups of flour and it was still sticking to my hands, my peel, etc. I didn't really notice a difference with the sugar, and it grilled just fine, once I got it off of the pizza peel.

All that said, when it is finished cooking, it's pretty decent. Or at least the grilled version was. The first batch that I made I did half in a cast iron skillet and half on a pizza stone. The pizza stone version kind of sucked, but the skillet version wasn't too bad. When I tried it again, the grilled version was unanimously the winner. I'm going to keep searching for our ultimate pizza crust, though.

Soft, light and fluffy pizza crust! Followed the recipe as described (used 3 1/2 cups of flour/ dough was still sticky). After an hour of rising I split the dough in half and rolled it out onto two 13"x9" baking sheets. Gave the dough another 20 minutes of rest before I topped it. Baked at 425F on the lowest oven rack for 18 minutes.

country:

text:
I  absolutely love this crust,  the only thing I did differently was to preheat my oven to 170 degrees F and put a small pan of water on the bottom rack .  It cut the proofing time in half.  I removed it from the oven, punched it once in middle, waited a couple minutes and then stretched it out on my baking sheet.  Let it sit another 15 minutes and then put on my sauce and toppings.  I let it bake at 425 for 12 minutes and then took the pizza off of the baking pan and let it cook the last few minutes directly on the rack.  It was perfect.

False
followersCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3107596.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made a couple of the pizza crusts on here, and I love this one! I followed others' advice to bake it a little bit if not using a pizza stone, before putting toppings on. I didn't roll the dough out with a rolling pin, but did "hand tossed" like I used to when I worked in a pizza restaraunt (basically just stretched it into a vaguely circular shape). That way the edges of the crust was thicker and the part under the toppings were thinner. And then I brushed some melted butter on the edges and sprinkled garlic salt. Had enough dough for two pizzas! Loved it! And I ordinarily am not a great chef so if I can do it, anyone should be able to lol

text:
This has been my go-to pizza dough recipe for years, but I've never been able to make it with less than 3 3/4 cups of flour - 3 1/3 is just too wet. 
Sometimes I sub in a cup of sourdough starter for a cup of the water; and I either sub the sugar with maple syrup or eliminate it.  For two of us, I get three 12" pizzas.

text:
I've made this recipe many, MANY times now and we love it. I use half the dough and freeze the other half. Half the dough makes a large thin crust. I spread the dough and assemble the pizza on a large piece of parchment paper, then place it (with help) on a cast iron pizza pan that has been preheating along with the oven. I cook it right on the parchment paper. It doesn't stick, no oil required. Makes a nice crisp yet chewy crust. Clean up is easy too.

Display Name:
Erin Sheldon

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My kids liked this crust without any changes. I found the dough easy to work with and the texture was fine, but the flavour was unremarkable. The second time we made it, I took other reviewer suggestions. I substituted garlic- and basil-infused oil for the olive oil, added about 2 t of finely ground herbs (I have oregano, rosemary, and red chili in a spice grinder), and substituted 1 c whole wheat flour and 1 c of a 12 grain mix for some of the flour. My kids actually liked this one just as much and we thought the crust was divine. We have used these crusts to make everything from cheese and pepperoni pizza, to spreading the crust with Chef John's artichoke-spinach dip and adding goat cheese and green olive tapenade! My review is 4 stars as the recipe is written and 5 stars with added seasonings for flavour.
Review:
Rating:
4

text:
Alerted by reviews complaining that they got a too sticky or even liquid dough and then had to add a lot of flour to get it right, I started by mixing the dry ingredients (flour, yeast, brown sugar and salt), and only then added the oil and, gradually, the water. So I got the right consistency. I have no complaints about the taste. Just very decent pizza.

text:
I made this dough into calzones (with ham, ricotta and mozzarella).  It came out pretty good - 3 nice sized calzones, which is exactly what we needed.  I only had bread machine yeast on hand, and followed directions to add the yeast to dry ingredients (on yeast jar) rather than to the liquid directly.  Followed the rest of the instructions, but noticed that the dough is very sticky and wet.  I used way more than the 3 1/3 cups of flour called for.  It rose just fine, but was very hard to roll out due to the stickiness.  Possibly I didn't knead long enough?  I felt like maybe it needed a bit more salt for taste, but my husband and daughter liked it as is.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First off, there is one big mistake in the directions/ingredients - just which amount of flour do you use?  I used more than the 3 and 1/3 cup of flour called for in this recipe.  I ended up adding about a 1/3 cup more to my bread machine (why do all the work when it will for you?).  I also added more yeast as my old bread machine needs it.  Even with the 1/3 cup additional flour, I was not happy with how it mixed in the machine.  It was very sticky.  The stickiness continued out of the machine and I needed about another 1/3rd cup of flour or so to roll this crust out.  After getting it rolled out, the problems stopped for me. I normally make the pizzas, then refrigerate for a few hours before baking.  Just allow 20 minutes or so for the pizza to warm up some before baking.  It baked up beautifully and was tender.  It was a nice change of pace from our normal crust recipe.  We will use this recipe again, but start with 3.5 cups of flour in the bread machine and reduce the liquid to 1 and 1/3rd cup (what my machine recommends for that amount of flour).

text:
Great Dough! I too tried and failed at my first attempt as some others may have done,but I figured out the problem . My crust came out tough and didn't brown right and just came out terrible so all I did was 1. Make sure my temp on the water was 110 Degrees and 2. I let my dough rise TWICE! Yup I let it rise for an hour and then punched it down and let it rise for another hour and voila! Turned out perfect !

text:
Best pizza crust recipe I've found! I like it handmade and as is, BUT I like it better made in my bread maker adding: 1) chopped fresh garlic and garlic powder; 2) chopped onion/onion powder; 3) 1+ Tbsp. Italian seasoning; 4) 1 tsp. vital wheat gluten for each cup of flour. *Always oil and pre-cook before adding toppings, or they soak through!**I've been making this for years, and I've always needed 4 cups of flour, so now I just start with that.  Thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great Dough! After Reading A Couple Reviews, I Added 1/2 Tsp Of Sugar, 1 Clove Garlic Minced, 2 Tsp Basil To Dough. Also, I Followed The First Step By Lettting Yeast, Sugar And Water Sit For 10 Minutes . Then Added Salt & Flour, Put In My Bread Machine With The Setting For Dough. Slowly Added A Cup Of Flour. I Noticed The Flour Was Collecting On The Sides Of Pan So, I Added A Tiny bit  Of Olive Oil. Lastly After The Dough Sat For An Hour, I Put Olive Oil In My Cast Iron Skillets , Tossed My Pizza Dough (3 Small Pizzas), Placed Dough In Skillet Added A Small Amount Of Butter On The Crust And A Tiny Bit Of Garlic Powder. Cooked Dough For 10 Mins Then Added Sauce And Toppings. Will make this recipe again.

text:
A pizza crust recipe review is a tough one since everyone could have a different preference in crust style and if it doesn't meet expectations, the reviews reflect it. I was looking forward to a great pizza crust. But this recipe is only okay. If your looking for a bready crust similar to a pan pizza crust at Pizza Hut this is it (I'd rate 4-stars). But I'm looking for a crust that forms a hard crust shell and dense chewy inside. This is not it, thus 3-Stars.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to pizza crust recipe, I must have made it a dozen times, and I am getting better at it every time. The recipe is big though, I make two or three round pizzas from the amount (although I do always at least double it because for some reason every time I make pizza, someone come over and a single dough wouldn't be enough). I don't pre-bake, but I let each rolled dough rise for a good half hour before filling. I sprinkle the cheese on top just for the last five minutes so that the crust gets some colour before the cheese burns. I also use a little more salt in the dough.

Fantastic! Finally found the chewy, crunchy pizza base I've been looking for:) The dough was quite sticky so, as I was kneading, I added more flour. text:
This was okay/good.  It was crispy on the outside and soft on the inside as others have stated.  It held up nicely to the toppings.  To me, it needed more flavor.  It did remind me a little of pizza hut crust, so if that is favorite this is a good recipe to try.  The plusses are that it was easy to make and much better than any store bought product.  I followed the recipe as written and did not make any changes.  Technically it was a success.  It just wasn't my taste preference. If you are going for pizza hut flavor, brush the ends with melted butter.  It is hard to please everyone, especially when it comes to pizza!  Thank you Jay for taking the time to share your recipe with us!

This is my staple for all pizza, pizza rolls or calzone! It will stretch out for a nice thin crust or let rise again on the pizza pan for a good thick crust! I prefer to use filtered water.

text:
This was my first time making fresh dough, so I'm glad this was a popular recipe, because the video was handy and I had to watch it twice. I did add 1 full teaspoon of brown sugar, but I followed the directions, otherwise, and the result was delicious. The recipe yielded two dough balls; one of which I froze, the other made a large calzone. I brushed the inside with a butter garlic sauce and filled with ham, peppers, onions, mushrooms, and white cheddar. I also brushed the top with butter garlic sauce and baked at 425° for 20 minutes, dropped it down to 375° and cooked for an additional 10 minutes. This gave me a tender inside and crispy bottom. Thank you for sharing!

country:
None
text:
This was my first from scratch attempt at pizza crust, and it was fabulous!  I learned from reading reviews how I could make the dough in my stand mixer, then I added a little garlic and some Italian spice to the dough.  I don't have a pizza stone, so I preheated my USA Pan and put the dough on that once the oven was hot.  I baked the dough alone for ten minutes, then removed it to brush on olive oil with garlic powder.  After that I added my toppings and baked for ten minutes more.  I always thought of homemade pizza as being an absolute last resort, an opinion probably shaped by those familiar pizza kits I had as a kid, the ones with the envelope of powdered cheese.  This has made homemade as good - or better - than restaurant pizza.  And it was so simple!  Thanks for sharing your recipe, Jay!

text:
This was a really easy recipe. I made this for my boyfriend and myself. He was really impressed. This recipe can easily serve four people if you have sides with the meal (we had salads). It tasted similar to pizza hut's pizza crust minus all the messy grease. Since I put mozzarella in the edges to make a stuffed crust, I baked it for 8 minutes prior to adding the toppings. I knew I wanted a lot of veggie toppings, so it also provided peace of mind knowing the middle would be cooked. I cooked it for 20 minutes after adding toppings. The crust came out wonderfully crispy on the outside and doughy (but cooked!) on the inside. I will most likely make this again, but maybe adding garlic powder and cornmeal next time.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This crust was so much better than the last one we tried (which had equally good ratings), so maybe pizza crust is just really subjective.  Using the amount of flour given, the dough is so sticky as to be nearly impossible to handle.  I had to keep adding more and more flour, and am guessing I used between four and five cups total.  Once the crust was at the "not sticky" point, the texture was perfect  though.

Because so much flour was needed, we ended up with a really thick crust, like Sicilian.  I should have saved or discarded a bit, not gone ahead and used it all.  The edges didn't get as brown as I'd have liked, but the crust was fluffy and light.  It's not the most flavorful, but the crust doesn't doesn't compete with the sauce and toppings.

My husband and kids devoured the pizza, even my kid that doesn't care much for pizza, so this will be our recipe from now on.

country:
None
text:
I have made this crust numerous times. My family and friends love it! It's one of, if not the best, pizza crust I've made! Turns out great every time. Couple of things I do differently are adding a tablespoon of honey, an extra half teaspoon of salt (so I use 1 teaspoon and 1/2) and a teaspoon of brown sugar instead of 1/2 a teaspoon. Also, once the crust is rolled out, I melt butter, adding garlic powder and salt to it. Then, I brush it on the edges of the pizza crust. The crust is so tasty and flavorful that way.  Excellent recipe!

text:
First time making pizza, turned out just how I like it. My 2 year old and husband both loved it. I used a baking tray oiled and put pizza dough in middle of oven for 10 mins before adding toppings. I added a LOT more flour  than it said to get it to the right doughiness. Next time I will probably just add the flour to the bowl and keep mixing with a wooden spoon until it looks right, it was too sticky with the quantity of flour in the recipe. I will be making this again for sure. My husband has already requested it at least once a week! We never buy pizza from the supermarket because we dont like them, I had bought bases ready made and added topping when my 2 year old was about one to give her different food but havnt done that for a while so really pleased with this recipe. DELICIOUS. Thanks. Ps my husband says 11/10 :)

text:
A superb pizza crust! I have not ever made pizza dough before so made the recipe exactly as directed. This recipe was just the one for a beginner like me! My dough rose as described in the recipe - i placed the bowl in front of the oven vent while i was preheating the oven and it doubled in size as described in the recipe

I was not making a pizza in the true sense of the word. i divided the dough in half and rolled it out to about 1/4 inch thick, then cut the dough into 5 circles using a plastic cereal bowl. 

I then topped half of each circle with my homemade sloppy joe mix! You can see the recipe in my recipe box!

text:
The good: The taste of the crust was pretty good.  It could have been more moist, though.  It was also much thicker than I thought it would be--hence after putting on sauce and toppings it was tough to cook through.  If I use this again, I would either cut the recipe in half for one pizza OR pre-bake the crust a while before adding toppings.  Even after baking for more like 25-30 minutes on my pizza stone the crust was still doughy in the middle.

text:
This was great! I've never made pizza dough before and at first I wasn't sure I followed the directions correctly. In the beginning the dough was very gooey and didn't look like what I thought pizza dough should look like until I added more flour. I let my standing mixer with dough hook do the kneading for me. My husband and I love this recipe! I've tweaked it a bit as I keep using the recipe.I use abt 2-3 teaspoons of brown sugar. Also, we bake the crust in the pan for abt 8 min before putting the sauce and other ingredients on. This makes the crust rise a little and also gives it a little crispness.

It is good recipe.  Maybe it could of cooked just a bit longer.  I made two pizzas about 12" instead of one very large.  Pizza #2 just came out of the oven.  I let it cook 16 minutes or so. userID:
755603
Display Name:
AMMSEJS
isPro:

166

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/306771.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YOU DO NOT NEED TO LET THE DOUGH RISE FOR AN HOUR!! Just make the dough, spread it in the greased pan, and bake the crust for about 10 or 15 minutes before adding the topping (I bake it at 375 or 400 degrees) ,THE CRUST RISES WHILE BAKING, then take out ( the crust will be light with maybe some slight browning around the edges or underneath at this point), add the toppings and pop back in the oven until the cheese is melted and cooked to your liking. I add some seasonings to the crust dough: seasoned salt, oregano, garlic powder, onion powder, and a little cumin, and I put the oven on broil right before taking the pizza out of the oven to get the cheese nice and bubbly. My daughter and I made this for the guys during their football game and all really enjoyed!

userID:
5839772
Display Name:
quinna

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent.  I used 1/2 C all purpose flour and 1 1/2 C whole wheat flour for the 2 1/2 C all purpose flour the recipe instructed to be mixed with the yeast/water/oil/salt. I used very little additional flour (maybe only another 1/4 to 1/3 C) during the kneading and rolling steps. This dough was so easy to mix and knead, I can't imagine why anyone would want to bother using a mixer.  Following the instructions, I let it the dough stand about 15 minutes before I added the toppings. I baked it on a 10" x 15" cookie sheet in the middle of the oven. I did not have a problem with sogginess in the middle of the pizza like other reviewers.  I don't usually like thick crust pizza because it is so heavy and overly filling, but this crust had a light texture inside and a nice crustiness outside. This recipe is a keeper.

text:
This is now our favorite pizza ever.  We loved it more than take out pizza.  The only thing I did different was added a little Italian Seasoning to the dough and cut about a 1/4 off of the main dough to make bread sticks.  I baked in a very olive oiled 9x13 for 10 minutes with minced garlic and a little more Italian Seasoning.  After that I added my sauce, cheese and mushrooms and a little more olive oil around the edges of crust and baked 15 more minutes.  PERFECT!!!  I think the minced garlic really gave it the perfect taste.

text:
This was my first pizza dough creation and it was ohhh so delicious. I will say that if you aren't baking on a pizza stone, DO grease your pan. We split the dough into two and made two smaller pizzas.  Our kids put the topping they wanted on theirs and the adult one was loaded down with toppings. The kids pizza took 15 min to bake to a crispy bottom with a soft chewy crust and the adult pizza took the full 20 min to get done. This recipe was so easy and just perfect crust. I think we will be enjoying homemade pizza more often at this house! I wouldn't compare to any delivery chains crust. This had more of a higher taste quality. Thanks!!!

userID:
2877309
Display Name:
KnitOn
isPro:
False

50

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yep.  I'm a fan!  And I was skeptical at first.  This recipe is very similar to my former favorite pizza dough recipe.  In our house, we have Friday Night Pizza and a Movie Night and we make homemade pizza.  We've been doing this for about 5yrs now!!  Lots of pizza!! I already had my old recipe memorized and we liked it - but after reading all the raves, I gave this one a try!  Glad I did!!

Crispy outside, tender inside. Its delicious.  I add garlic powder for additional flavor.  This recipe doubles well.  I use my KitchenAid for the mixing and kneading with the dough hook, but give it a final knead by hand.  It practically makes itself that way! Also, I preheat the oven to at least 500deg with my pizza stones on the lowest rack.  Transfer your pizza with the toppings on to the preheated stone.  In the summer, we like to grill our pizza with fresh veggies and a sprinkling of cheese! Don't forget the cornmeal for ease of sliding the crust around and for extra crunch on the bottom (no flour).

text:
Loved it! I did do as suggested and added 1 tsp of salt and an additional 1/2 tsp of brown sugar bringing that to 1 tsp. I used my kitchenaid mixer with a dough hook and went ahead and added 3 cups of flour to start...then added until it became thick enough to move to a floured board and that was maybe an additional 1/2 to 3/4 cup of flour? I only moved to the board the dough to the board so that I could oil the mixer bowl and put the dough back in. (no need in making two bowls dirty)...I used the quick rise yeast and I think 30 minutes was all it took to double. The crust was soft and yet had a crunchy texture. My husband definitely agreed in using this recipe again! Thanks so much for sharing! It was definitely easy to make! :)

Update: 6/7/14 I used this exact recipe to make the bread for Bierocks. Perfect! The bread was perfect for this recipe and so quick to make! I cut it into 12 pieces and rolled them out like mini pizzas to put the filling in...then put in oven at 425 for 10 minutes. Can't say enough good things about it! Will keep this as my go to recipe for that too!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic.  I proofed mine in my oven for the first rise, just turned it on as low as it will go and propped the door open a couple inches.  This cuts the rise time down to about half.  I also used milk for about 2/3 of the water called for at the beginning of the recipe.  I just like a little milk in my bread, I think my yeast tends to work better with it.  When I transferred it onto my pizza pan, I poked a few holes in the bottom with a fork to keep it from rising too much during baking.  I didn't do the 2nd rise or a pizza stone, and it turned out great.

text:
Good dough, but definitely needed some seasoning.  It was perfect texture, but pretty bland.  I added a packet of Italian seasoning.  Next time, I might throw in more sugar and salt.  The recipe was fairly easy to make.  Dough was very sticky and took quite a lot of flour to work into stiffness.  I don't have a pizza stone, so I followed the advice of other reviewers and let the dough bake for 10 minutes before adding cheese and sauce topping (no meat).  Baked for another 10 and was done.  We really enjoyed the pizza, mostly for the toppings and the freshness.  The crust on it's own was just OK.  This would be a great base recipe to keep on hand for making fresh breadsticks!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This pizza dough is perfection! I was very nervous because it was my first attempt at baking any type of bread. I have always been too terrified to try anything requiring yeast! But I got a fancy KA stand mixer for Christmas along with the dough hook, and our basil plant was in need of picking, so I decided to try making a pesto pizza. It was EXCELLENT. After reading reviews, I added a bit of extra salt and some parsley and oregano to the dough. Pre-baked for 10 mins on my pizza tray, added my homemade pesto and some fresh spinach, tomatoes, mushrooms, onions and peppers. Turned out incredibly delicious and super easy! Will be making this again and again. My six year old niece gobbled it up (she had her own small pepperoni pizza, of course!)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best recipe yet for Pizza. First I used 1 tsp of brown sugar, made sure my water was 110 degree's for yeast and sugar. I used my mixer and stand with a dough hook. after the 2 1/2 cups of flour I added another 1/2 cup to the mixer, dumped it on my floured counter....
I used another 1/2 to whole cup of flour as kneading the dough.
The dough will still be a little sticky but that's okay.
I used a non stick pan sprayed with a little olive oil.
I also brushed a a little oil on the dough before pre baking.
I pre baked the crust for 5 minutes and when i i took it out I brushed the outter crust with melted butter and minced garlic then added my sauce & toppings, baked for another 12 minutes and it was great....I got 2 meduim pizza's out of the recipe. 
Perfect

text:
Having grown up outside of NYC and living in NYC for almost 25 years I know good pizza.  When I moved to PA I couldn't find a good pizza so I had to learn to make my own.  This was the first recipe I tried and I wasn't disappointed.  This makes a crust better than many NYC pizzarias.  I've played with it a bit like adding whole wheat flour, gluten, honey, various spices and it always turns out great.  It's just a matter of what I'm in the mood for at the time.  I'm making it again tomorrow night and I'll be making a whole wheat crust with some basil and garlic, with of course pizza sauce and mozzarella topped with pepperoni, more garlic, mushrooms and broccoli.  I'm salivating just reading this because I know it's going to be great.  This crust always turns out well.  Should I try some bread flour instead of regular flour?  Do I want to take the risk?  Hey, why not.  This crust is so easy to make in the bread machine, if it doesn't turn out well I'll just make another batch.

Ok, I've tried this with bread flour and instead of water I use milk.  I cook it on a pizza stone.  The crust is crispy on the bottom but the rest is tender.  The taste is great and I won't make it any other way anymore.  My friends in PA are telling me to open my own pizzeria.  As I said before, the pizza in this part of PA leaves a lot to be desired.  I tell them if they wan't great pizza any time they want, to move to NYC.  Now all I need is a great pizza sauce recipe.  Any suggestions?

Excellent pizza crust! I took others suggestion and used 1 1/2 tsp salt and 1 tsp brown sugar. It easily made 2 pizza crusts. I made 1 pizza a pan pizza by coating a cast iron skillet with vegetable oil and heating in the  oven until hot then putting the dough in while the skillet was still hot, then put back in the oven and baked the 15-20 minutes suggested! It made a nice crisp crust. Yum!

I use this recipe at least once a week for pizza. I choose to use OO flour from Italy. The recipe makes enough for 2 large super thin rectangular pizzas. It helps to actually take the temp of the water before adding the yeast to ensure good activation. I let the dough rise in a slightly warmed oven for one hour prior to rolling out.

text:
I enjoyed this recipe.  I was looking for a crust that was a little bit crispy and this one delivered.  I halved the recipe to make one pizza and it was just the right thickness.  I baked the crust slightly before adding my toppings. As some of the other reviewers said this crust didn't turn a golden brown when baked.  I used this crust recipe and the beer pizza recipe from this site for the sauce.  It was a great combination and I would have it again.

Display Name:
SillyMonkey

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/509146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I made two small/medium sized pizza's from this pizza dough recipe. Oooooh man did it turn out AWESOME! Like some other reviewers suggested I prebaked my pizza dough. I rolled it out as best as I could (1st time) and as thin as I could because we both really love thin crust pizza's. Then placed it on a pizza stone with lots of corn flour, I think we only baked the pizza dough for 10-15 mins each, just enough so it was firm and not dough like anymore. Then we flipped over the cooled pizza crust and put all of our sauces and topping on it, then placed back onto the pizza stone, and cooked for remaining time,..sorry foget how long I baked for. It tuned out awesome though. I was a little worried about the pizza tuning out soggy with all the sauce and ingredients on the raw dough before baking, but this way worked out perfectly!

text:
I made this tonight without alteration. The dough itself turned out well. I sometimes do not have success with dough. The taste though, was a bit bland though. My husband enjoys flavorful crust and this didn't have it. I made this into two pizzas. I made a small one for my son and one for the Mommy and Daddy because my son likes plain old boring pizza and we don't. I wanted this crust to be thinner, as well. Next time I will add herbs and seasonings to the crust and discard a portion of the dough so my crust can come out thinner next time. All in all, this recipe yielded a nice dough and wasn't hard to work with, but the flavor is only 'meh.'

text:
I made this recipe gluten free by replacing the flour with Bob's Red Mill all purpose baking mix and about a tsp of xanthan gum- It came together wonderfully. I didn't measure the amount of flour I used, I added to the right consistancy, but it was under the 3.5 cups. The dough rose beautifully and rolled out easily, but it did stay a little flat through baking. It's not the best GF pizza dough I've made, but it is a really solid foundation. I'm going to work with it a bit more to get a bread-ier type feel.

userID:

Display Name:
Lisa Pontell
isPro:

followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
39
favoritesCount:
86
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6837591.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Only add enough flour while mixing with dough hook until poked with index finger -the dough feels like chewing gum.  This  is the best advice I can give and helped me tremendously.  Leaving at room temp in a plastic bag coated with oil for 3-5 hours- punch down occassionally.  I use fresh yeast because it is what I have on hand but convert measure by googling.  You may have to use more salt to taste  and more flour.  Made in a small stand mixer with dough hook and went 5 min med low speed.   Not as easy as it seems to make great pizza dough.  Also great flour really helps.

text:
I had a problem with this recipe.  I haven't made a pizza crust in several years so thought I'd try a new recipe.  I doubled the recipe, but it didn't rise after sitting for an hour.  It was still extremely sticky when I poured it out to knead - almost still a liquid.  I used a stone, so I didn't pre-bake the crust and the final pizza came out too doughy and dense.  Almost like a pie crust that didn't get cooked all the way through.  I'm going to have to keep playing with this recipe till it comes out right.

Really nice. My family prefers a paper thin crisp crust and even though I rolled this thin, it was still *slightly* doughy for the hubs. This is a winner though with the addition of parsley and italian spices, garlic powder. I whirled raw garlic in the chopper with oil and spread that right on the par baked crust, topped with fresh basil, smashed tomatoes and mozzarella. I doubled the recipe and will use the other half tomorrow for some lovely creation or another. Calzone maybe? This dough would work well for that.

country:
None
text:
This is my new favorite pizza dough recipe!  I use all whole wheat flour and make it in my KitchenAid mixer with the dough hook and let it knead the dough for about 15 minutes.  The dough is definitely stickier than my old recipe but I just oil my hands well with olive oil when I spread out the dough.  It's easy to work with; it's not elastic like some other pizza dough I've tried so you don't have to worry about it shrinking once it's spread out in the pan.  I make 3 12inch pizza's on pizza stones and it always turns out perfect!

userID:
6346026
Display Name:
Phanes
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The crust can make or break a pizza.  A bland (unsalted) crust makes an entire pizza taste like paper towels.  And a crust that is thick but too dense also makes for an unpleasant crust.

I like both thick and thin crusts, but I've been trying to "perfect" a thick crust pizza.  The recipe I had been using used only one cup of warm water and a quarter-cup of olive oil (I sometimes use butter instead) to 3.5 cups of flour and 2 tablespoons of yeast.  That resulted in a dough that was barely moist enough to hold together and it felt quite leathery.  If I rolled it out thin enough, it made a halfway decent thin crust, but a very dense thick crust.

I then increased the water to 1.25 cups and kept 2 tablespoons of yeast.  That was better, but still not good enough.  I then increased the water to 1.5 cups, yeast to 3 tablespoons, and then 3.5 cups of flour, about 1.5 tablespoons of salt, and a tablespoon of sugar (all ingredients prepared correctly, of course, like dissolving yeast with sugar, waiting 10-15 minutes, etc...)  Anyway, that dough TRIPLED in size!  I had it in a lighted, slightly warmed oven with a damp towel over the top of the bowl.  I came back an hour and fifteen minutes and the dough was sticking to the towel.  It was a quivering mess, like a bowl of wheat Jell-O, but when I manage to flop it into an appropriate size onto a pizza pan, it has made the best crust of any pizza I've ever made so far.  I plan to try 1.5 cups with 2 tbsp of yeast next.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-10-03T09:03:47.39
helpfulCount:

AWESOME crust. I was pleasantly surprised by how much this crust was enjoyed, given the simplicity. I did have to use white sugar, as I am out of brown, but I doubt it made a difference. I also divided the dough and made 2 crusts- next time I'll be doubling the recipe instead!

I will make this time and time again!
Thanks for sharing.

this recipe is absoulutely awesome! i took other reviewers advice:) i used garlic salt in place of salt and also added italian seasoning:) also i only needed the 2 1/2 cups of flour and just turned it onto very well floured counter:) i also used olive oil for the rising in the bowl. i made 1 large and 1 smaller pizza i pre-cooked the the larger 8 minutes. the large one after topped off took 10 minutes to cook. the other 1 im waiting to finish baking:) thank u so much for such an awesome recipe!it was so easy! i was concerned after reading the not so great reat reviews but am so happy i went ahead and tried it!

text:
This crust was delicious! It did remind me a lot of Pizza Huts pan crust. I just halved the recipe and it turned out great. I followed some of the other reviewers and prebaked it about 15 minutes before putting the sauce and toppings on.I baked mine on a round cookie sheet which I greased then lightly sprinked with cornmeal.I baked it on the lower rack and it only took about 15 minutes after putting all the toppings on.My pizza turned out delicious and I will definately use this recipe again. I don't think I'll be ordering from Pizza Hut anytime soon..I liked my pizza better!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is hands down the best pizza crust recipe I've tried! Crispy on the outside, chewy on the inside.  I used 2 metal pan, greased and sprinkled with corn meal.  I allowed the crust to rise the additional 15 minutes after I spread it in the pans.  Added sauce, cheese and toppings (NO prebaking) and put them in the mid/lower part of the oven (the one on the bottom rack was crispier).  They not only tasted fantastic, but looked professional!  They rose beautifully and came out just perfect.  This is it!  The search is over!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't know what made me enjoy this better--the taste or the excitement of making my first pizza dough from scratch.  This was a very simple and easy to follow recipe.  I did end up using more than 3 1/2 cups of flour, but I followed the directions and added flour until the dough was no longer sticky.  I created two small pizza crusts and cooked them on the grill.  I find it cooks faster on the grill and creates a nice, crispy crust just as I like.  I'll never use the canned pizza crust again.  Plus, this was so cheap!  I would allow myself a good two hours before planning on cooking the dough as it took longer to rise than an hour.  But I'm convinced this is the best way to make pizza at home.

region:

country:
None
text:
So I've made this pizza crust recipe at least 10 times since finding it on here, and it has never ever failed me yet. I like to crush up some garlic, mix it with a bit of oil and brush it all over, especially on the crust. It always turns out fantastic, and is chewy and crispy the next day, even out of the microwave! You have to try this recipe!  I've rolled these into calzones as well, and they turned out marvelous.  Here's a tip - double the recipe, set half aside. When it's risen, follow the directions, but roll it out in an even shape and bake it with cheese on top. Makes some awesome breadsticks! Very versatile dough. Thanks!

While my crust wasn't crispy on the outside, like so many experienced, the flavor was really wonderful and...bready.  The lack of crunch may well be the fact  that I used a pizza stone.  In any case, if you like a flavorful, chewy, soft crust, this one will do it for you in spades.  It makes a lot, compared with some dough recipes.  For my 15" round stone, it made a full, fairly thick crust.

text:
Wow! I've tried many homemade pizza crusts over the years, but this is the best and easiest one yet.  I increased the brown sugar to 1 Tbsp. and added a shake of garlic with the salt and oil.  We like a thin crispy crust so I got two large pizzas from this recipe.  I used olive oil to grease my pans and sprinkled with yellow cornmeal.  I baked at 400 in my convection oven.  My family loves this crust.  Thanks Jay!

text:
I only rated this 5 stars because more weren't available!  What a great crust - quick, easy to work with, and most of all, delicious.  I make the basic crust as Jay described - or I will play with it.  I haven't had a failure yet.  The only permanent change that I have made in the recipe is the use of malt extract instead of brown sugar.  I use malt (from beer brewing) for the sugar in all of my baking because I like the more complex flavor it gives.  Thank you, Jay.  This is truely a great recipe.

country:
None
text:
Excellent crust.  I like to freeze half in saran wrap (I've found it works better then wax paper).  I let it rise and then punch it down and split it.  One half goes right into the oven for about 15 minutes as a prebake before toppings - I've found this just makes a better crust for our taste.  I use a deep dish ceramic pie dish.  The other half goes right into (tightly wrapped) freezer bag and into the freezer.

I love this recipe. I have been lurking on here for months and this recipe made me join just so I could write this review. I changed nothing and cooked two pizzas in 9 inch cake pans.I realize that I could have made at least 4 of the same pizzas had I spread the dough a little thinner. This will be staple recipe in our house no more spending money at the HUT. Thank you so much for sharing.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/324415.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It is a great crust, crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside.  Our guests loved it.  We made mini-pizzas on the grill.  I preheated the grill on high and rubbed the grate with veg. oil.  Be sure to make each pizza just prior to tossing on the grill.  They tend to become sticky when they sit.  I grilled each for a couple minutes on one side.  Then we took them off the grill, put (minimal) sauce and toppings on the grilled side, and placed them back on the grill to melt the cheese.  Used with "Unbelievably Awesome Barbeque Chicken" recipe, also on this site.

text:
This pizza crust is delicious!  I love making my own dough and I was really impressed by how well this dough turned out.  Beware, this does make one giant pizza crust, but I like to divide the dough into two smaller pizzas.  This way the dough cooks faster without the cheese overcooking.  I even added some whole wheat flour to this dough and it still turned out delicious!  I recommend this crust to everyone.

text:
I make my pizzas pretty thin, and this dough is fantastic. It's easy to make, tastes great, rolls out easily, rises well in the oven, and the crust tastes wonderful.  This is the first time I've had pizza crust taste so good.  It is important to brush the crust with olive oil at least twice: once before you put it into the oven and once again 1/2 way through.

text:
I love this recipe.  I always hated making pizza dough before (Lucky when I was in college a local bakery sold it premade) because of the smell of the yeast.  This mixes up without the excessive yeast smell, cooks just perfect on a Pizzazz pizza cooker and other then the time allowing it to raise doesn't take a large amount of time.  My only regret is not reading the reviews before I made it.  It really does make a very large pizza, 1/3 to 1/2 is enough for me.  Now I can have a homemade pizza with fresh toppings for less then half the cost of a premium frozen pizza and it tastes a lot better.  Thank you!

Very good pizza crust. I cut the amount of yeast required in half (for a thinner crust) and added 1 teaspoon of soy lecithin for better mixing. It didn't rock my socks off, but it was a decent homemade pizza crust. The main downside was that there was not a lot of bubble definition in the cooked crust, even with a pizza stone.

country:
None
text:
I give it 5 stars for taste and 3 for ease to work with, so an average of 4 stars.  I upped the recipe to 20 servings so it would make 2 large pizzas.  I also made mine in my bread machine.  It mixed up well but the dough was very sticky and I ended up having to mix in quite a bit more flour to make it workable.  Now I use 1 3/4 cups of water as opposed to the 2 cups called for in the 20 serving recipe and that helps.  I have still had to add in a bit more flour but not nearly as much, I could probably cut back a bit more on the water.  The crust is very tasty though so it makes it worth the extra stickiness.

text:
I tested a few recipes and this one is the one I'll be sticking with from now on.  I used a double layer aluminum pizza pan with the aeration holes and this crust turned out excellent.  I also used a not stick spray and a light powdering of flour, but I'm not sure if that had much to do with it.  The consistency of the crust was equal throughout and I didn't even use a rolling pin (I did use a drinking glass to try and get the edges equal though). I would take this over any restaurant style any day.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great pizza dough.  I have been using this recipe for about a year.  I have not had a pizza delivered to my house since then.  I make this about twice a month.  I do add some Italian seasoning and sometimes I think I use a little more flour than the recipe calls for but otherwise I keep it the same.  My family loves it.  I put the dough in my warm car out in the driveway to rise and can sometimes cut that time down.  I use a 1/2 sheet pan lightly greased with evoo and have enough dough for another pizza on the stone.  That one is usually the adult pizza with things like feta and spinach or whatever the kids might not like.  For an easy sauce I just give a quick buzz to a can of Italian tomatoes with the hand blender.  I do not roll out the dough either I just spread it out with my fingers.  This recipe has turned out well every time. It is really worth the extra time.

Thank y so much for sharing this recipe. We make pizza once a week instead of buying now that I've found this awesome recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/59083.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pizza crust recipe was fantastic!  I tried it for the first time when my son had a play date after school that was staying for supper.  I made the dough,but only had time to let it rise for about 1/2 hour.  It still turned out great.  There was a lot of dough! I let the kids (4 of them) each make their own pizza's and baked them on a pizza stone.  We did roll out the dough, but it was not like cardboard.  It still rose while it cooked and tasted great.  The rest of the dough I rolled out to somewhat of a rectangle and place it on a large cookie sheet, spreading the dough to the edges. Topped with sauce and toppings and baked.  This was the best home made pizza I have ever made!  I will definitely use this again and let the kids make their own pizza's this way instead of using canned biscuits covered with flour and rolled out.  It just tastes much better.  Just prepare for the time it has to rise when you start to make it! My error, but I can't wait to make it again! : )  Thanks for submitting!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the first recipe I used when I learned to make dough. After making a few tweaks it comes out perfect. The first few times I struggled a bit with it being to sticky, and also it would get a lot of holes when I hand tossed it.   After watching a couple of youtube videos on making pizza....   I made a few changes such as... adding 3 tablespoons of oil, mixing in 3.33 cups flour right away, Putting it in a ziplock overnight with more oil in it (like in the video), then doing like the guy in the video does of not flouring the work surface but taking a bowl with flour and putting the flour right on the dough. After about 3 attempts I actually made a good pizza so give it a little time if you've never tried before.

text:
Excellent! My boyfriend HATES home-made pizza (just found out last night after 5 years LOL!) but he said it was pretty good and was one of the better home-made pizzas he has ever had. I brushed some melted parmesan garlic butter on the crust before and during baking. However, I would recommend to add more flour than the 2 1/2 cups before you turn out the dough, I had quite the sticky mess for a while and added so much flour to get the right consistency it would have been easier to just mix in some of the additional flour before moving to the next step. Should have used my dough hooks and stand mixer, maybe that will help next time. Excellent crust though, would recommend to bake for a bit before adding toppings if using a standard metal pizza pan. This makes a great pizza!

city:

text:
Thia is easy to make, less complicated than I first thought. I used the dough hook on my Kitchen Aid and it worked great.
After you put in the 2+ cups of flour you just have to "wing it" adding a little more flour at a time until it is no longer sticky. Easy to work with, used a dark 11x17 pan @ 400 degrees for 20-25 min. I still need to keep looking for a good sauce  I have heard that Contadina makes good pizza sauce.
Review:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am an idiot when it comes to bread and pizza dough. Somehow, even with store bought dough, I always have a problem with the dough being soft in the middle, and the cheese burning away LOL. I don't think I did this recipe correctly, and I promise to try it again next week with an update. It definitely has potential and if this many people are raving about it, it has to be me! I used a stand mixer, and when I had used all the 3 1/2 cups, it was still way to sticky to touch, so much that I had to plop it out from the mixing bowl to my oiled bowl, and after an hour or so I had to pour 1/4 cup flour on top of it and all over my hands and knead it through to roll it out. I used 2/3 of it on my 12" pan. I put it in at 325 degrees for 10 minutes, then removed it, topped it, and put it on the lower level for another 17 minutes at 425 degrees as someone else had suggested. To me, it was dryer than I would have liked, but I am guessing it is bc of that extra flour and because of how I baked it. I did add oregano and garlic salt to the dough, and I even put EVOO and garlic butter sprinkle glazed all over the crust, still dry. This DEFINITELY deserves a second shot, and I'll be happy to post the results bc next time I"m just going to do it EXACTLY as the recipe says even if my intuition says to add more flour or bake it differently. I'll be back!!

text:
I've tried making this recipe 3x now.  The first two times it turned out horrible!  Soggy in the middle, blah blah blah, you know the story.  The third time I tried it a year later, I took some suggestions by baking the pizza for 10 minutes first.  I did try the cornmeal idea but it didn't really work, I don't think I added enough Olive Oil for it to soak into the crust, so I probably won't do it again.  But finally the crust turned out decent enough.  I had tried some small cake pans to make deep dish crusts and make them individual.  Needless to say the crust was a bit thick on the outside, but it made 3 little pizza's, and it turned out not half bad.  I think the biggest thing was to bake the pizza for 10 minutes first.  My husband didn't mind it, and I think with a bit more practice I could get it to a five star, but till then I am only going to rate it a 4.  Oh and if you're going to add spices to your dough you might need to add a bit more then you think.  I added Garlic Powder and Italian seasoning but you couldn't even taste it in the dough, so the dough was a bit more on the bland side, I think the next time I try it Im going to try a lot more spices to pep up the crust a bit.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is now the only recipe I use! After many a trial-and-error with other recipes, I have found the winner! So many doughs have an overly yeasty taste, or are tough, hard to roll out, or dry. This pizza crust is great thick, or rolled out thin. It stays nice and chewy and never has that yeasty taste that I think ruins the home-made doughs.
I have used 1 tsp garlic powder, plus half a tsp each of dried basil and oregano, or kept is simple with a tsp of italian seasoning. It is also great with finely minced garlic added to the dough. I never have trouble getting it to stetch to fit virtually any size pan... it stretches easily with no annoying spring-back. I make the dough in my kitchenaid mixer before a final hand-kneading, and bake on convection setting. We are now using this recipe weekly.
Outstanding!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the fabulous (and helpful) reviews for this recipe, I decided to make a pizza for the very first time. I halved the recipe to make one medium pizza. I used garlic salt instead of regular salt, and following others' recommendations, I brushed the crust with olive oil and baked it at 325 degrees F for 10 minutes before adding the toppings. After adding tomato sauce, cheese, and pepperonis, I baked the pizza on a low oven rack at 425 degrees F for 16 minutes. I ended up with a golden brown crust without burning the toppings. My only complaint is that the pizza was a tad bit too oily for me, but then again, it is a pizza. Overall, the crust was very tasty, making my first home-made pizza a great success!

text:
Very good, but like other reviewers I also found it was very "sticky" and need ed to add more flour.  I put in about a teaspoon of Italian seasoning just to add a little something more to the dough.  I baked my pizza in a 13x9 pampered chef stone cookie sheet.  It didn't seem to want to brown and it was pretty thick around the edges.  Made a good deep dish pizza, but we like a little thinner crust.  I will probably make it again.  We all seemed to like it.  Used the exquisite pizza sauce recipe found on this site and we had a very good dinner.  It was a little work, but was fun to say I made the entire pizza by myself.  Our 16 month old grand daughter loved it.  We had to stop her from eating it.

text:
Pretty good for my first try at making pizza dough, though the process was a bit messy. I added more flour then called for since with the initial measurements the dough was so runny. UPDATE: Using the Kitchenaid stand mixer + the dough hook is a million times easier then kneading it yourself! I have made this recipe countless times since first discovering it. I found the taste to be the same, with manually doing it versus using the mixer. The measurements seem to be spot on this way too. 5 stars, everyone loves this recipe!

It was fairly tasty, but not great with my veggie pizza.  I made a half batch with whole wheat flour and 1/4 tsp basil added.
