text:
This is a wonderful recipe that we have been using for several years now! The only suggestion I would make would be that we bake the crust by itself for a few minutes before we put the toppings on and toss it back in the oven for a final baking. This helps keep the pizza from getting too soggy. Of course we add lots of toppings (6+). If you are only adding a few you probably wouldn't need to do this.

text:
Made pizza for the first time last night with this recipe and it was great! Soft and chewy and the slightest bit crunchy.  Instead of letting it rise the extra 15 minutes, I just put it in the oven for 5-6 minutes to brown before I put the toppings on.  Made the recipe exactly as is, except I halved it (8 servings) because I'm only cooking for 2.  Made one nice pizza crust!  Next time I'll add some spices to it.  Don't have a pizza pan or stone, so I just spread it out in a round with my fingers on my cookie sheet.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never made home made pizza crust before so I had no clue what I was doing but apparently this recipe is fool proof.  I used a jelly roll pan with the intent of splitting this into two crusts but there wasn't really enough so I ended up with one very thick crust pizza.  It was soft and chewy and really delicious.  Next time though I will use two round pans and split it in two or use a large size jelly roll pan.  

I baked it for a few moments as suggested and then put the toppings on and baked for another few minutes.  I then put the cheese on and baked until the cheese was golden brown and bubbly. I was worried that it wouldn't be fully cooked because it was so thick but it was cooked perfectly.

thanks for the recipe!

Wow.  I made the dough the night before and wrapped it up in saran wrap and put it in the fridge.  The dough broke through the saran wrap!  I punched it back down and placed it in a rubbermaid container and 8 hours later it had pushed the lid off the container!
I really liked this dough.  My kids LOVED it.  The crispy edges were great.  
I really like the fact that it was a good dough to make ahead of time but make sure you put it in a container instead of saran wrap!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delish...5 stars plus!!  We are a faithful Friday night pizza family (typically McCain Crescendo/Kraft Delissio, etc), but every now and again we like to make our own (usually buy the pizza dough at the store!).  I have looked at this recipe on numerous occasions and wanted to try it.  I made the dough around lunch time and put in the fridge, brought out again just after 5pm to let it proof for a couple of hours (since it was well chilled).  Rolled it out and used a large stoneware bar pan since the recipe yields a large dough.  We always use stoneware for our pizzas as they cook them beautifully (normally the round pizza stone).  This was perfect in my barpan (Pampered Chef) and I liked the raised 'edge'.  I did not add any additional seasonings to the dough as I always season the actual pizza, so added oregano, granulated garlic and pepper along with our toppings.  Needed about 30 mins to bake and the result was AWESOME, perfectly crisp, yet still tender...gotta love stoneware!!  I used 2 cups white flour and 1 1/3 whole wheat.  Beats any store bought or ordered pizza...YUM!

Wow! Nice crust...great to work with.  I did prewarm my pizza stone before putting on the crust after 1st rise (sprinkled corn flour over stone and took a fork and punched holes around the pie)...then baked it about 5-7 min. and then added all the pizza toppings and baked until pizza was done.  When it came out after the pizza was done, I seasoned the crust with olive oil/garlic salt/parm. cheese.   Yum!

text:
This crust looked beautiful and was very easy to make.  I wish that I had listened to the comments that suggest adding spices.  I've never added any flavoring to dough before (other than salt or sugar), but this definitely needs some garlic or onion powder and maybe some Italian seasoning.  

It came out a little dense, but I think that was because I put a lot of flour down when kneading, to avoid sticking.  I substituted 1 c. wheat flour for 1 c. white flour, to make it a little healthier.

With a few modifications, I'd give it 5 stars.

text:
This was fantastic!  I turned half into 4 individual calzones tonight and I froze the other half to use for pizza next week.  I was worried it wasn't going to turn out (I've had spotty luck with yeast dough in the past) but I used a thermometer and followed the directions to a T: after it doubled in size, I knew it was going to be perfect!  I baked the calzones 2 at a time in a 425 oven for 20 minutes on a preheated pizza stone and the exterior was crusty and delicious and the inside was soft and chewy just like the description.  Thanks for the recipe, no more store bought dough for me!

This recipe is great for a soft, easy pizza dough that tastes really good for as simple as it is. I don't work with yeast very often, but it really turned out great. I used one cup of bread flour and the rest all purpose flour. It make it a little bit more doughy, which I'm not sure I'll do next time. However... its soft and really good. I made the easy pizza sauce off this site, for one cheese pizza, then I used the 2nd crust for the Buffalo chicken pizza off of this site. Both turned out great. Thanks!

text:
Great recipe! This made enough for a nice thick crust large pizza tonight.  It could easily be halved and made into 2 medium thinner crust pizzas.  I added 2 tbsp. Italian seasonings for extra flavor and also precooked for about 10 minutes before adding toppings.  Advice:  make sure and brush with olive oil to the edge of the crust so the edges will come out softer. I will be definitely be making this again. Even though I make it by hand, it's a cinch to put together.  Awesome recipe, Jay, thanks!

text:
This was an amazing crust!! I made 1 small thin crust and 2 deep dish pizza's with it. Everyone loved it. I did need more flour then recipe called for but I never work off flour amounts from the recipe. Every flour is different and it depends on the weather as well. It was a nice soft dough and very elastic. Streched out really nicely. The thin crust was really crisp on the bottom and the crust had great bite. The deep dish came out really soft and not soggy at all. The bottom and sides got crisp while the inside stayed soft and fluffy. This is my new pizza dough recipe.

This was such a good crust! Not too thick, not too thin. Crusty and chewy at the same time. It made a lot of dough--enough for a big pizza and garlic knots and even some cinnamon rolls! 

This was a crowd pleaser! My super picky 2 year old scarfed it down, and my even pickier boyfriend ate half the pizza! 

My only complaint was that it was kind of bland. Next time I think I'll add more salt and some garlic, maybe some oregano. 

I also had some trouble getting the dough to rise enough, as it's pretty cool in my apartment. I put the bowl in the oven, covered with foil, set on the lowest setting (200 degrees) for about 15 minutes, and that really helped!

text:
i made this in my bread machine. i read the review that said that the dough was a little too sticky when she made it in the bread machine so i decreased the amount of liquid by 1/8 of a cup. The consistency was good this way. This crust was good but went quite hard around the edges. That may be due to my longer baking time. I put the pizza crust in the oven for 5 minutes before i put the toppings on so that may be why. i would make this again but make the crust thicker and only make one pizza instead of trying to stretch it to make 2.

text:
I added 1 t. Italian seasoning and 1/4 t. fresh cracked black pepper to the dry ingredients to give it more flavor.  Topped it with about 1 to 1-1/2 c. jarred spaghetti sauce.  Next was 12 oz. cooked and crumbled turkey Italian sausage, 1/2 c. chopped sauteed red bell pepper, 1/2 c. sauteed  onions and 8 oz. sliced sauteed mushrooms.  I sprinkled 1/4 t. dried oregano over the top and 8 oz. fancy shredded mixed pizza cheese.  It made a full 1/4 sheet baking pan sized pizza, enough for 12 generous slices.  Wow, was it good!  We are not impressed with delivery pizza anymore after this.  Thanks, Jay.

text:
I made this in my bread machine, and it turned out very well, albiet a little on the sticky side.  It was a bit of a challenge to stretch out to a large rectangle w/out creating holes, but we were eventually successful...we just had to flour & re-flour the surface and our fingers during the process.  Our plan for this dough was to make a Stromboli (rolled bread, stuffed w/ a 1/4 lb. each of thinly sliced deli-style boiled ham, hot Capicola, Genoa Salami, Sandwich-size Pepperoni, and Smoked Provolone Cheese).  This dough held together beautifully during the baking process.  Previously we'd always used store-bought doughs that have split or leaked during baking.  I must say that this dough performed really well.  It had good flavor, but next time I'll probably add some garlic & herbs to enhance the flavor a little more. I will make this dough again, and am looking forward to making traditional pizza with it.

text:
Awesome recipe!  I never would have thought of using brown sugar instead of regular granulated sugar, and I'm not exactly sure what it did for the overall taste, but the pizza came out fabulous.  I halved the recipe since I had a regular sized pizza pan, let it rise and then sit as instructed, and then went straight into piling my sauce, cheese and toppings.  I didn't have a problem with soggy crust in the least; perhaps other reviewers used too much dough?  Remember that this one recipe as written is enough to make a GINORMOUS pizza!  Next time I'll see if I can add extra spices to the dough, or brush it down with a little extra olive oil to sprinkle some oregano and/or garlic powder before baking.  The texture was great, but the taste was a little generic.  The second half of my pizza dough, which I stuck in the freezer for later, won't last the week!

I made this at the weekend and was positively surprised. I made it with wholemeal flour and it turned out a bit dense. However, my boyfriend said it was still the best crust I've ever made. This is really great pizza crust!! It's not the easiest or quickest to prepare but it tastes really good. It doesn't have that "homemade" taste other recipes Ive tried had. 
 I made it in a 13x9" glass pan as a deep dish and it turned out really really good. (I had a little extra dough so I made a 13x9 AND an 8x8)
 There was enough to feed the whole family, 6 of us, and we usually order 2 larges when we order pizza.

This is a great crust!  I added some chopped fresh rosemary and oregano to the mix.  I also had to use 4 and 1/4 cup of flour before it was no longer sticky. text:
WoW!! All the reviews already say how excellent this pizza crust is...but WOW. I don't have a pizza stone since this is my first time making pizza but I used round cake pans lightly greased and dusted with flour, to make four individual pizzas. They turned out wonderful. I didn't have any problem with the flour. If you knead the dough it adds that additional flour without making the dough too tough. I also let the dough rise a couple hours extra. MMM...THANKS for the recipe.

text:
Another thumbs up for this recipe--mine cooked up perfectly, not too thin, not too thick, not overpowering but not totally bland.  I added a tablespoon of Italian seasoning.  I also ran out of all-purpose flour after adding about a cup and a half, so I added whole wheat flour for the rest and it came out beautifully.  It was sticky with the quantities given, but I added a little more flour (kneaded with my Kitchenaid mixer) and it was easy to work with.  It makes enough for two full-sized pizzas.  Thanks for sharing!

text:
I've made this crust several times and I wasn't sure if I wanted to give this recipe 3 or 4 stars....It was super easy to put together, and that's a big selling point for me...However, as others have said, it is kind of bland.  Also, even if you roll the dough out thinly, it puffs up quite a bit, making it a bit too thick for our liking.  I've also found that rolling it out is extremely hard to do.  It always wants to shrink back up.  I tried brushing the outer edges with olive oil and a few different seasonings last time and it came out much more flavorful. Nevertheless, I'm actaully using this recipe tonight to make pizza just because it's the easiest one I've found out there.  Just make sure to add some salt/seasonings to it if you make it.

I've tried this recipe twice before, and it didn't turn out, due mostly to my own error with the mixer.  This time, however, the crust turned out perfectly, chewy and crispy as everyone has described.  I divided the dough into 4 sections before the second rise, and rolled 3 of them to the varying thickness my family likes and topped accordingly, and made the last section into small breadsticks.  Excellent- definitely a crowd pleaser!

This is becoming a Friday night tradition for our family, and it is cheaper and tastes way better than the take and bake pizza we used to get.  YUMMY!!!!

text:
This was a fantastic recipe.  Very easy to make, I don't understand why some had problems with it.  I did add some pizza seasonings to the mix before I added the flour, then used it to make a white pizza(sauceless).  I halved the dough, to save the other half, spun it out and put it on a medium baking stone..brushed with oil and minced garlic, cooked it at the recommended temp for 7 minutes, then topped, cooked for 12 more then broiled for a couple.. we used fresh mozzarella, fresh tomato, mushrooms, sausage, with a bit of goat cheese.  It was fabulous and as good as a lot of restaurants I've been at.

text:
This is a great pizza crust, I ended up with a crispy crust on the outside, and a chewy inside.  I added some garlic powder to the crust which added great flavour, i also used vege oil since I didn't have any olive oil on hand, and it turned out fantastic, only used 3 cups of flour. Some words of advice, do not increase the cooking temperature, I did and it resulted in a burnt crust, turned down the temperature for the 2nd crust and it was perfect.  I halved the recipe to make two medium pizzas.

text:
I changed this recipe slightly, using 1 1/4 cups water, 3 cups flour and 1 1/2 packets of yeast.  The end result was good, but it made a lot of dough so next time I think I'll use 3/4 cups water, 2 cups flour and 1 packet of yeast.  That should be good for two people, especially as I prefer to use it for thin crust pizza.  The thick crust version is a bit bready.

Followed recipe exactly.  It was so easy to roll out.  I used it for two medium pizzas.  My husband's first comment was how much he liked the crust. country:
None
text:
Before I found this recipe, I had given up on making homemade pizza.  I could not find a crust that was good.  Well, around here takeout pizza is terrible so I gave this a try.  I make this  (scaled down 1/2 to make one crust) with bread flour and quick-rise yeast.  My picky husband loves it!  It is soft on the inside and nicely crispy on the outside.  I have better luck using shortening to grease the pan since olive oil seems to make it slide it around.  I also tried to freeze the original two-crust recipe and it didn't taste as good when I made it fresh.  This crust comes out perfect every time.  I've conquered making pizza!

country:
None
text:
this was great. so, so easy to make and knead - i don't have that much experience with making dough, so i was worried about getting a sticky mess, but this wasn't sticky or difficult to manage at all! i didn't have a round pizza pan, so i used a rectangular pan and made 'sicilian style' pizza, with the Exquisite Pizza Sauce from this site, topped with grilled vegetables and mozzarella. my only complaint was that as i love really thin and crispy crust, this was a little thick and bready - but i think that's cos my was smaller than a round one would have been, so the dough wasn't rolled as thin. but cos this is so easy and tasted so great, i'm going to buy a proper pizza stone for next time i make it! i think also that will make a crisper base. i made dough balls (golf ball sized lumps of dough, baked and served with dip - just like at pizza express - a uk pizza chain, i live in england) with the leftover dough, which were yummy.

This turned out great! It was just as the description says, soft and doughy on the inside and slightly crispy on the outside. I topped it with Boboli pizza sauce (my favorite pizza sauce, I hate those Boboli pizza shells though!) mozzarella cheeze, pepperoni, and red pepper. So good! My husband, (MR.PICKY) raved about the crust! He told me to stick with this recipe. I had a little of the dough left over, so I made a calzone with it. This is the perfect pizza crust for me, and it is the only one I will use now! (Note: I used a pizza stone dusted with cornmeal to cook the pizza on. To me, this is the best way to cook a pizza at home.)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
My kids love pizza, and I was tired of the cheap-tasting store-bought varieties.  My wallet was also tired of the delivered restaurant-style pizza, so I decided to use this recipe.  

This was the best pizza crust I have ever made (in fact the only pizza crust I have ever made), and my kids raved about it!! I am finally considered a better cook than my mother.  I intended to follow the recipe to the letter, but I ran out of olive oil and had to use canola...my brown sugar was a little hard (albeit dissolvable), and I used a standard non-stick pizza pan.  Then I discovered that the bottom element in my oven had burnt out.  Believe it or not, this pizza crust still came out perfect(after cranking up the heat on the top element and placing the crust on the lowest rack). I can't wait to get my oven fixed, buy some olive oil and brown sugar, and try it again!

This was my first attempt at working with yeast and (thank God) it actually turned out! It wasn't even that hard! I let the KitchenAid knead the dough so it was a snap. The only complaint I have is that if you use a stone you must preheat it or it will take FOREVER to cook. Also, it was a little yeasty tasting, next time I would add a tad more salt.

None
text:
This is a great crust! I added some garlic and fresh basil to the dough.  Also, you can divide the dough into five and make personal pizzas.  I am thinking of making a few different flavor crusts:  garlic and basil, crushed red peppers, sundried tomato and parmesan.  I found that you do have to keep adding more all-purpose flour to make it easier to handle.

text:
This is a yummy pizza dough. I make it in a bread machine using bread flour. Sometimes I have to knead in a little extra flour after taking it out of the machine. I halve the dough. One half I use in a 13"x9" pan, other half I freeze for later. I prebake the dough for about 10 minutes before adding toppings and then continue to bake for 10-15 minutes more. The pizzas always turn out great.

text:
Wow! With 148 5-star responses I had to try this crust.  I wasn't expecting anything new as I've been having pizza parties with many family members at least once or twice a month for several years.  I've used the same recipe for years, but always wanted something with a more tender texture, soooooo I gave this recipe a shot.  Wow!  What a hit with all our regular diehards!  This crust is delicious and is different!  I found the crust to be a little sticky as well, but dipped my fingers into olive oil solved the problem beautifully!  I also patted the crust into the pan with oiled fingers and it behaved beautifully. Lastly, I doubled the recipe and had three perfect crusts.  The best!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This just replaced my 10-year "tried and true" recipe.  It was exceptionally easy, as I re-scaled it to 12 servings, then mixed it in a regular food processor with a metal blade (no special plastic blade needed) for about 4 minutes.  It was a little sticky getting every last bit out of the processor, but the time and energy savings were worth it.  I did knead it for about 2 minutes before rolling out one very large pizza the size of my stone.  My entire family loved it, including two very discerning teenage boys! Good work, Jay. Next I'll try the topping given in the "Onion Strips" recipe at this site.  Can't wait!

text:
This was SO simple... why couldn't the 20 other crust recipes I've tried get it right!  Thanks Jay....it is an absolutely perfect crust.  Don't need to try any more sub-standard recipes.. it's a keeper.  My hint: Instead of rolling it out, I pressed it out with my fingers (recommendation from a cooking show).  This allows it to rise better and stay "fluffy" instead of compressed.  Worked great.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the absolute best pizza crust I've ever had. I used white sugar instead of brown, mixed quick rise yeast directly into the flour mixture, and used about four cups of flour. It made enough for one thick pizza crust and also breadsticks. Brush oil onto the pan, then sprinkle with cornmeal before pressing the dough into the pan. It gives the crust a wonderful crunchy, nutty texture.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great tasting crust. My husband loved it! I let the kitchenaid do all the kneeding and it turned out great and made it really easy. Only downfall was it is a very soft crust so the topping browned before the bottom, causing a slight imbalance and too soft a crust to hold heavy toppings. That can easily be corrected by pre-cooking the crust a little. Other than that, it's great and I'll look no more for another. This one is very workable and we really enjoyed it.
